PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and is in light of the comments of the Minister for Finance yesterday that the government's intention to raise taxes is again `on the table'. I remind the minister of the broken promises budget of last year—which related to the tax issue—and the pledge by the then Treasurer late last year that there would be `no further need for any need for any future tax increases'. I ask the minister: does government policy change with a change of minister, and are the Australian people now being softened up for yet another round of tax increases in breach of the previous Treasurer's promise?

—If anything at all was said yesterday, it would rather indicate to the contrary. I have no comment whatsoever to make about any tax changes the government may or may not be proposing to contemplate in this budget. The question of the future of the jobs levy and the pros and cons of that has been amply debated already. Even in the absence of any explicit government commitment one way or another, these are matters that will be resolved in the budgetary process and it is inappropriate to comment further at this stage.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister saying that reference by the Minister for Finance to tax increases being on the table relates only to the government's proposed jobs levy? Is he ruling out any other tax increases in accordance with the pledge that was given by the previous Treasurer to the Australian people late last year?
—The Minister for Finance is big enough and strong enough to speak for himself. He did so yesterday. I have nothing to add to anything he said.

—I refer the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to a meeting last week in Geneva of the steering committee of the comprehensive plan of action for Indochinese refugees. This meeting, convened by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, discussed the issue of Vietnamese boat people. According to the media reports, the outcome of that meeting is that Vietnamese boat people will now be treated in the same way as asylum seekers from other countries. What is the significance of this meeting and what is Australia's involvement in the comprehensive plan of action?
—Why didn't you ask him about the jobs levy?

—He asked me about that at the weekend. I thank the honourable senator for what is a significant question. The conference to which he refers, which was the fifth meeting of the steering committee of the comprehensive plan of action—the CPA—for Indochinese refugees, was convened in Geneva by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Mrs Ogata, and was a significant development in the CPA.

PARA.TAB: The CPA has been an important part of the process of resettling Indochinese refugees. In 1989, the CPA was adopted in response to the humanitarian crisis caused by the continuing outflow of Indochinese asylum seekers during the 1980s. It put in place special arrangements for the reception, processing, resettlement and return of asylum seekers. An important part of the CPA was to consolidate an orderly migration program from Vietnam.

The meeting held in Geneva last week, at which once again Australia was represented at a very senior level, came to four important decisions. Firstly, with respect to the people involved, as at 14 February 1994, Vietnamese arriving in CPA countries by boat would be considered in the same way as asylum seekers from any other country. Secondly, the end of 1995 was set as a target date for bringing the work of the comprehensive plan of action and first asylum countries to a close. The third part of the decision, and an important aspect, is that there was agreement by countries, including the United States, for the use of non-voluntary return of non-refugees. In this context, countries hope that, with US support, together with the lifting of the US trade embargo on Vietnam, those non-refugees still in camps would now opt for voluntary return. But to put this aspect of the decision in perspective, at the end of last year there were 48,000 Vietnamese non-refugees in five camps throughout the region—about half of them in Hong Kong.

Another important aspect of the decision relates to the residual case load, that is, people who have been in comprehensive plan of action countries who have been screened but, because of health and character problems, have not been resettled. It is expected some several thousand of those people will be in this category by the end of 1995. First asylum countries consider that these people should be accepted by Vietnam.

The CPA, as it does draw to a close, has had numerous and quite significant achievements. Since its inception in 1989, the number of persons leaving Indochina by boat has reduced to a trickle, and the resettlement of refugees has continued. Some 60,000 people have returned home under the CPA arrangements. It should be noted that the UNHCR ensures that the returns are carried out in conditions of safety and dignity and, of course, maintains a comprehensive monitoring program in Vietnam for returnees. To assist the resettlement, the repatriation, the international community funds special projects to assist communities where these returnees have settled. It should be noted that Australia has allocated $100 million to development assistance in Vietnam through its overseas aid program, the end result of part of which would be to assist such resettlement.

Australia has played an important role in this process, not just in terms of its contribution to the CPA, but also in terms of its reception of people under this program. Since 1989, for instance, 15,000 Vietnamese and Laotian refugees have been resettled in Australia. In 1993-94, a further 2,200 refugees will be accepted in Australia. As I said, the CPA is now drawing to a conclusion. People have already been returned to their homes with dignity, but as it draws to a conclusion it is acknowledged in the region that it has been an important initiative in which Australia has played an important role. It is an example of multilateral cooperation in response to what was an immense regional crisis. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

As Senator Gareth Evans has stonewalled on this vital question, I refer Senator Cook to the deep internal split within the Labor Party over the jobs levy proposal, and to the comments of his colleague Senator Carr this morning in support of a levy when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is quite apparent there is a need to broaden the options in terms of taxation policy within this country to ensure that we have access to larger sources of revenue.
If members of Cabinet are saying certain matters before business groups and other forums, I think it is appropriate that Caucus members also express their attitude.

I ask the minister: firstly, does he agree with Senator Carr's comments that we need more revenue raising options in the budget and that the views of cabinet ministers such as Mr Beazley and himself on this issue are not in accord with those of caucus? Secondly, can he explain to the Senate how a jobs levy would create one new job?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that if Senator Short—
—Have you been in the sun or are you embarrassed?

—I actually got in the sun. I apologise to Senator Richardson for not `slip, slop, slapping' in an appropriate way. If Senator Short wants to participate in any internal Labor Party debate, then he should resign from his party and join the Labor Party. This is not a forum in which I propose to canvass the various views that are often expressed, sometimes in a robust way, in internal debate in a democratic party like the Australian Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: On the question of the jobs levy, there was a green paper on employment which was a report to the government. It is not a government proposal; it is contained in a report to the government. That, along with all the other recommendations in the green paper report, is of course being considered in a process that we are engaged in, in producing a white paper on employment. It stems from our concern about how one deals with long-term unemployment and a number of other aspects of the jobs market. When the white paper is finally brought down it will doubtless cover issues like industry policy and regional development.

We are in the gestation phase. We have a report to us, and it is necessary for us to consider it. Therefore, it is accurate to describe it as being on the table in front of us. Until that time, questions on this subject are idle or simply mischievous in order to try to stir up some esoteric political point that the opposition, divided as it is, would like to make in order to distract attention from itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say Senator Cook's obfuscation makes Senator Evans look positively forthcoming. —The introduction to this supplementary question was that I had failed to answer. I did not fail to answer; I declined to answer. PARA.TAB: On the issue of the jobs levy, that was a recommendation that was put as an option in a paper canvassing options for employment, in particular dealing with the long-term unemployed. That is a report to the government, and we will respond to that. I am not going to respond here. As I have said, it is in gestation. We will respond to it in a proper, measured and responsible way in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the Senate what action the government is taking to ensure that people living in rural and remote areas of Australia have access to the same level of community facilities and services as their urban counterparts?
—The Department of Primary Industries and Energy does administer a number of programs that are directed to this end, including—
—Do you have a whiteboard?

—In respect of that interjection, Senator Ferguson should just wait one minute. For consistency, I am expecting a censure motion in respect of this answer. Programs include the telecentres program, which aims to improve access to communications technology in rural Australia; the countrylink program, which provides information on government services; and the rural access program. The RAP aims to improve skills and training and provide better access in remote areas to health services and information. It helps local groups in small, isolated rural communities to become involved in providing services relevant to their own areas. To date, 337 of these communities have received assistance. I have just approved funding of in excess of $255,000 for 26 projects under the second round of rural access program grants for 1993-94.

PARA.TAB: The successful projects include providing funding to enable a student hostel development in Chinchilla in Queensland to operate 12 months earlier than planned—for Senator Boswell's interest, that is in a National Party electorate—and also a tractor safety project in Moree, which is in the electorate of the Deputy Leader of the National Party, John Anderson. That tractor safety project is designed to respond to the ministerial advisory group on farm safety.

I believe the preponderance of these grants are in fact in National Party electorates. As I said before in response to Senator Ferguson's interjection, in view of consistency I do expect to be censured by the opposition about that. RAP is community driven. To be successful for these grants projects must demonstrate active community support, either in cash or through contributions such as personal services or the provision of venues and equipment provided free of charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer to media reports that the government is unlikely to implement most of the Kelty regional development task force recommendations. Is the minister still actively considering the task force recommendations for a significant increase to the road building program, for additional support for further wool and fibre processing, for the retention of the pharmaceutical industry development program, for the retention of the shipbuilding bounty and for enhancing the information technology strategy? Secondly, does the minister agree that failure to proceed as recommended would have significant negative effect on regional employment, particularly since Australian investment and superannuation funds continue to flow unchecked into Asia to create jobs there?

—I can tell Senator Spindler that our policy formulation process is on track and moving according to timetable. The government, as I have said, will probably bring down, around budget time, a white paper which will respond to those issues of employment, industry policy and regional development—all of those things. In the regional development area, we have before us the Kelty report on regional Australia, there is an Industry Commission report, and I am in anticipation of a report from McKinsey and Company Inc. on business investment in regions, which report is due at the end of this month. I think it is appropriate that we have all of those recommendations before us and respond to them across the board. At this stage that is my intention.

PARA.TAB: It is a big agenda and it is certainly an important one. No-one would ever underestimate the importance and significance of the issues before us. There is widespread interest across the board about all of these matters. We have received a huge number of submissions on them. Indeed, I have seen reports over the weekend that even government caucus members have put specific views in public. All of those things will, of course, be properly and reasonably considered by the government when it formulates its response.

There are 137 different recommendations in the Kelty report. I thank Senator Spindler for indicating some of the areas on which his interest focuses, but I add that the report contains a number of other significant recommendations, some of which concern taxation, some of which concern education and a range of other things as well. All of those things have to be responded to. We will do so when we have completed our process. I will answer Senator Spindler's question but in the form of the statement when it comes down.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I am certain the minister will be aware of recent developments in Burma involving Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, including the call on her last week by US Congressman Bill Richardson, and indications over very recent days that talks might even be held between her and General Khin Nyunt of the SLORC. At the same time, there have been reports that her period of detention may be extended for a further six months. What is the reaction of the Australian government to these apparently conflicting responses in Burma?

—In the first place, the relaxation of the conditions of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's detention involved in allowing access to her by United States Congressman Richardson in his visit last Monday, 14 February, is a very positive step by the Burmese State Law and Order Council—or SLORC—and one which we unequivocally welcome.

PARA.TAB: I also particularly welcome indications of a possible meeting between General Khin Nyunt, who is secretary of the SLORC, and Aung San Suu Kyi. We very much hope that such a meeting will take place and that it might lead to a wider dialogue on the issues confronting Burma, including the process of national reconciliation and an improvement of human rights as well as, of course, to the immediate and unconditional release of Aung San Suu Kyi, which we and the rest of the international community have long been calling for. Such a dialogue is an absolutely crucial element in any process of reconciliation that might be contemplated in Burma. Again, it is one that we have long advocated as an important first step. We just hope there is some reality to that prospect, but the reports at the moment have not yet confirmed that that will occur.

There is one other report which, however, points in the other direction and is disconcerting and that is the suggestion that the SLORC has extended Aung San Suu Kyi's period of detention until January 1995. Prior to these reports there had been speculation that she would be released in July this year. General Khin Nyunt has said that a decision on her period of detention has not been made. We obviously hope that the SLORC will send an unambiguously positive signal by releasing her in the short term, but I have to say there has still been no real indication that it is prepared to do so.

Finally, Australia continues to work away quietly in the hope of making a positive contribution to the resolution of the continuing tragic situation in Burma. In particular, a couple of weeks ago we convened an experts workshop jointly with the Griffith University centre for the study of Australia-Asia relations. The participants in that workshop included regional and other academics with specialist knowledge of the situation in Burma and broader regional affairs and conflict resolution. The workshop was intended to generate a fresh infusion of ideas from various key people around the world who are knowledgeable about this area on how national reconciliation in Burma might be achieved and what role the international community might play.

It is very much in keeping with our strong support for what is called second track diplomacy as a tool in seeking solutions to complex problems of this kind. I hope that the ideas that emerge from that workshop, which were quite substantial, will prove useful. At the present moment the government is giving close consideration to them and how they might be advanced. It may be that, before too long, I will be in a position to say something further publicly about that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Senator Schacht has advised this chamber that Mr Frank Kelly will receive the same pay as a senior adviser in DITARD as he did when he was Comptroller-General of Customs; that is, a base salary of $126,760, plus allowances. The Secretary to DITARD also receives a base salary of $126,760. On what basis did the minister approve, or agree to, an adviser in his department receiving the same salary as the Secretary?

—It is my understanding that a decision on salary was made by the departmental secretary, as my delegate. It was not made by me. The salary figure was one that was recommended after consultations with the relevant persons.
—By whom?

—By the Public Service Commissioner—the person who is in the correct position to make this recommendation. It arose in the consultations over Mr Kelly's future, bearing in mind always, which sometimes people in this chamber tend to forget, that he was a statutory office holder and entitled to continue in office should he not choose to stand aside. That is my understanding of these circumstances.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It would seem from the minister's answer that he is implying there was some sort of obligation to continue employing Mr Kelly on his old salary for the time he would have been Comptroller-General, that is, 20 months. Is there a legal obligation to employ Mr Kelly on $126,000 for another 20 months? Or is it the case that, under Public Service mobility provisions, Mr Kelly is only legally entitled to return to the salary level of his previous substantive position of Deputy Comptroller-General with a base salary of between $85,000 and $103,000 and, therefore, Mr Kelly is receiving special treatment?

—It appears that Senator Ferguson did not listen to the answer I gave to the question. Had he listened to the answer he would not have led off in his supplementary in the manner in which he did. I made the point in my answer that Mr Kelly was a statutory office holder and had he chosen to do so he could have continued as the Director-General of Customs.
—But he resigned.

—He resigned and did so obviously after a consideration of all the circumstances and with the relevant Public Service personnel and, on the recommendation from the Public Service Commissioner—as I say, this is my understanding—a decision about salary was made when it was indicated—
—Was there a legal obligation to employ him at that salary?
—There was a legal obligation to recognise the rights of a statutory office holder.
—But he resigned.

—He resigned in circumstances which are notorious and well known in this chamber and do not require any repetition from me. But the fact is that the government acted on the best advice of the most responsible and senior person advising on this matter, the Public Service Commissioner.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns reports of the killing of as many as 200 East Timorese following the massacre in Dili in 1991. Has the Australian government received any information regarding the fate of survivors of the Dili massacre? What actions has the government taken to investigate this claim of gross human rights abuses in the former Portuguese colony? Will the government be reviewing its military relationship with Indonesia in the light of the evidence of further human rights abuses?

—Our embassy has been very closely following developments in East Timor, not least since the Dili massacre. But we have never obtained any evidence to suggest that the number of deaths was anything like the scale that has now been alleged in this latest Pilger documentary. At the time I said that our best estimate of those killed was about 75. The commission of inquiry established by the Indonesian government rejected, of course, the initial official figure of 19 deaths and estimated about 50 deaths. There are other assessments which have put the figure at anywhere between 50 and 200, but none of them seem to be based on hard or substantial evidence.

PARA.TAB: At the time our embassy assessed that the discrepancy between claims concerning the number of people killed and claims about the number of bodies counted in the cemetery did indicate that there might conceivably have been a second series of killings which took place away from the cemetery. However, we found then and still find any evidence for such a second series of killings to be quite sketchy and circumstantial. In particular, we have no evidence at all to confirm the claims that have been made concerning the treatment of wounded East Timorese at the local military hospital. There were no allegations at the time or subsequently, until now, that a second series of killings did take place at the military hospital. And there have also been what I might describe as reasonably credible witnesses, like Father Wanandi who does have some connections and associations with the government but nonetheless is a Jesuit priest in high standing who reportedly administered communion at the hospital daily at the time to wounded East Timorese students. We now have his public statement in the past few days dismissing Pilger's allegations concerning events at the hospital.

Nonetheless, it is the case as I said publicly yesterday that there is a conflict of evidence about some of these things and it is not possible yet to finally draw the line on what precisely happened, when and where and how many people were in fact killed and how many remain unaccounted for. Our ambassador in Jakarta accordingly raised these reports, as has been made public, with Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas, when he met him last week. If the allegations did prove to be true the Australian government would, of course, voice its very strong concerns, as we did clearly and persistently at the time of the Dili killings.

As I said at the time, and I repeat it now because this goes to the last part of the question, we have no evidence to suggest that these killings were a deliberate act of state policy in any way. Rather, all the evidence seemed to be that they were a case of aberrant behaviour by elements of the military.

We believe that the Indonesian government's actions following the killings, the establishment of the independent commission of inquiry, the sentences that were awarded to security authorities through the Military Honour Council, the unprecedented statements of regret by President Suharto, all amounted to a really credible response to the event.

We have continued to urge the Indonesian government to clarify the number and status of those missing. I have raised this with Foreign Minister Alatas on a number of occasions; our embassy in Jakarta has recently raised it again. The Indonesian government has informed the UN Secretary-General that 56 people remain missing. That is the latest of a successive series of pronouncements by the government about those missing, the previous statement from armed forces spokesmen putting it at 64.

We are aware of discrepancies between those figures and those of the independent commission of inquiry which found that 91 people were missing. That is part of the reason why, for example, at the Commission on Human Rights last year we voted in favour of a resolution expressing concern about the lack of information on the number of people killed in November 1991, and urging the Indonesian government to account fully for those missing. We remain concerned about the absence of final and conclusive evidence on this whole question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Firstly, in the light of the offensive description of nuns published in the Macquarie Dictionary Thesaurus, what action has the Office of the Status of Women taken to ensure that this degrading attack on a charitable and vulnerable female religious order is checked? Secondly, can the minister either explain or justify the selective moral outrage of the women's groups which have not protested the gender-based slurs directed against nuns through the Macquarie Dictionary Thesaurus, as they would have those against other females?

—I have no advice from Minister Kelly about whether she is taking any action at all about the Macquarie Dictionary. It is drawing a very long bow to make an association between words in the Macquarie Dictionary and the Minister's responsibilities. But certainly I will make sure that that question is passed to her to see whether she has any further comment.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht. I understand that last year the minister convened a meeting with various groups to discuss a range of issues relating to an increasingly complex and important policy area referred to as the technical infrastructure. Is the minister able to provide any information about the issues covered by the meeting, and what developments have taken place since that time?

—In the past two or three months there have been some press stories about disputes going on between various bodies responsible for carrying out standards or technical infrastructure matters in the Australian economy. As a result of some of that controversy, in December last year I convened a meeting between a number of the industry groups to discuss these matters. There were increasing numbers of representations to me from industry saying that these matters had to be cleared up.

PARA.TAB: I also want to say that, although this sounds a very dry and boring area, technical infrastructure or standards is a very important area for Australian industry. We in the industry portfolio see it as being an important area of micro-economic reform. Industry wants to have an open, transparent system of setting standards so that there is uniformity across all of Australia. Those standards also equate with our export drives, so the standards we have in Australia for industry are also relevant to our international markets.

When I convened the meeting the following groups were present: the National Association of Testing Authorities, Standards Australia, the National Standards Commission, the National Measurement Laboratories, the Joint Accreditation System of Australia and New Zealand, various industry groups and officers of my department.

During that meeting it became clear that there were quite strongly held differences of opinion about the roles of NATA and Standards Australia—that they are competing with each other. Some industry groups were getting concerned that laboratory accreditation may be adversely affected for industry by the unnecessary competition between these bodies. I have asked both these bodies to respond to me about ways in which this controversy can be overcome so that we can have in Australia a simple and transparent system of maintaining standards which is cheap and efficient to industry and also easily understood. I must say, as minister responsible for part of this area, that it is a very complex structure we have in Australia and I do not think industry at times gets the best deal out of it because it is rather complex.

As a result of the meeting and asking for submissions, I hope to have the issues considered, including the role of the National Association of Testing Authorities and the role of Standards Australia; the nature and relationship between Standards Australia and its subsidiary, Standards Australia Quality Assurance Service; and, more generally, the national interest issues versus commercial considerations.

They are complex issues and particularly important in reducing cost to business in Australia. To make ourselves an internationally competitive economy, these are issues that have to be addressed. I hope to be able to report back to parliament in the near future on a successful outcome to these discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Will the minister please explain why the South Fremantle Football Club requested a $4,000 sports grant and was actually given $50,000, while the goldfields shire of Menzies, which is part of a lower socioeconomic percentile, applied for a grant of $10,000 and got not one cent?

—I cannot explain that at the moment but I shall certainly seek to. I can tell Senator Knowles that in the year in question when Mrs Kelly was allocating $30 million for $100 million worth of grants, quite clearly, it was never going to be possible to stretch 30 into 100 and therefore some were going to miss out, and the one she has nominated missed out. I regret that that could have occurred. It would be nice to be able to fund them all. I do not understand the first part of the question and I will certainly seek some information from Mrs Kelly to find out what the reasons are.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the minister seen statements by Dr Adrienne Clarke identifying population increase as the basic threat to the global environment, including greenhouse, ozone depletion, desertification and soil erosion? Does he recognise the rapid rise of population in the Asia-Pacific region? Has the minister also seen the statements by Dr Marc Latham, Director-General of the International Board for Soil Research and Management, that the loss of soil, water and nutrients poses a far greater and longer term danger to the Asia-Pacific region than a trade war between the US and Japan? This is the reason why the question is directed to the minister and not to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. How does the minister reconcile this environmental analysis of what is happening in the Asia-Pacific region with the gung-ho economists' prediction of boom times to which Australia should attach its economic and social future?
—I have not seen the statements to which the honourable senator refers and, if I had, I am not sure that I would be terribly much the wiser about what the point of Senator Coulter's question is.

PARA.TAB: Of course the government is aware of the problems posed to the world's environment by the loss of soil, water and nutrients, and of course we are aware of the potential environmental impact of rapid population increase. Whilst Drs Clarke and Latham may have only been writing or speaking about these issues recently in the statements Senator Coulter cites, they are hardly newly identified problems. They are problems which we are making our own contribution to addressing through the aid program and also through our input into the multitude of international environmental bodies that have been coming to grips with these various problems.

The Commission on Sustainable Development, for instance, in which Australia is particularly active, has, as its name would imply, a mandate to promote policies in which economic development is balanced against environmental considerations and to assist developing countries in that regard.

The basic problem I have with Senator Coulter's question is that it seems to imply that one cannot do two things at once in addressing these sorts of problems—that one cannot talk and chew gum at the same time. The fact of the matter is that there is no absolute inconsistency between economic development of the kind which is occurring in such a dynamic fashion in the Asia-Pacific region and environmental protection. A cogent argument can in fact be made that countries experiencing economic development will—at least eventually—be much better placed financially and otherwise to deal with problems such as population pressure and various other environmental problems that are associated with this age and the technology of the age, and the population pressures within the country in question.

An equally cogent argument could also be made that a trade war, which Senator Coulter also seems to think has some bearing on this, between the United States and Japan could have such deleterious effects on countries in the Asia-Pacific region, if it were to be pursued to its most alarming conclusion, that any hopes of their rapidly being able to solve the environmental problems they already have would be seriously diminished thereby. For all those different reasons, I think the question, with the utmost respect to Senator Coulter, is quite misconceived.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the minister aware of the considerable concern being expressed by Tasmanian women's organisations regarding the failure of the government to appoint a Tasmanian representative to the Australian Council for Women? Does the minister acknowledge the importance of including women from isolated and rural areas and representatives from all states and territories in national consultative bodies? If so, how does it justify this blatant snub of Tasmanian women? Does the government consider that the needs of Tasmanian women can be best represented by a woman outside their state? Is the government prepared to instigate action to correct this glaring anomaly?

—The Australian Council for Women was established in November 1993 as the focal point for planning and coordinating the Australian activities relating to the preparation for the fourth United Nations conference on women to be held in Beijing in 1995. The members of that council were selected on the basis of their breadth and range of expertise and their links with their community, not on geography. The main functions of the council are to provide expert advice to the government on the most effective ways of preparing for that world conference, to liaise with the community sectors, including non-government organisations, academia, the private sector, the media and the public, and to assist the non-government organisations to provide high quality advice to the government on how best to prepare for the world conference.

PARA.TAB: I am aware of the concerns from Tasmania and, indeed, I think a number of my Tasmanian colleagues have written to the government about the absence of Tasmanian representation on that committee. In the end, it is a matter of balance—of making sure that the expertise is there on the committee. We cannot, of course, have somebody from everywhere on the committee.

The important thing is that Tasmanian representatives, particularly Tasmanian women, have an opportunity to have their voices heard through that council, and it will be making sure that it seeks the opinion of Tasmanian women. I will certainly pass on this matter to Minister Kelly and see whether she can add anything further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer, but I really would like to know from Mrs Kelly why Tasmanian women do not have the expertise that Senator Crowley is talking about and how she believes they can be best represented. I advise the minister that the state government has a very able and hardworking committee. So it surprises me, and I think all Tasmanians, that the Commonwealth has not seen fit to appoint a Tasmanian woman to the Australian body.

—I am very pleased to make clear to Senator Calvert that the appointment of women to this committee is no measure of the insufficiency of Tasmanian women; it was a measure of the skills and talents of the women appointed. It is not to say that other women not appointed to that committee do not have skills. Of course many Tasmanian women have a number of skills. They have made, and continue to make, contributions, indeed, on other committees which they have participated in and have been appointed to. But, as I say, I appreciate the contribution of women in Tasmania. It will be sought. That committee will be making sure that it consults with the women in Tasmania. I will seek an answer from Mrs Kelly if there is anything further to add.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Following the announcement earlier today of an Australian jewellery manufacturer's successful entry into the Japanese market, will the minister inform the Senate of the implications of this announcement for this industry sector?

—This is, in fact, a good case study of government backing private sector initiative, helping remove impediments, providing market intelligence and enabling a private sector initiative therefore to flourish. A consortium of Australian jewellery manufacturers, known as Austjewel, has successfully entered the Japanese market with significant sales of distinctive, high quality Australian jewellery to Seiko's wholesale agents.

PARA.TAB: Austjewel is a network of five independent jewellery manufacturers who joined forces to increase their productive and marketing capacity and who have an uncompromising commitment to quality of design, production and service. Their success in closing a deal with Seiko demonstrates their achievement to world's best standards. Support programs provided by my department and Austrade led to the establishment of Austjewel and helped it in its business and export marketing planning, market research and in its review of leading edge technology in the world jewellery market. The enterprise networking program enabled Austjewel to retain Export Bridge Japan, a company which specialises in the Japanese market and which was of tremendous value to Austjewel in setting up contacts with Seiko.

The sales were achieved at a special exhibition arranged by the Seiko Corporation in Tokyo earlier this month. Further large orders are expected within the next few weeks. The importance which both Seiko and Australia attached to the Austjewel launch was demonstrated by the fact that Seiko was represented at the highest corporate level and the Australian government was represented by the Ambassador to Japan, the deputy head of mission and the departmental counsellor in Tokyo.

Austjewel's commitment to quality and leading edge technology has been crucial to the consortium's success in a very tough market. Its success is the culmination of five years solid partnership between the department, Austrade and the consortium. It is a further demonstration that Australia can produce high quality and high value added elaborately transformed goods which will be worth many millions of dollars in export earnings over the next few years. I commend the Austjewel consortium and the work of the departments.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to the presentation of certificates to two Queensland firms in recognition of their outstanding quality management systems. The firms are the macadamia producer Suncoast Gold and Toowoomba's Pecan Shelling. I ask the minister to outline the criteria and objectives of the scheme under which these two firms gained the certificates and whether their achievements are indicative of government policies designed to encourage improved efficiency in our agricultural industries?

—Last week my colleague Senator Sherry presented certificates under the Australian horticultural quality certification scheme to the two Queensland companies mentioned—Suncoast Gold Macadamia and Toowoomba's Pecan Shelling. These awards are managed by the Australian Horticulture Corporation and the certification system rewards businesses which meet international best practice standards.

PARA.TAB: The certification—it is no mean feat to achieve it—provides an assurance to the customers of the firms that gain it that they will receive the same high standard of service or product every time they deal with that particular company. It is a scheme available to all Australian horticultural industries.

I remind the Senate that it was through the initiative of this government that the Australian Horticulture Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation were established in 1988 specifically to assist Australian horticultural industries to develop their export marketing drive and research efforts. In March 1991, the Horticulture Corporation established its internationally recognised quality certification scheme. The underlying purpose of the scheme is to develop and introduce cost effective management systems that will improve the ability of Australian horticultural industries to expand into quality conscious overseas markets.

The macadamia industry is an example of the potential that exists for horticultural industries if they are willing to accept the challenge of meeting the world's best standards, which is what is needed to succeed in the international marketplace. Of course, macadamias are one of Australia's truly unique contributions to international cuisine. In fact, in the 1992-93 financial year, we exported macadamias to the value of $25 million, and the Horticulture Corporation estimates that by next year we will be exporting about 80 per cent of a macadamia crop worth around $50 million.

I would like to add my congratulations to the recipients of the horticulture quality awards. I would encourage all our export producers to strive for quality because it is the key to our future export success.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I refer the minister to a 1993 budget decision which waived the assets test for Austudy applicants in receipt of health care cards. This commitment was especially welcomed by hard-pressed rural families with farm assets on paper but little or no actual income. My question is: why are primary producers and holders of health care cards being told by Austudy officials that they must now satisfy an assets test before being deemed eligible for assistance?

—I am advised by Minister Free, and acknowledge, that this matter arose out of the 1993 budget decision to allow persons whose parent or spouse held a health care card to fast-track access to Austudy on the grounds that they had already met the appropriate means test administered by the Department of Social Security. This decision allowed speedier payment of Austudy for families suffering a sudden income drop. Unfortunately, the budget decision was misinterpreted in the material circulated to students, which stated that all holders of a health care card were exempt from the Austudy assets test. This was not the intention of the decision. The consequence of this misinterpretation was to allow individuals or their families with assets in excess of the Austudy assets ceiling to use the health care card, for which no assets test is necessary, as an alternative route to receiving student assistance.

PARA.TAB: Minister Free has advised me that he has ordered an urgent internal investigation into how the normal DEET quality control measures failed to pick up this diversion from the intent of government policy. When this loophole was detected, DEET moved to close it by applying the assets test to health care card holders. As a result of this action, I understand that approximately 20 Austudy applicants have been adversely affected. No change will be made for those who were assessed and notified before this action was taken.

Whilst interest groups have argued that the public statements made last year should be confirmed, the financial implications of such a decision make it a matter for consultation with central agencies. This is taking place as a matter of urgency. Nevertheless, the government will not be changing the intent of its original policy decision.

The case made on behalf of asset rich but low income families, especially those in the bush, is well understood by the government. It was this understanding which led to the extension of benefits under the assistance for isolated children scheme in the last budget. It is worth remembering that last year Austudy assisted half a million students at a cost of $1.56 billion. It is hardly surprising, therefore, that while the opposition has sought to score some easy points on this issue, it ignores the government's unquestionably good record on student assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the minister to the statement from Minister Free's office that the government intends to honour its policy, but at this stage it is not clear whether it can; this will take a few days to sort out. —The advice I have just given to the Senate makes it very clear that in the future, if they hold a health care card, they will receive assistance so long as they meet the assets test. That is the government's policy. In view of Senator Boswell's interest in this matter, I will refer his supplementary question to the minister, because he has asked about the minister's statement as to discussions and negotiations going on. In my initial answer, the minister's response provided to me did say there were matters for consultation with central agencies. I will get an answer for Senator Boswell on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a question asked by Senator Herron on 10 February, I gave an undertaking to provide further information in relation to skin cancer and Medicare benefits. There is no fee differential between general practitioners and specialists for the two items in the Medicare benefits schedule covering the treatment of skin cancer by serial curettage. Medicare schedule fees of $89.95 and $313.40 for serial curettage apply equally to general practitioners and specialists.

PARA.TAB: A key element of the changes to these items which came into effect on 1 November 1993 is the requirement for histopathological proof or specialist confirmation of skin cancer before Medicare rebates are payable for treatment by serial curettage. TALK.START.PARA: —During question time I was asked a question by Senator West about the results of an examination by the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation. Can I say in my defence that one of the side products of the change of question time in the House of Representatives is that we can no longer rely on listening to question time there to stay awake during question time in the Senate. I have obtained information for Senator West in response to her question. I seek the leave of the Senate to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
There are a number of government inquiries currently under way into research and development.
The most significant is the Industry Commission inquiry which is expected to issue its draft report in August this year.
However, the government has just received a major report commissioned by the Rural Industries Research and Development Corportion from AGRANS consultants.
The report has found agricultural research has been the most important factor in the development of new industries with new crops in Australia in the past 40 years.
Thirty five industries were studied.
Thirty one of these identified Australian-based research and development as being of high importance to their productivity.
Twenty five identified this research as a key factor.
These new crops have contributed significantly to the overall growth of agriculture production in Australia.
New crops were defined in the study as those which had become commercial since 1950 or were only small at that time—they include such crops as avocadoes, macadamias, mangoes and soy beans.
These crops had a gross value, in current dollar terms, of $20 million in 1950.
By 1991/92 the gross value of these crops had increased to $1.5 billion.
The report found that other factors of importance to the growth of new industries were marketing, government assistance in developing quality standards and the introduction of new technology.
It was also found new industries did not have to be geographically concentrated or supported by large companies to be successful.
The report clearly demonstrates the integral role which tightly focused research can and does play in developing new opportunities for the rural sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 10 February I made a statement during question time concerning resolution No. 9 of the Senate Privilege Resolutions. I had intended to participate in the debate which followed to respond to some of the comments made. In the interests of allowing interested honourable senators to express their views, there was not enough time for me to respond before the debate ran out of time. I now tender a considered response which, with the concurrence of honourable senators, I will incorporate in Hansard.
—Mr President, I would like to hear what your decision is rather than have you incorporate it in Hansard because there is still considerable concern about your determination.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —You can hear it if you want to; I was trying to save the Senate time. If it is the wish of the Senate, I will read the statement. I wish to make a statement concerning the debate which took place following my statement during question time on 10 February 1994 concerning resolution No. 9 of the Senate Privilege Resolutions and senators' exercise of their right of freedom of speech in the Senate. I wish to refer to some questions asked of me and points raised during that debate.

PARA.TAB: I had prepared the substance of the statement in advance, entirely on my own initiative, so that I could make it at a suitable opportunity. It was a general statement not applicable to any particular incident or circumstance in the Senate, and it resulted from long-standing concerns about such allegations made both in the chamber and before estimates committees.

I considered that the time at which I made the statement was an appropriate time to make it because, in the course of the asking and answering of a question, there was a dispute, the basis of which was a suggestion that allegations were being made of improper conduct against other persons. I made no judgment about whether allegations were being made or whether those allegations were unsubstantiated or had some foundation. The fact that it was suggested that allegations were being made and that this was leading to dispute during question time indicated to me that it was an appropriate time for me to make the statement. It was also appropriate because at question time most senators are present and that is the time when disputes of this sort are likely to arise.

In retrospect, I accept that it might have been more appropriate to make the statement at the end of question time. In making the statement, I was acting in accordance with resolution No. 9 of the Privilege Resolutions, paragraph (2) of which provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: the President, whenever the President considers that it is desirable to do so, may draw the attention of the Senate to the spirit and the letter of this resolution.

The substantive part of the resolution, which the President is empowered to draw to the attention of the Senate whenever the President considers it desirable, sets out matters which senators should take into account in speaking in the Senate. The resolution does not permit or require the President to draw any conclusions about anything which has been said in the Senate, nor does it permit or require the President to link a statement with any particular remarks in the Senate, and I did not do either of those things. I therefore believe that I acted in accordance with resolution No. 9.

PARA.TAB: The terms of resolution No. 9 and its authorisation of the President to draw attention to its terms involve no inhibition on senators' right of freedom of speech; on the contrary, the resolution is a recognition of that right. My statement drawing the attention of the Senate to the resolution similarly did not involve any inhibition on senators' right of freedom of speech but a recognition of that right which is upheld by the resolution. I made this clear in the preamble to the statement.

During the debate it was suggested that the intention of resolution No. 9 was that senators should take into account the matters set out in the resolution when speaking about persons other than members of the Senate or the House of Representatives. I do not believe that this is a correct interpretation of the resolution. Subparagraph (1)(c) enjoins senators to take into account, as one of the list of matters which they should take into account, the limited opportunities for persons other than members of parliament to respond to allegations made in parliament, but that does not mean that senators are enjoined by the resolution to take into account the listed matters only when speaking of persons outside parliament. The resolution is in general terms. The explanatory note tabled with the resolution when it was moved confirms that the intention was that senators should take those matters into account when speaking about any person.

It was suggested in the debate that my action was unprecedented. On the contrary, the chair on at least two occasions in the past has been moved to draw attention to resolution No. 9 by matters arising in debate.

To conclude, I believe that I have acted entirely in accordance with resolution No. 9 of the Privilege Resolutions of the Senate. If the juxtaposition of my statement with a particular question has given rise to offence, I apologise for such offence. I nevertheless stand by the substance of my statement, which, I repeat, was a general statement, and ask that all honourable senators pay close attention to resolution No. 9 when framing questions, whether at committee hearings or in the Senate chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, we on this side of the chamber note your statement and thank you for it. We particularly thank you for your statement that if your earlier intervention had caused offence then you apologise for that, because it did cause offence to some on this side of the chamber. That is not the basis upon which we want to start the relationship between honourable senators on this side of the chamber, and you in your high office sitting in that chair. I particularly note, and am pleased to see, that you assure us that you have no intention, and had no intention, of inhibiting us in our right to and responsibility for freedom of speech in this place. We will continue to exercise that right, as we must.

PARA.TAB: There is only one aspect of the matter that still puzzles me. I do not want to dwell upon it and I do not want another long debate on the whole matter as we would like to bring it to an end and start afresh. But I am puzzled by your statement today, `I made no judgment about whether allegations were being made, or whether those allegations were unsubstantiated or had some foundation'. Mr President, I remind you of the context of your intervention on the previous occasion which followed statements by the minister in which he accused us of making unsubstantiated allegations. In response to that, you said:

SPEECH.PARA: The increasing practice of senators making a series of unsubstantiated allegations and throwing mud in the hope that some will stick is, I believe, frequently an abuse of parliamentary privilege.

In those circumstances, it is very hard for us to understand how you would then come into the chamber today and say you were not making any judgment on whether there were unsubstantiated allegations. It seemed very much from the statement that you made and the giving of a literal interpretation to your words that you had made such a judgment. But if we were confused by that, and you have clarified it today by saying that we misconstrued your language, then I accept what you say and I hope that we can start off on a fresh basis.

PARA.TAB: You understand, from what you said today, that we have a responsibility to pursue matters that we think are in the national interest. We do not make statements or accusations in this place without having substantial reason to do so. We check our facts. Sometimes they are found wanting, but more often they are not. We do not make allegations without evidence to support those allegations. That is the way in which we have operated and the way that we will continue to operate. But we will not allow resolution No. 9 to inhibit us in our responsibility of pursuing ministers and trying to bring them to account and, in particular, the issues that are causing us major concern about the potential conflict of interest that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has got himself into between the responsibilities of his office and his very large personal business interests. We will continue to pursue those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank you for your remarks, particularly when you said, `If the juxtaposition of my statement with the particular question has given rise to offence, I apologise for such offence'. I thank you for that apology because I certainly was offended by the remarks, particularly in that context. Nonetheless, I am concerned about some implications of the statement. It seems to me that you are saying that the question of possible abuse of parliamentary privilege clearly does not now apply to the question I asked, and your apology seems to suggest that.

PARA.TAB: Obviously it has been established that my statement did not involve any such abuse of parliamentary privilege. I take it, Mr President, that your clarifying statement today, where you said that you were going to intervene at this point because you had been concerned over some time at what appeared to be the possible abuse of parliamentary privilege, clearly now does not relate to my question.

That raises the following matter. In your explanatory statement today, you said that you would make a statement at a suitable opportunity and later said that you were empowered to draw it to the attention of the Senate wherever the President considers it desirable. Clearly, of course, it has been established, I think, by your own statement that it was not desirable by any test to do so immediately after I asked the factual and proper question. Nor was it a suitable opportunity directly after I asked a proper and direct substantiated question. As you know, Mr President, I substantiated the facts of that question by tabling the documents that I had searched from the Australian Securities Commission which had been available to Senator Gareth Evans for more than a year had he wished to look at them, when he described the question as containing `unsubstantiated allegations'.

Also, it is worth noting that your statement was not applicable to any particular incident or circumstance in the Senate, that it might have been more appropriate to make the statement at the end of question time, and that if the juxtaposition caused offence you were sorry for it. In that context, unfortunately the media clearly took it to be a matter directly related to my question. Continually, the media have remarked on it not only in the news items of the day but also in follow-up stories such as on Order in the House. The clear inference has been made by the media that you, Mr President, were indicating that my question was a possible abuse of parliamentary privilege. The matter even went to the extent of Order in the House running an item about my question by substituting a totally different question from the one I asked.

I find it quite extraordinary the way in which this matter has been handled by the media without mentioning the specific detailed substantiated question I had asked, which related to which version of the debt owing to Mr John Brown by Mr Keating's companies should be believed. I said there were four different versions. I apologise for that, as there were five. One return did not mention the debt at all. I suppose failure to mention by omission is another version of the debt. But it ranges from nil to $4.5 million, the debt owed by the Prime Minister's companies to Mr John Brown, a former minister, a former ministerial colleague, a man who lobbies very effectively on behalf of various interest groups in this parliament and who is on some governmental bodies.

It was a totally proper question. Yet as a result of the unfortunate juxtaposition of your statement, Mr President, in relation to which, as I say, I am grateful for your apology, the media universally took the line that it was directed at my piggery questions rather than at that particular piggery question. I want to stress that this reinforced a false impression being created by the government, and by Senator Gareth Evans in particular, that every question I have asked is somehow unsubstantiated when Senator Evans knows that the details behind all of those questions are clear, are available to him to establish—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President. Is it in order for Senator Baume to address the substance of his question which preceded your particular direction in circumstances where you yourself have said quite explicitly, in what you have just said to this place, that your statement was not actually based upon or specifically to be regarded as being in response to that? It seems that whatever other merit—and it is not much—that Senator Baume's current contribution may have, it is not one that goes to the substance of your statement.
—Senator Baume, are you moving to the substance of the general debate? You should direct your comments to the statement I have just made.

—Thank you, Mr President, but the point is that your original statement, for which you are now making an apology in so far as the relevant part affects me, said specifically that you were concerned about what appears to be the possible abuse of parliamentary privilege by people making unsubstantiated allegations. I am demonstrating that while I am grateful for your apology, I am still concerned about the suggestion that there were unsubstantiated allegations; and the very phrase you used was the phrase used improperly and disgracefully by Senator Evans who knew that what he was saying was wrong. If he did not know that what he was saying was wrong, it means his indolence and incompetence are overwhelming.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that details of all these matters have been presented to this chamber over the past 18 months, and the factual material is available. Senator Evans continues to characterise this as unsubstantiated allegations. The problem is, Mr President, that you accepted that and because there was a disagreement in this chamber, you took it to be a suitable opportunity to say that unsubstantiated allegations should not be made.

Mr President, I draw to your attention that fact. Just because Senator Evans falsely, wrongly and improperly suggests to this chamber that something is an unsubstantiated allegation, that is not an appropriate time or a suitable opportunity for you then to intervene. In other words, I am suggesting that Senator Evans has a record of being totally, completely and utterly wrong in these false accusations. I suggest to you that you should be aware of Senator Evans's appalling record in seeking to denigrate what I am saying. He knows the facts; I have them available and they are documented.

The reason what I am saying is germane to this matter is that you said you regarded it as an appropriate time, and that it was considered desirable to raise this matter because there was a disagreement, an argument. It was suggested that allegations were being made in this chamber, but they were being made by a man with no status, standing or reputation in this area; a man who has consistently sought to denigrate facts provided by the Australian Securities Commission. He kept saying it was unsubstantiated muckraking when I said the Prime Minister's company's accounts were false, that they had not been delivered in appropriate time to the Securities Commission, and that they had to be amended by something like an aggregate of $5 million for understating losses and overstating assets.

All this material is on the record, Mr President. Yet when a member of this chamber, who happens to be the senator representing the Prime Minister in this chamber, accuses me, without one shred of evidence being presented, of making a set of unsubstantiated allegations in a statement, you, Mr President, were prepared to accept that as a suitable opportunity to make a statement of this nature. All I am saying is that this clearly was not a suitable opportunity. Your apology to an extent acknowledges the fact that it could have been better timed.

I would suggest that even if you had made that statement at the end of question time it would still have involved your accepting the word of a man whose word in this matter should not be taken seriously. I entreat you, Mr President, that if you consider such interventions in future you have a much greater degree of recognition of Senator Evans's track record of setting out on a deliberate and political campaign of denigration. He has never answered the substance of any one of these well-documented, factual questions relating to the Prime Minister's involvement in an $80 million multinational joint piggery venture, which has a whole series of question marks hanging over it, none of which have been adequately responded to by this government and on which he has not given one iota of hard evidence. I would suggest that if you are to take any notice of this man's nonsense in the future it may be a good idea if you asked him to substantiate whatever nonsensical point he was trying to make.

I do not think any senator other than in that particular corner of the chamber believes that you were wrong to act as you did.
