PARA.TAB: It is a great pity that your grace in the way in which you expressed yourself today was not matched by the opposition and, in particular, by Senator Baume. Senator Baume is one of those people who just cannot take yes for an answer. He cannot accept language of the kind that you offered today without seeking, in turn, to make something of it for squalid, partisan reasons of the kind we have come utterly to expect from him. Whether the juxtaposition of your statement from the chair with Senator Baume's prior question was appropriate or not depends, I suppose, on whether one chooses to describe Senator Baume's question as amounting to an allegation—whether substantiated or not—as distinct from an inference, implication, innuendo or some other form of imputation.

Let me say in that respect that although you, Mr President, have made it clear that you do not want to be taken as having made that juxtaposition, there were certainly plenty of grounds for you to do so had you chosen to take that particular course, because there was plenty of imputation in Senator Baume's question and plenty of imputation about exposure of the Prime Minister to improper influence. That was the content that was the subject matter of the question. Senator Baume knew that perfectly well, and his tears today are utterly of the crocodile variety.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise the same point of order raised by Senator Evans in relation to Senator Baume. Senator Evans invited you to direct Senator Baume to restrict his comments to comments on your statement. That may have been fair. You upheld that and Senator Baume took notice of what you said. As an example, the man who says he wants the standards in this place to improve, then proceeds to commit exactly the offence that you have criticised Senator Baume for.
—You have made your point of order. I allowed a fair amount of latitude before and I do not think Senator Evans has gone as far as Senator Baume did.

—Mr President, I sought to confine the debate since you, in a spirit of free speech, allowed it to proceed thereafter in a fairly untrammelled fashion. Since I, in the course of that untrammelled contribution by Senator Baume, was referred to in turn as acting improperly, disgracefully and in an indolent and incompetent way, and matching by my contributions my appalling record of denigration, I think in all the circumstances even Senator Vanstone would acknowledge that it is appropriate for me to say a word or two on the substantive issue, which I had genuinely not the slightest intention of dealing with in this place had not Senator Baume acted as he did.

PARA.TAB: Let me just say quickly for the record in response to Senator Baume, since he has put it on the record yet again, how appalled I continue to be by his question and the reason I continue to be appalled by it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Substantively!

—Let me respond substantively then. I do not think Senator Baume ought to be spending too much time on this; he would be much better occupied in working up his defence to the defamation action to which he is presently subject in the New South Wales Supreme Court as a result of his previous excursions on this subject. I do not resile in any way from what I have said.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is highly improper for Senator Evans to refer to any matter which is before the courts, and he knows it is highly improper. It only gives further substance to the sorts of adjectives that have been used to define him today. He is further debating it and using—as I said, highly improperly—reference to that court action, and I ask him to withdraw that reference.
—I do not think there is any reason to withdraw a reference to a court action unless it is sub judice. I do not think that the sub judice rule—

—Mr President, on the point of order, all I said was that Senator Baume would be better occupied in devoting himself to the defence of his defamation action rather than coming in and raising other issues. I am not suggesting for a moment that this issue is immediately involved. It is a separate issue which is involved in the court case, and I do not propose to canvass the substance of that issue. On that basis, Mr President, I would seek to proceed.

—Mr President, on the same point of order, I would argue that it is a reflection on Senator Baume, because the purpose it was raised by Senator Evans was to imply that, because of the issuing of a writ, in some way Senator Baume was guilty of the allegation that has been made by the Prime Minister. It is the only reason the minister raised it. He did not raise it to add some intellectual input to the debate; he raised it because he wanted to reflect adversely upon Senator Baume. In those circumstances he should be told that that is not in accordance with the standing order and he should desist.

—In the interests of harmony I ask Senator Evans to withdraw, but I must say that it makes it very difficult when provocative statements on the one side beget provocative statements from the other. What else can you expect?

—Statesmanlike intervention, Mr President, with which I agree entirely. Apart from saying that Senator Baume might be better occupied elsewhere, and apart from saying that this is none of Senator Baume's business, I now proceed to respond to the substantive issue.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I heard you ask Senator Evans to withdraw and I do not think he has. I think he has ignored your direction.
—I ask you, Senator Evans, in the spirit of harmony in the Senate to withdraw.
—I withdraw whatever it is you want me to withdraw, Mr President. It is a bit difficult to understand what, precisely, but I will if that helps to proceed in a spirit of harmony.

PARA.TAB: I will respond briefly to why it is that I responded as I did the other day to Senator Baume's particular question. Let me say quickly and succinctly for the record that the nub of Senator Baume's question was that there was something in the nature of a loan outstanding from Brown and Hatton, and John Brown in particular, to the Prime Minister which exposed the Prime Minister to some sort of obligation or potential improper influence should Mr Brown choose to exercise it. The subtext of the question was that there was some mystery about the amount of that particular loan, and it was repeated again today because there have been multiple versions of it according to the various documents that have been in one way or another on the public record.

I repeat, Mr President, that I fully accept that this is of marginal relevance to the point of your particular statement, but it is of complete relevance to the allegations that were made against me by Senator Baume today, and it is probably important that this be on the record.

Let me state quickly for the record that the first point is that the relevant figure as to the outstanding loan is that which appeared in the accounts audited by KPMG Peat Marwick for the year ended 30 June 1991. The amount in question there appearing in those audited accounts is $2.76 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —So it is substantiated, is it?
—There is no issue that the—
—You called it unsubstantiated muck before.

—I did not. I do not recall ever using the expression in that particular context—there were plenty of others—of unsubstantiated allegations. I said that this appears to have no more substance than any previous allegation he has made. I now make that point very clear. There is a figure identified in this way as a potential loan in the way that I have indicated.

PARA.TAB: The second point to make absolutely clear is that the so-called `loan'—and I use the expression in inverted commas—is payable only at the discretion of the directors themselves. It is payable only at the discretion of the directors who notionally have the obligation to pay it or who would have the clear cut obligation if it were a formal legal loan. That is made perfectly clear, as Senator Baume himself acknowledges in his own statement somewhere on 10 February. He quoted from a document that stated that the $4 million—he refers to $4 million but the figure, as I said, is $2.76 million—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to that in a moment. He quoted from the document that stated that the $4 million will be paid only if the company's directors so determine and if the company makes sufficient profits and has sufficient funds available to pay the additional price in question. I repeat, the accounts made clear that any amount payable to Mr Brown is payable only at the director's discretion. Senator Baume knew that. The payment of any funds to Mr Brown from this provision is payable on the determination of the managers and directors of the company. The point to be made here, of course, is that Mr Keating is not now, and never has been, such a manager or a director. Moreover, the matter was determined by the former directors. This whole question was determined by the former directors before the Prime Minister even became a shareholder in Brown and Hatton—that is, before the Prime Minister was involved in this at all.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. As we are debating your statement, which is concerned with substantiation of assertions and allegations, I wonder whether you would ask Senator Evans to tell us if the statements he is now making are authorised by the Prime Minister?
—It is up to Senator Evans how he answers. Allegations were introduced by Senator Baume which Senator Evans is responding to. It is up to Senator Evans to answer the question in the way he sees fit.

—My information—and it seems to be clearly Senator Baume's advice and information—is as I have described it. The amount in question is payable only if the company directors so determine that the company makes sufficient profits and has sufficient funds available to pay it. That is the basis of it.
—It is a curious little arrangement.

—But it is one that completely predated Mr Keating's involvement in the company. That is completely the basic point in issue. The basic point which emerges from all that—and even the bears of very small brains opposite ought to be able to appreciate it—is that even if we adopt the kind of jaundiced view of human nature that runs through every contribution that Senator Baume has made on this subject and which led him to perverse and wrongful accusations in the contributions he previously made about AQIS conflicts of interest, FIRB conflicts of interest and taxation conflicts of interest, we have to conclude that the nature of this arrangement is such that Mr Brown has no leverage over the company or its shareholders. Any funds dispensed to him from this particular provision would be entirely at the company's discretion. Game, set and match. Once again those opposite are left absolutely without any shred of justification for what they are saying.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I conclude by saying this: I fully acknowledge, as I said a moment ago, that, in a sense, all of that was totally irrelevant to the point of your statement today. You said, and you made it clear—I think we all accept what you said at face value—that your statement was not to be taken as directly linked to that question, as extraordinary and as unattractive as it was, from Senator Baume. I simply hope that under those circumstances—and your having described the context of your statement in the way that you have—nobody derives any encouragement from that statement today to misuse this particular area of parliamentary privilege in future.

I think it is important that you be gracious in the chair, Mr President. But, as I said at the outset, I think it is also important that you be very firm. Resolution No. 9 of the 1988 privilege principles is very firm in the nature of the direction, the nature it gives to senators and the nature of the obligation in honour and decency it imposes upon us. I think it is very important, indeed, for all of us and for the benefit, the credibility and the reputation of this place that we do not sully it with innuendos, implications, inferences, or more direct forms of allegations about people that cannot, in fact, be sustained and are simply designed to make a political point of one kind or another.Mr President, whatever the immediate context of your ruling might have been on this occasion and whether that context was such as to justify it or not—we could argue about that for time immemorial—I hope that the substance of what you are saying will be fully appreciated and taken into account by all honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do not want to comment at length on your statement, as Senator Evans did, but there are a few matters arising from it that I would like to raise. Firstly, I thank you for your statement and I endorse everything that Senator Hill has said with respect to it.

PARA.TAB: A Speaker from the British parliament once made the point that he had neither the eyes to see, the ears to hear nor the mouth to speak save as directed by his chamber. That was his way of indicating that the role of Presidents and Speakers is not to follow their personal interest but to apply the standing orders as set by their chambers. I am therefore somewhat perplexed by your frequent reference to your longstanding concern over this matter of privilege. Whether or not you are concerned is not the issue; you have your job to do and you are required to do it.

I wonder whether you can assist those of us who have not seen that concern evidenced. I have been here only nine years. Since you have been here longer, perhaps you could cite from Hansard the occasions when you have raised this matter or produce the letters that you have sent to the President of the Senate because this matter has been so troubling you over such a long period. I make that request not so much for you to verify the fact that you have this longstanding interest but to acquaint us with the depth of that interest.

With respect to your statement, you say—and, as Senator Hill said, we accept—that it was not made on anyone's instructions. I remind you of what I have said earlier: it is very unfortunate that you chose to make that statement in question time, following, as it did, Senator Baume's allegations about Mr Keating and the response from Senator Gareth Evans to the effect that they were unsubstantiated allegations. That was another example of Senator Evans's belief that it is improper for us to raise a question in here because it necessarily becomes an allegation unless it can be substantiated—in other words, unless we already know the answer. That is a non sequitur. It should be obvious to anyone that that is a ludicrous proposition for Senator Evans to make and I suggest it would be a ludicrous one for you to endorse, Mr President. Why would anyone bother asking a question if one already knew the answer? If one knew the answers with respect to these matters, people would be reading about it in the papers.

Times will change and the tide will turn, and one day those opposite will be sitting on this side of the chamber. They might believe that the time is further away than we think it is but that is a matter for debate. One day they will be sitting on this side and they should be aware that this is a matter of parliamentary interest and not just a political dispute. We could raise a number of examples where allegations have been hotly denied by those on the other side and have then turned out to have some substance to them. One was the entire Burke affair. Senator Gareth Evans's first response to that matter was that there was nothing to it at all.

Then there was the Marshall Islands affair, which was similarly responded to in the first instance. The accusation was that the allegations were false. That will always be the response from those on the other side. Perhaps they believe at the time that the allegations are false and that there is no substance to them. But if some of those on the other side had done something wrong—be it a case of maladministration or criminal activity, such as keeping stamps that they should not have kept—they would hardly put an ad in the paper, telling everyone about it. So in good faith, their colleagues come to their defence and say that the allegations are unsubstantiated. That is the foam over the substance of the matter—the froth and bubble in this chamber—but the bottom line is that the question is entitled to be asked and we can only hope that the answers will be given eventually.

Mr President, I am pleased that you have said that your statement was not delivered on anyone's instructions. As I said earlier, it is a very sad thing for you that, because of its placement, it very much looked that way at the time. I accept that you feel entitled to have done so at question time but perhaps it would have been better if it had been done after question time. I think everyone would agree with that. I make the point that it might have been better to do as a number of previous Presidents have done when they have been concerned about matters, and that is to distribute a letter to all senators, raising the specific point and indicating that if a particular standing order is stretched any further in the chamber, action will be taken in the chamber. At least that puts everyone on notice as to your views in that respect.

Mr President, you also indicated that there were two other occasions where the Chair—I think you used that term—had chosen to make such an intervention. I am wondering whether, when you have a moment to draw our attention to your longstanding interest in this matter—that is, the occasions on which you have raised it in the Senate and have written to any previous President about it—you will also give us an indication of when these two previous occasions occurred. Did they occur in question time? If so, was that when question time was being televised? Was the action taken by the President or someone acting as chairman of a committee? Did it follow a statement in the Senate that could possibly be taken to be a statement to which the President was responding, as happened in your case? I think it is important to clarify that because, as you said, yours was a prepared intervention and that is what worries me because it indicates you had given consideration to making it at an appropriate time. That is another matter. You have indicated that it may have been better to make it at a later time and I agree with that.

Last but not least, I turn to the matter of the contribution made by Senator Gareth Evans. I have already made my point about the stupid business he goes on with: people not asking questions until they know the answer, and not making allegations until they can substantiate them. It seems we have to know all the facts before we can ask anything about the facts. That is completely ludicrous.

As for standards in this place, I welcome the honourable senator's indication that we all have some responsibility towards maintaining the highest standards of integrity possible in this place. His remarks, however, seemed a little hollow when, time after time, we see our policies misrepresented, especially on broadcast days, and when any complaint is made about it the throwaway line from those on the other side is, `That is a debating point'. Somehow, when the misrepresentation is made by the other side it is called a debating point but when a genuine question is asked on this side it is described as a false allegation designed to denigrate the Senate. It seems somewhat inappropriate that those opposite should take that attitude.

I would only hope that Senator Evans would express the same desire for standards in electoral campaigns because the lies and deceits perpetrated by those on the other side—or, rather, by the people in charge of their campaigns, with whom they simply go along—do nothing to alter perceptions in the community.

I notice Senator Ray laughingly offering his handkerchief. As he said before, `Here they are again, the tears, because you lot lost'. It was sad that we lost, but one of the factors occasioning the loss was the gross misrepresentation of our policies by those on the other side. Mr President, you would well know that when the community is making its assessment of the standards of parliamentary behaviour it is not restricted to the behaviour it witnesses in this place. Very few people in the community see as much as they should see because we cannot maximise the television broadcast. With our present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the opportunity will probably be even further limited.

The standards by which the community judges us are not only those that apply to the behaviour they see and hear in this place but also those that apply to what they see and hear on the news services at night, during campaigns and out on the streets. Senator Evans says that he would like to see higher standards in this place but he does not seem to realise that members of the House of Representatives and senators should conduct themselves in a manner befitting the highest standards not only in this place but in the electorate as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there has been a useful discussion regarding a statement made by you. Having listened to Senator Vanstone, it would be fair to say she pointed out matters which needed to be pointed out. But it would seem to me unfortunate if, on broadcast day, the impression was given that somehow the fulsome and proper explanation you made in your statement previously was not accepted, and that what was happening was that the explanation you gave, together with an apology for any offence you might have given—
—Unknowingly.

—Unknowingly, should not be accepted on the basis on which you put it forward. It cannot be easy for a person holding the high office that you hold to come in and say that, on consideration, perhaps the statement should have been made on a different basis. It is proper at this stage to make it clear to those listening to this debate that you have done all that you could possibly do. On the last occasion the time allotted for the debate about your statement passed before you had an opportunity of explaining your situation. You have given an explanation subsequently on an occasion that is the most apposite.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to in any way curtail the debate, or cause any offence to the other side. At the same time, it is difficult to see what more you could do than you have already done. What concerns me is that if the debate runs on more than it has, clearly, it might be interpreted by those listening that those on the other side have not accepted what you have said and want to, as it were, use this occasion to go on about matters which may or may not be to their political advantage. That would be an unfortunate situation, not only for the chamber but for their standing. On the other side there are people who have most generous hearts. It would be a great pity if the impression given was that their generous hearts were not quite as generous as might be the case.

There is a great quote that reads, `To err is human, to forgive divine'. I think it is time for a bit of divinity to come into the chamber. Perhaps humanity has had its day. I do not want to stop this debate, but I wonder where it is going.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contributions made by Senator Cooney, to my mind, for the most part always lift the standard of debate in this parliament. Some of the points made by him were most useful. I would like to assure him that I certainly accepted the comments by the President. Within the culture of this place the President recognised that he had taken an action which was perhaps liable to misinterpretation, or for there to be a particular spin put on what he did. The President stood up today and tried to clarify the matter. I certainly welcome that statement. As far as it goes, it helps lay to rest at least some of the concerns on this side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I say, `lays to rest some of the concerns'. You would understand that the reaction on this side of the chamber was generated because of awareness about the behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), his strong views about the Senate, and the attacks that he makes on it from time to time. Allied with it is the extreme sensitivity of the Prime Minister when issues relating to his piggery investments are raised.

It is well known that many journalists have received abusive phone calls from the Prime Minister when they have written stories regarding the piggery. On one notable occasion the editor of the Sunday Age, not being part of the culture here in Parliament House, decided to give a full transcript of the nature of the conversation he had with Mr Keating regarding the piggery. That was a front-page story. It revealed to people the sort of bullying which the Prime Minister resorts to when he feels people are questioning possible conflicts of interest regarding his very substantial interests in this piggery.

There are those two reasons, Mr President. The attitude of the Prime Minister to the Senate is appalling. I hope, as you have now assumed this high office, you will see it as your role to defend this chamber. We are going to have a very difficult year. Statements made by the Prime Minister about the Senate in recent days show that the tensions which have existed between the Prime Minister and this chamber will continue.
Mr President, we look to you, as the Presiding Officer, when the Prime Minister steps overboard, to help defend this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pious humbug!
—It is not pious humbug at all.
—It is.

—That is part of the Labor Party culture. We are trying to lift the standards of this parliament; therefore it is not unreasonable that the Presiding Officer, the most senior officer in this chamber, a man who is given very substantial rights and privileges because he occupies that chair, should, in return, see part of his role as defending the Senate. There is nothing that you have said, Mr President, that leads me to feel that you do not see your role in that light.

PARA.TAB: I was concerned a year or so ago when the Prime Minister referred to senators in very derogatory terms. The person who formerly occupied the chair found it difficult to respond. I hope that, if you are faced with that challenge, you will not find it difficult to respond. The public are looking to people like yourself, as the President, and the Speaker—the two most senior people in this parliament—to uphold the standards of this parliament and, if need be, to defend it. Equally, if you feel that behaviour is not appropriate, you should give us your views. That is why there is the sensitivity on this side of the chamber.

We know the Prime Minister has been very lax in his personal affairs previously. People will recall the problems with Mr Keating's tax returns and travel allowances. He has built up a record of laxity in relation to his personal affairs, particularly his financial affairs. Mr President, because you allowed the debate to travel far and wide, the comments made by Senator Evans were very interesting. He has very dramatically confirmed that the accounts show there is a very substantial debt from the companies in which Mr Keating has a 50 per cent interest, to Mr Brown, which apparently only has to be repaid at the discretion of the directors. I had not heard it put as clearly before, certainly by someone on the government side. The question is: what is the nature of the agreement that has been made? We would like to see the documents. I think Senator Evans made a further concession in the debate today—and Senator Baume has pursued this matter, quite rightly, in my view—which confirms the sort of problem that Senator Baume is raising.

Mr President, as I said, I accept your statement in the spirit in which it was offered. But I ask you to indicate to the chamber whether Mr Keating at any time has spoken to you about the sort of action he feels should be taken in relation to questions in the Senate regarding his piggery. We know the way Mr Keating behaves. It is well known that Mr Keating does not like this Senate. He does not like people questioning him about his piggery.

I know, Mr President, you said you made that statement on your own initiative. I accept that. On the other hand, I believe it would be quite improper for Mr Keating to speak to you about any matter regarding rulings in the Senate in relation to his piggery. I would regard that as a highly improper action by Mr Keating. I would certainly like you, Mr President, to effectively address that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you just said you accepted the statement he had made.

—No; I accepted that the statement the President made was on his own initiative. The President said that, I understand. But another question which is equally important is whether at any time Mr Keating has sought to speak to you, Mr President, about the way piggery matters are being raised in the Senate and whether he has attempted in some way to try to put pressure on you. I think it is important for you perhaps to speak to the Senate about that and to tell us whether that has occurred at any time.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I think the next 12 months will be very difficult and very challenging and that you will have a very difficult role. I welcome the action that I understand you have already taken to step down from your position as one of the faction heads in the Labor Party. I do not know whether you have made a public statement on that matter; if you have, I must have missed it.

That sort of gesture is terribly important. It shows the importance you place on the office that you have assumed. It also shows your determination to buttress the independence of this office. If in fact you have resigned as a faction head, I would regard that as certainly an important step in the direction of trying to remove yourself to the extent you can. It is not completely possible in the structure of the Senate as we now have it to distance yourself in the way our great Speaker Sir Billy Snedden did—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you distanced him.

—No. Sir Billy Snedden made it very clear that he saw it as important to distance his office from day-to-day party political activities. I think that was a very important gesture by the Speaker and should be praised rather than sneered at by Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, with those few brief remarks, I welcome your statement as far as it goes. I am concerned about the behaviour of the Prime Minister in relation to the Senate and the piggery. I am also concerned about his attempts to bring pressure to bear on people who he feels are not sufficiently aware of or concerned about protecting his own particular interest. Any assurances you are able to give on that matter would be particularly welcomed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also welcome the statement that you made, Mr President. As Senator Evans very rightly pointed out, it was firm, fair and very deliberate. The issue I want to raise with you today is one I could not raise when you were delivering your address to us today and standing in the very important position that you occupy. It is a matter of protocol.

PARA.TAB: During your delivery the ministers of the crown in this place and two-thirds of the Australian Labor Party walked in and out of this chamber like Brown's cows. I take that to be an absolute mark of disrespect towards you. You were standing and making an important statement. It was very obviously a statement that was controversial in the sense that when it arose Senator Baume and Senator Evans were engaged in a very controversial debate.

As you were standing there making that statement today I would assume you must have been feeling quite ill because of the lack of respect and courtesy that was afforded you. On one occasion I noted that Senator Evans was the only minister remaining in the chamber whilst you were speaking. Others walked in and out whilst you were on your feet.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!
—I was sitting here.
—I was in here for the entire time sitting next to Senator Schacht.
—Walking all around the place, talking to Senator Schacht while the President was on his feet.
—Don't say I left the chamber when I didn't.
—This is an important issue that I would ask you, Mr President, to address so as to maintain the decorum that is so rightly and correctly expected of senators in this chamber.

—I shall be brief. I thank you most sincerely, Mr President, for making your statement and for not incorporating it. You will appreciate that at the time you made that statement there was considerable concern on this side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney used the word `juxtaposition' in relation to your intervention after Senator Baume had spoken. The clear implication on this side was that you were trying to intimidate him; there was no other interpretation. That was the interpretation taken by us and by the media at the time. This had never been done before. It was the first time this had occurred in this chamber, certainly in the time I have been here. I subsequently discovered that never had a President intervened during question time to make a statement. There was no other interpretation than that this was intimidation on your part on behalf of the Prime Minister. One of the media reports went so far as to say that it was carried out under instruction. I do not think that would have been so, but some of my colleagues may have thought so. Today Senator Evans alleged that Senator Baume had a jaundiced view of things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell me how you succeed in intimidating Senator Baume?

—Nobody could intimidate Senator Baume; he is impervious to intimidation, I am proud to say as one of his colleagues. Mr President, I think it is important for the Senate itself that you will be judged on the manner in which you chair the chamber and on whether you show impartiality.

PARA.TAB: Your appointment to the position of President was unopposed because of the actions of your predecessor who was held in high regard. It seemed to us that Senator Sibraa chaired the Senate as impartially as was possible, given the constraints that he was a member of the government party.

The future is in your hands, Mr President. I welcome your statement today, and I accept it completely at face value. It does clear the air. You have apologised regarding the feeling of intimidation, but I want to reinforce the statement that there was a juxtaposition that was unfortunate, and I accept your apology in that regard. I trust that you will continue in such a way in future because your record will be determined by the impartiality of the position that you adopt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill and other colleagues have already appropriately responded to your welcome statement in the Senate today. I rise in light of my speech on the last day of sitting simply to say that I accept your apology. I accept it in the terms that you have expressed, on the basis of the assurances that you have given. I note that the question I raised in my previous speech and the other suggestions that I made have all been addressed by your statement today. I thank you for that.

PARA.TAB: In this brief contribution let me refer to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). As I indicated on the last sitting day, I have never made any implication as to your conversation with the Prime Minister on this matter. The fact that this matter has arisen makes it entirely clear that your position is strengthened should an occasion arise in future where a Prime Minister, or any other person in some position of power in either house, might put suggestions to you. You can respond to any individual, including the Prime Minister, with the integrity of your own position as President of the Senate. If ever there was any feeling of pressure being applied to you by any group of senators or any powerful member of the House of Representatives or the Senate, you would be in a position, according to your duty as President of the Senate, to report that pressure to this chamber.

I conclude by saying that your statement has cleared the air. You have made a strong statement in which you have expressed your responses to the matters which were of very grave concern to us. I make the final comment that nothing that has transpired has in any way led to a criticism of Senator Baume in respect of the question he asked in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to extend this debate any further than it needs to be, but I would simply like to wind up the debate by making two or three points. Firstly, I would like to reiterate that I did this on my own initiative and I did it on the basis of long experience, particularly as a chairman of estimates committees over the years. I find the allegation that I might have done it somehow under instructions from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or that I had addressed the Prime Minister offensive in the extreme. I assert quite clearly here and now that I did not at any stage talk to the Prime Minister, nor have I at any stage talked to the Prime Minister, about this issue.

PARA.TAB: On the question of defending the Senate, of course I will defend the Senate when it needs to be defended and when it deserves to be defended because sometimes accusations that are made about the Senate have some foundation. But I do remind honourable senators that most of you have fairly broad shoulders and, in some cases, fairly thick skins. I do not imagine that some of the accusations really have hurt as much as the cries of anguish would indicate.

In relation to Senator Kemp's reference to Billy Snedden, I think Senator Kemp is simply wrong on what he says about him. Billy Snedden was trying to suggest changes to the Speaker's position in line with the British system. As a result of the changes that he tried and failed to get support for, he made the gesture of not going along to party meetings except when matters of principle were being discussed. So he still attended party meetings but not all of them. He was the only Speaker who did so. All other Speakers and Presidents have attended their party meetings in line with the tradition that has developed in this country. I will research the other matters that have been raised and take them up later.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation. The point I made about whether you had spoken to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about this matter was not intended to cause you offence.
—I was not in fact referring to you, Senator.

—My question was whether the Prime Minister had spoken to you; that was the point. Mr President, I take it from what you have said that he has not spoken to you about it, and I am pleased to hear that. But I would have to say that if that is the case, you must be one of the few senior people in the Labor Party to whom he has not spoken about this serious matter.
—I would ask you to withdraw that statement. That is an direct imputation on me after I have made an explanation. I ask you to withdraw.
—Mr President, I said to you that you—
—I ask you to withdraw that statement. It is a direct imputation on the President.
—Outrageous.
—It is not an outrageous statement at all.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. With respect, Mr President, you did not make it clear. You made it perfectly clear that you had not spoken to the Prime Minister. The issue that my colleague, Senator Kemp, is seeking clarification on is whether the Prime Minister had contacted you.
—Let me make it clear that he has not. I thought I had made that quite clear before. I would ask Senator Kemp to withdraw.

—Yes, that having been made clear, I certainly withdraw any comment that may have caused you offence, Mr President. I certainly withdraw. That certainly was not my intention. In fact, I wanted to clear up a particular concern which I think we have now cleared up.

PARA.TAB: Again, I wish to make one brief comment about your views on Sir Billy Snedden. Mr President, it is these gestures which build up the structure of your office. You and people who have occupied that chair before you, having recognised the need to buttress the independence and the impartiality of the office, have taken these steps. I know you did not wish to sneer at it but I have to say that it came across to me that you felt this was a minor gesture by Sir Billy Snedden. I think it was a very important gesture. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Local government throughout Australia is a very important part of our democratic system. It is the third tier of government in Australia. It is a sphere of government which carries out very important duties which affect all of us, particularly in a more local way in our daily lives.

PARA.TAB: One of the matters that very much concerns me and concerns the peak bodies of local government is that some action has been taken by the government in recent years that has effectively prevented self-employed people from offering themselves for election in that very important third tier of government. The government's superannuation guarantee legislation penalises self-employed people who have their own superannuation and who, like everyone else in Australia, would normally be able to get a tax deduction for that. But, in certain instances, because of the government's superannuation guarantee legislation, councils now have to pay the superannuation guarantee charge—in many instances only a small amount is being paid—in relation to elected councillors. That is okay; there is no problem with that. But there is a problem in that the present legislation effectively prevents those councillors from claiming a tax deduction for their own contributions to private self-employed superannuation funds.

This can mean a very severe financial impediment for self-employed people in local government. It is a matter that peak bodies recognised two years or more ago when this legislation was introduced. As a result of that, they petitioned the government and said, `Look, this is being very unfair to people who are elected to local government positions'. The government looked at this and, because it was in the run-up to an election, the previous minister, Mr Simmons—a former local government person himself; I think he was mayor of his local council—came out with a commitment. He promised that the government would do something about this; that it would fix the superannuation guarantee legislation so that it did not penalise self-employed people by making it very difficult for them to stand for local government positions.

I think Mr Simmons was sincere when he made that promise. But, in retrospect, it is pretty obvious that the thoughts he was enumerating had been given to him by some people who did not ever intend to put those promises into effect. It is now almost two years since Mr Simmons promised in writing that the government would fix that matter, and nothing has been done.

I have asked several questions on the matter. I have continually brought it to the attention of the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Human Services (Mr Howe). The Australian Local Government Association has also done so. Because people send me copies of letters, I am aware of the constant stream of correspondence from local authorities right around Australia to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and to the local government minister asking for that matter to be attended to because the situation is grossly unfair.

Yet, two years after the event, nothing has been done. In September last year Senator Richardson answered a question in this chamber and, after getting advice from the minister, said to me that the minister was looking into it, he had referred it to the Treasurer and we would be getting some advice. That was September last year, and there has been nothing since. A couple of weeks later he told the Australian Local Government Association conference the same thing, but still there is nothing. We were told today by Senator Richardson that it is being looked at and something might come up by June.

Unfortunately, the Queensland local government elections are to be held on 26 March. That will effectively interfere with the right of many people in Queensland to stand for election to that important tier of government because they will be severely financially penalised for so doing. It is a disgraceful situation and one that this government, in spite of its promises and its firm, written commitments two years ago, still has not honoured. That is why I asked in question time: is this a ploy on the part of the Labor Party to save its members facing defeat at local government elections in Queensland, or is it simply another lie in the long list of Labor lies that preceded this election?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to the environmental impact of economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that the question was in three parts and related to the remarks by Dr Adrienne Clarke, the head of CSIRO, that the major environmental problem facing the world today was one of population increase. She had specifically said that that extended to questions of greenhouse, ozone depletion, water pollution and soil erosion and she listed a number of other damaging events. Secondly, my question referred to Dr Marc Latham, the Director-General of the International Board for Soil Research and Management, dealing with such questions as agriculture and soil erosion. He has also and specifically drawn attention to the rapid increase in many of the environmental factors affecting soil and water throughout Asia.

PARA.TAB: The point of the question was in the third part, in which I asked Senator Evans how he reconciled this alternative environmental analysis of Asia with the conventional economists' analysis—the gung-ho analysis that we had in the Garnaut report and have seen more recently in other reports—that Asia was going to be the booming development area in the world and Australia should hitch its wagon to Asia because that is where the future lies. I found his answer totally unsatisfactory in that he came out with the conventional view that, as the economies of Asia grow, they will then be able to address their environmental problems.

Senator Evans is ignoring totally the fact that the environmental problems that I listed in the first part of the question are most severe in those parts of the world which are richest. I point to our own situation where, in terms of purchasing power, the per capita GDP in Australia is one of the highest in the world, yet we are the second worst country in the world in terms of greenhouse.

When those of us in the environment movement raise the issue of greenhouse, what we should be doing about it, and how we should be spending money in addressing this problem of greenhouse, we are told that we cannot afford it. In the news this morning we heard that scientists at the AAAS meeting in America were suggesting the injection of millions of tonnes of sulfur into the stratosphere as a cheaper way of solving the problem than addressing directly the problem of the increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere because the rich nations of the world that are responsible for this problem simply cannot afford to address it.

Senator Evans has totally ignored the evidence which shows that on a per capita basis the environmental problems are worst in the developed world, not in the underdeveloped world. The question still stands and remains unanswered: how is it that Asia, with a burgeoning population increase, will be able to sustain the sorts of economic development which are predicted for it, and is it wise for Australia to hitch its wagon to a series of economies which, for environmental reasons, many of us believe will fall flat on their faces? If Senator Evans reads these remarks, I would like him to review the real evidence in relation to the ability of rich nations to address their environmental problems.

Australia has not only the problems I have outlined in relation to greenhouse but also problems in relation to ozone. We are the world's worst polluters when it comes to ozone depletion. Our water pollution has been mentioned in recent days by the Sydney Water Board. Every ocean beach around Australia in proximity to a capital city is seriously polluted. We are told repeatedly by this government—and we will be told again during the budget sessions that we are just about to go into—that we cannot afford, as a rich nation, to address those problems. How is it then that Asian nations, where these problems are even worse, are going to be able to address them? The question is: is it wise for us to hitch our economic and social future to the nations of Asia? I would certainly argue, and I think many people coming from the environment side would argue, that it is most unwise for us to go down that path. I would like Senator Evans to reconsider his answer to my question today.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has come from the question asked by Senator Coulter is the fact that much of the environmental damage is not caused by population growth at all; it is caused by rich countries, many of which have quite sparse populations. Australia, for example, is contributing significantly to the problem of environmental degradation.
—On a per capita basis, one of the worst.

—As Senator Coulter says, on a per capita basis, one of the worst. We must increase our actions to eliminate the production of ozone depleting CFCs, which will have the beneficial effect of reducing the production of powerful greenhouse gases. The industrialised world has a responsibility to transfer to developing countries those technologies which will be able to attack the potential for an exacerbation of the environmental damage that has already been caused by our richness and our greed.
—That is not what economic rationalism is about.

—That is true. It is not what economic rationalism is about at all; that is exactly right. The point I am making is that it is really unfair to blame population growth, as the CSIRO has done. This is not the time to debate this at length, in a motion to take note of an answer given by Senator Evans, but I do flag that we should look at these things with a great deal more perception than simply jumping on the population control bandwagon. I attended an inter-parliamentary global conference on the environment in Washington on 2 May 1990. I pitched my tent in Green Belt National Park. I was appalled that the well-heeled in the population control bureaucracies were staying at their five star, energy guzzling hotels and belly aching that there were too many Africans and Asians in the world and that they had to do something about it.

PARA.TAB: We do have to think about these things with more perception and discernment than is coming forth from those seemingly eminent people. Eminent they are in their own faculty, eminent they are in their own science, but not eminent when it comes to discerning the major cause of environmental pollution in the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

What a slap in the face for Tasmanian women! Senator Crowley is saying, `Because we are having the meeting in your state and you do not have a representative on that particular council, we will co-opt one for the meeting'. Wonderful!
