TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the statement and the related document entitled Strategic Review 1993. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement and the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Strategic Review 1993 was approved by government earlier this month. It is the latest in a series of published documents in which the government has presented and explained the development of Australia's defence and strategic policies over the past decade. But this document is the first major step in the adaptation of our defence and strategic policies to the major changes now under way in the regional and global security environment following the end of the Cold War.

PARA.TAB: The Strategic Review 1993 looks ahead three to five years to assess the consequences of Australia's security of key strategic developments now under way globally and regionally, and it proposes policy approaches to meet those challenges over the next few years.

It is the first part of a two-stage process. The second part is a white paper, which is now being prepared for government consideration. We expect that it will be published later this year. It will look further ahead into the next century and set long-term approaches to maintaining our security and managing our defence resources.

For the past ten years Australia's defence forces have been developed to meet regional contingencies, not to fight the Cold War. But the end of the Cold War has set in train long-term processes which will profoundly change our regional strategic circumstances.

We need to start adapting now to these emerging trends. Predictability in security matters has declined. Relationships are now more complex, fluid and uncertain. These are not necessarily unfavourable, but they do place new challenges on defence policy-making.

The changes to the fundamentals of regional security are reflected in two major trends. The first of these, flowing directly from the end of the Cold War, is the evolving role of outside powers in regional security affairs, and especially the United States.

America's continued engagement in the Asia-Pacific region is not in question. Despite big cuts, America will for the foreseeable future remain the strongest military power in the world by a wide margin. And America will retain strong interests in the stability and security of the Asia-Pacific region. Those interests will remain fundamentally aligned not just with Australia's interest, but with those of the region as a whole. Therefore, we are confident that America will remain strategically engaged in the Asia-Pacific region, making a very important contribution to maintaining peace and stability in the region.

But it is clear that Americans do not see it as appropriate for them to shoulder alone the responsibility for guaranteeing Asia's security. They will support regional security initiatives, while maintaining their bilateral relationships.Increasingly over coming years regional countries, including Australia and our Asian neighbours, will need to take responsibility themselves for the basic elements of security in the region.

The second major trend in regional security is the extraordinary economic growth in the region itself. Over the next ten years, the strategic potential of the nations of the Asia-Pacific will increase significantly as their economies continue to grow and diversify. Their actual military capabilities are likely to increase, with many new capabilities already being introduced. So by early next century the strategic potential and military capacities of the nations of Asia are likely to be substantially increased.

These trends do not mean that our region is necessarily becoming less secure. On the contrary, the Asia-Pacific region today is stable, prosperous and dynamic. With a few exceptions, the countries of our region show strong economic growth, stable and effective government, and a commitment to peace, stability and freer trade. We have seen that commitment reflected in the development of institutions like APEC and the ASEAN Regional Forum.

Of course, some serious problems remain, particularly on the Korean peninsula, and also for example in the South China Sea. But the collapse of superpower rivalry has eased many tensions in the region, and effective cooperation has helped to resolve longstanding problems like Cambodia.

So we have good reason to be confident about the security of our region. But we cannot be complacent. The fundamental conditions which support Asia-Pacific security are changing, slowly but in important ways. Security in the Asia-Pacific region will ultimately depend on the maintenance of a new and more complex set of interrelationships between the nations of the region.

The clear message of this review is that Australia's security—like its economic future—lies in and with our region. This means we must be a participant, not an onlooker, in regional security and other areas. We must pursue our national interest, through engaging with our region. The challenge for all the nations of the region is to expand their strategic engagement alongside each nation's commitment to its own national defence.

These developments have important ramifications for Australia's strategic policies which are set out in the Strategic Review 1993. I will deal with these first in summary, then in more detail. The Strategic Review confirms that the central focus of defence policy should be our capacity for national defence. This will continue to be pursued through a policy of defence self-reliance.

The Australian people expect that Australia should be able to defend itself, and it is a fundamental requirement of a responsible government to ensure that the nation has this capability. The forces developed for the defence of Australia will also be able to contribute to global and regional activities consistent with our national interests.

Next, a dominant theme of our defence policy will be increasing defence engagement with the region, with a growing focus particularly on South-East Asia. Our alliance with the United States also remains important both for the way it enhances our capacity for national defence and for its contribution to regional security. We will continue to pursue alliance activities which sustain these mutually reinforcing priorities. Finally, the Strategic Review concludes that we must continue to support efforts to promote effective global security mechanisms, especially through the United Nations.

Turning to the opening theme of the Strategic Review 1993—national defence.It is clear that at the core of our ability to contribute to those key activities I have just outlined is the maintenance of a highly competent Defence Force equipped with advanced technology and structured for Australia's unique geo-strategic environment.

The Australian Defence Force of today is shaped by the rigorous application of planning principles enunciated in the Defence of Australia 1987. The most important of these principles is that we must be confident of being able to deal in a timely way with circumstances in the future.Moreover, our capability to defend our own territory is central to our standing in the region and to the role we can play as a partner in regional security.

Our strategy for the defence of Australia remains one of defence in depth. This strategy, and our force structure planning, give priority to presenting any adversary with a comprehensive array of military capabilities capable of independent defensive and offensive operations.

Emphasis, therefore, is given to clearly-focused intelligence and surveillance operations, to strong maritime and air defence capabilities, and to highly mobile and capable land forces which can deal with hostilities quickly on our own terms. The capabilities for these roles determine the ADF's overall force structure.

To optimise our force structure, the development of the ADF will give a particular emphasis to the key principles of joint operations, the promotion of competence and professionalism, the selective application of advanced technology and a rigorous approach to preparedness.

Major expansion of force projection capabilities by other nations for direct attack would require long lead-times which would be clearly evident to us. Our intelligence monitoring and analysis plays a key role in assessing warning time for major conflict.

A commitment to the defence of Australia includes a commitment to the industrial strength of this nation. The development of our defence science and industry are important elements of our self-reliant defence capability. Without support from defence science and industry, the sustainability of our combat support capabilities would be quickly eroded.

The Government is committed to developing, in Australian industry, an ability to support and maintain Defence Force equipment and, where appropriate, to produce it in Australia. The close relationship between defence industry and defence science will be an important factor in our ability to deliver the technological advances demanded by our defence requirements.

As a result of this Government's support for local industry, Defence is now better able to draw on Australian industry. This is reflected in the considerable increase in local content for defence systems and equipment, from 30 per cent a decade ago, to 65 per cent today. Defence depends heavily on Australian industry for the provision of goods and services. Local shipbuilding and electronics industries are playing a major role in the delivery of many of our major defence platforms such as submarines and frigates. Defence is also looking towards industry to provide maintenance and support of equipment and, through the commercial support program, to provide a range of support services such as catering and base support.

I turn now to the next theme of this review, namely regional engagement. The recognition that our future security lies with our region, not against it, provides us with significant opportunities to enhance our national interests by contributing to regional security and enmeshing ourselves in this economically dynamic region.

We intend to expand and accelerate our strategic engagement with our nearer region alongside our primary commitment to developing our self-reliant capacity for the defence of Australia. We are establishing closer relations with nations of the Asia-Pacific region—especially our neighbours in South-East Asia—across all aspects of national endeavour. The enhancement of these relationships will greatly strengthen our security. Their proximity is a factor in our security and their position as major trading partners contributes to our national well-being. Australia in turn has much to contribute to regional security and the capabilities we have developed for our self-reliant defence will help support peace and stability.

During the preparation of this review, we undertook an unprecedented series of consultations with the countries of our nearer region. It was important that we understood regional views and perspectives, and that our thinking was understood and appreciated by our neighbours as a positive contribution to our mutual security goals.

The same approach was taken with our alliance partners. This forward-looking, open approach is a touchstone of defence thinking under this Government. It has paid significant dividends in our developing relationships with our region.The result is that Australia is better prepared than many other countries to face the realities of the post-Cold War world of today, a world that is more regionally focused than before.

Nonetheless, the Asia-Pacific region has been changing rapidly in line with the aspirations of individual nations. Australia, as an active member of this region, must make the necessary adjustments to keep pace. In South-East Asia, we are developing defence relationships based on the concept of strategic partnership. We have long stressed the need for Australia to strengthen its linkages with its neighbours and comprehensively engage with the region.

We aim now to move beyond the framework of existing cooperative activities to consider new opportunities, including for shared training, defence science and industry cooperation and procurement. This will increase our understanding of regional defence developments and encourage effective and responsible planning for self-reliance that will add to the strategic strength of the region as a whole. Clearly, the particular nature of our partnerships which develop will vary from country to country over time.

Our relationship with Indonesia remains central to regional engagement. Priority will be given to the development of personal and professional relationships amongst senior officers on both sides, combined exercises, personnel exchanges, training and other activities which foster long-term mutual understanding at all levels.

The five-power defence arrangements will remain relevant to our defence policy objectives of promoting regional security and are an important element in Australia's national engagement with our nearer region. Through the Malaysia-Australia joint defence program and defence science and industry working group, we have a well-established and mutually beneficial defence relationship with Malaysia.

With Singapore, the relationship has broadened substantially to include access to our training areas such as the Delamere Air Weapons Range and Shoalwater Bay and to the collocation of Singapore Air Force personnel and 30 aircraft with existing Australian RAAF personnel at Pearce in Western Australia. This agreement, totally funded by the Singapore government, is a valuable extension of Australia's defence links with Singapore.

These increasing defence force and defence industry links with regional nations are an important indicator of the growing sense of regional strategic community. It serves our interests and those of regional countries to pursue the development of such links. Such activities represent the type of openness that is one of the building blocks of regional stability and security. More broadly, the Association of South East Asian Nations will be central to efforts by regional countries to achieve workable and common approaches on regional security issues. The establishment last July of the ASEAN Regional Forum was an important step in this regard.

With New Zealand we will seek to maintain a strong defence relationship based on the longstanding commitment of each nation to the security of the other. Our efforts to promote our shared defence interests and commitments will be based on our program of closer defence relations and the coordination of our policies throughout the region. We will also maintain strategic commitment to Papua New Guinea and other south west Pacific states with a focus on cooperation, which assists in promoting national resilience and increases the capacity of these nations to deal with security problems.

Further afield, the increasing power and influence of the major Asian powers such as Japan, the People's Republic of China and India, require Australia to develop constructive contact with these countries in the security field. In particular, we need to understand their interests and gain their understanding of Australia's objectives in enhancing regional security.

The continuation of a US strategic role in the Asia-Pacific region remains a critical element for the security of Australia and our region. Our alliance relationship with the United States is the next key theme of the review, with an emphasis on its importance in the context of a shared commitment to security in the Asia-Pacific region. Australia's defence relationship with the United States helps maintain US strategic links with this part of the world and thereby contributes to regional stability. It is also of enduring significance for our national strategic posture. Our alliance with the United States continues to be an important factor in the development of Australia's defence capabilities. Both countries acknowledge the continuing importance of our security cooperation under the ANZUS treaty, including the continuing relevance and the value of mutual security obligations embodied in the treaty, and our close consultation on issues of mutual security concern. The nature of the relationship continues to evolve, as it has over the past five decades, but it has grown even stronger. This is a reflection of the depth of our shared values.

While Australian industry is increasing its ability to support the Australian Defence Force, a number of weapons platforms and technologies in our defence inventory are purchased from and supported by the United States. We could not afford to produce such systems locally. The joint defence facilities and our intelligence relationship with the United States remain valuable factors in our security and they continue to make a major contribution to global and regional security. Australia's defence science activities benefit strongly from cooperation with the United States, both bilaterally and through the technical cooperation program.

The final theme of the Strategic Review 1993 concerns our support for the United Nations and wider national efforts to promote mechanisms that contain the spread of weapons of mass destruction. An Australian contribution to international efforts to keep or restore peace is consistent with our interests. Our participation in peace support operations is a tangible demonstration of our commitment to the peaceful resolution of international conflicts, one of our major foreign policy goals.

When peace support operations occur within our own region, Australian involvement also reinforces our position as a participant in and a contributor to regional security, which is one of our major defence goals. Working together with regional states on peacekeeping operations, for example, in Cambodia adds to a sense of regional security and reinforces our capability to act together in other situations if needed.

There are limits to the amount of peacekeeping to which we can commit. Our level of contribution should not blind us to one basic point: such activities are supplementary to the central role of the Australian Defence Force in the direct defence of Australia and its interests and the promotion of those interests within our neighbourhood. Each request we receive for our participation in a peace support operation must, therefore, be considered on its own merits and with a very clear understanding of its implications for our national interests.

Finally, a word about resources. In recent years, Defence has made highly innovative and successful reforms to maximise efficiencies and maintain investment and capabilities broadly in line with our long-term defence policy, despite significant reductions in financial guidance. These efforts will continue and intensify, but the maintenance of a self-reliant defence capability that can protect Australia, contribute to the security of our wider region and support the United Nations will require continued commitment by the Commonwealth and the people of Australia to adequate sustained defence funding.

In conclusion, Strategic Review 1993 is the first comprehensive post-Cold War assessment of Australia's strategic outlook. Work has now begun on the Defence white paper to be released later this year. It will take account of the key assessments and the broad policy framework in the strategic review and, from these, develop detailed planning guidance for Defence for the first decade of the next century.

It will review and, if necessary, revise our basic planning concepts to ensure that they fit our evolving strategic environment and provide planning guidance on force structure development, management of regional and alliance relationships, and industry, science and personnel policy. This strategic review and the white paper which will follow will build on the defence policy developed by this government over the past decade to provide a clear and rigorous basis for Australia's defence policy into the next century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for presenting his ministerial statement, even though it is probably a few months late. There is no more important obligation on a government than the security of its people and their freedom from aggression from other nations. It is, quite simply, the first and most important duty of a national government.

PARA.TAB: Sadly, in the 11 years of this Labor government we have seen a policy of keeping debate on defence out of the parliament and as low key as possible. We have also seen a policy of progressively reducing the defence budget. There has been a marked decline in Australia's defence capability in the 11 years that the Labor Party has been in government. I accept at the outset that it is difficult, but I certainly do not accept that it is impossible, to maintain an interest in funding defence forces in a democracy in a peacetime state. But the lessons of history are that wars are a recurrent, tragic event for the human race.

We never know when we will need a defence force. If we have a good defence force, the chances of having to use it are considerably less than if we have no defence force or an inadequate defence force. The other basic fundamental about a defence force is that we cannot fund it in good years when we have a good season, a good wool clip, good beef prices or something like that and then not fund it when times are hard. We have to maintain a basic level of constant expenditure so that we maintain capability and expertise within that defence force. It is an ongoing commitment.

It is now nearly 50 years since the end of World War II. That means that the time of stress placed on the nation, when its national security was challenged, is beyond the memory of most Australians who are alive today. The ending of the Cold War a couple of years ago also contributed to a run-down in interest and willingness to support defence measures. The emergence of the United Nations, both in its peacekeeping and peace enforcement roles, has conveyed some false aspects to the maintenance of international security. I am very pleased that we have not had any world wars for 50 years. I am very pleased to see the end of the Cold War, which was a highly dangerous state for all of us. I am very pleased to see an expansion of the United Nations into peacekeeping and other roles to maintain international security. But that is not the end of the matter by any means.

What we are talking about here is national security, and in that there can be no mistakes. We are playing for the highest of all stakes with respect to our own security. If we get it wrong and we do not protect the country in the way we should, then tens of thousands or even hundreds of thousands of young lives will be lost, and lost pointlessly. We will have many careers broken. We will have enormous disruptions to the community and an enormous economic debt. Of course, in the worst possible case, we could lose the country. So this really is a very important issue.

It has been the practice of all Australian governments, probably since the end of the Second World War, to make appreciations, in the military sense, of what might be the security situation that faces Australia. These appreciations are done every three to five years and, up to 1990, they have always been regarded as confidential documents. In 1990 the Labor government released a publication called Australia's strategic planning in the 1990s, which was the first release ever—of what used to be called a strategic basis paper—for the general public. I support the government in its activities to add to the debate on security matters by doing so.

The difficulty with these strategic planning papers is that, first of all, they are sanitised. We do not know what has been left out. This paper is in exactly the same category as the one that preceded it in 1990. The other great difficulty is that they lead to white papers, which more precisely define the threat and, therefore, the force structure and capabilities that are needed to counter that threat.

It is not given to anyone, least of all the senior people in the Department of Defence, to accurately foresee the future. While it is prudent and commonsense to make an appreciation of what might happen, the difficulties are that when those predictions become prescriptive, they become enshrined as fact as to what is going to happen and the force structure of the Defence Force is designed about them. Sadly, that is what tends to be done instead of taking them as a guide, like the Queensland railways timetable, of what might happen. As I said before, it is not given to any of us to forecast the future.

The first paper to be released, Australia's strategic planning in the 1990s, was a sanitised document. It virtually validated what the government had been doing up to the time. It maintained the status quo. Page 3 of that report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the end of the Cold War that has prompted the government to release this declassified version. ASP 90 shows that the broad thrust of Australia's security approach remains appropriate despite the major global changes we have seen.

There is not terribly much difference between the paper tabled today and ASP `90, except that it rejects the assertion that despite the end of the Cold War there have been no changes. Sadly, the document before us today is twice the size; it is 75 pages. While I have made only a quick review of it, I have a feeling of disappointment about it. It mentions, as a central part of its claims, the fact that the end of the Cold War creates a different environment for Australia. That is perfectly true. But it then does not go on to forecast in any detail at all what those changes might be that affect the Australian Defence Force.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems we face in dealing with a paper such as this—after all, this is a booklet of 75 pages—is reviewing it in the time that we have before it comes into the chamber. I would like to thank Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence, for his generosity in making the paper available to me before the normal one hour before tabling time. It was made available to me a bit after 12.00 p.m. today, but even so it is a very short period to go through what is a really major statement, read the minister's 20-minute tabling speech as well and organise my views on it. The sad point is that if we do not tackle it at the time of tabling, we will not get a chance in the Senate to come back to it.

There is a great deal of repetition in this document. It does not really advance the sum of public knowledge at all. Without being unkind to it, I do not think there is an original thought in it. All that is in it about the changed circumstances, the government could have learned had it listened to what I have been saying for years and what all the members of the opposition have been saying—that is, the ending of the Cold War has had significant changes on Australia's security considerations.

We have moved from a bipolar world to a multipolar world. We have moved from a world where global issues predominated to a world where regional or national issues predominate. We have moved from superpower defence, where we could shelter with the Americans and the NATO countries, to a period of self-defence. We have moved from some degree of certainty of our defence threats to an area of uncertainty and unpredictability. It is not only the uncertainty of what might happen in foreign relations in the region, our relations with other countries, but also we have a great deal of uncertainty now as to who our allies would be in any sort of military conflict. That becomes very important with respect to logistic support, munitions, equipment and things that we would need.

Overall, I have the impression, reading this book, that there is a very strong influence of Foreign Affairs on the Department of Defence. While I have the greatest of respect for the Department of Foreign Affairs, it really has a limited place in defence planning and defence analysis, particularly when it gets into the field of intelligence gathering, which Foreign Affairs prides itself on. The only thing that I would say to the department is that from Fiji to the Falklands it got it wrong. While there is a place for consultation around the cocktail circuits and the embassies of the world, the business of defence is the business of the defence department. I can see many fingerprints on this document of current thinking in the Department of Foreign Affairs.

At the end of the day, Strategic Review 1993 comes up with no specific requirements that have to be met for the defence of Australia. The minister presented a good speech for 20 minutes and I do not propose to debate that speech here. I think the essence of what we are talking about this afternoon is in the paper itself. I propose to move through the paper. The introductory statement is good. In the preface it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The defence of Australia is not just an activity of Government. It requires the understanding, involvement and support of the Australian people.

That is a fundamental truth. That is something that the government should actively work at—to educate people that defence is not the responsibility alone of the people in uniform in Australia; it is something that involves all of us. We all have a part to play in it. In the introduction there is again a general statement:

Australia's security derives from a combination of factors, including the maintenance of a highly competent defence force equipped with advanced technology and structured for Australia's unique geostrategic environment, growing involvement in a widening range of cooperative arrangements with Asian neighbours, and our active support for global security and international alliances.
That is true. The next sentence says:
The Australian Defence Force (ADF) of today is shaped by a rigorous application of planning principles enunciated in the Defence of Australia 1987 White Paper.
I mentioned before the difficulties that arise—the lack of flexibility and balance—when white papers prescribe what will happen in the future.

PARA.TAB: Chapter 1 is a reasonable review of Australia's strategic outlook. There is some comment about the United Nations in paragraph 1.10 to the effect that it is to be supported and encouraged to fulfil its fundamental role, which is the maintenance of secure international relations around the world. However, it must be recognised that there are limitations on what the United Nations can do. For example, there are difficulties when a shooting war starts, particularly within a country. We have all witnessed the impotence of the United Nations to effectively control what is going on today in the former Yugoslavia.

The next point in this chapter refers to United States strategic defence policy and transitions and the very major defence force reductions taking place. The certainty of those reductions, which is not mentioned in this report, is that the Americans will make a mess of them. They always get force reductions wrong; that is the lesson of history. They will probably cut too deeply and inappropriately and that will lead to increased security tensions around the world. Conversely, when expansion is required the Americans always get it right—they get it right brilliantly. They have produced miracles when it comes to force expansion, but when it comes to force reduction, unfortunately, history is against them.

The other difficulty with the American position in the Pacific at the present time is the great conflict of interest over commercial activities in Japan. No-one knows where that will end up but the certainty is that the Americans will be looking for allies. If we have some military difficulty with another Pacific nation, there is no way that we can make a confident prediction that the Americans will support us under ANZUS. It is possible that America will give preference to its commercial interests and support a country with interests at variance with our own. After all, when our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was in Japan last year he said that Australia would support Japan against the United States in any commercial conflict arising out of trade negotiations.

The chapter goes on to talk about North-East Asia. In particular, it deals with the Korean peninsula, an area of serious concern since it is the world's pre-eminent military flashpoint. The situation there shows the limitations of arms control agreements. I have been a great supporter of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, as has this parliament, but the defiance of the provisions of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty by the North Koreans demonstrates that at the end of the day these agreements have their limitations.

South-East Asia is an area of great economic growth, but growth is uneven between the nations. History shows us that when economic growth takes place and economic competition is paramount, that often leads to some degree of military competition and, at times, friction. While the economic growth of South-East Asia is to be applauded for a variety of reasons, that is no guarantee of peace eternal in the region.

The chapter also deals with the South-West Pacific area. It does not say too much because there is not much the government can say about its activities in the South-West Pacific area. It and Papua New Guinea have been the great black hole, the area of neglect, in our foreign policy over the last 11 years. Similarly, the chapter on New Zealand is also very weak. The New Zealanders simply are not pulling their weight. Recently, the foreign minister of Australia went to New Zealand and told them to pull up their socks and do something about it; they just yawned. This is a country that spends 1.4 per cent of a minuscule GDP on defence, so in real terms, that expenditure is very low. It is really only a token. I remind the Senate that it was New Zealand that broke the ANZUS agreement, and the consequence of that was increased costs for our defence forces, which are already tightly strapped for money.

The Australian government has taken the view that if it does not cosset the New Zealand government and put up with its unreal views on world affairs—particularly with regard to its own security—New Zealand will get right out of having a defence force. They believe that half a loaf is better than no loaf. My personal view is that, unless New Zealand is prepared to make a contribution proportionally equal to our contribution to security, we should sever any links with them, and that includes commercial agreements such as the CER and the rest. We are flat out paying for our own defence without carrying a weak sister at the same time.

Chapter 2 deals with the United Nations. One problem is that the United Nations has not set up a military command and control system. It has not planned for anything other than peacekeeping activities. Most of those activities have been successful. Cambodia was a brilliant success. It was a great mistake that the Australian government did not send General Sanderson to New York as our military attache to the UN. While he would have been grossly over-ranked there, he would have gone as a hero—the victor of Cambodia—and he would have filled a vacuum that exists in military planning and military expertise, which would have been extremely valuable and would have expanded Australia's influence in the UN.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there certainly is a vacuum there.

—There is a huge vacuum, as I know very well. Instead, the government created the fiction of the joint forces headquarters at HQADF and created a post for him that will simply cost us money. It is a post that certainly does not need to be filled in peacetime.

PARA.TAB: Chapter 3 deals with regional security. That is the standard line that the government is pushing now—the line the opposition has been pushing for 10 or 15 years. Fifteen years ago I said that our defence and security depended on the defence and security of the region. That is one reason that I attacked the isolationist theme of the Dibb report and why its recommendations were totally untenable. However, the government has now come around to recognising that fact, which is good, even if it is a little late in the day. Of course, militarily, Australia has always enjoyed good relations with the military establishments of all the nations in the regions. In some cases, they are better than our commercial or diplomatic relations.

Chapter 4 deals with Australia's relationship with the United States. It is a very important chapter because even today ANZUS is absolutely essential to us. It is welcomed by the regional countries. They like Australia being part of ANZUS because they recognise that it is a sort of guarantee of the United States taking an interest in the region. There are also many benefits of ANZUS for Australia. High technology equipment is one. I should say here that Australia is one of the few countries in the world that has always paid top dollar for the equipment it has purchased from the United States. We have never been a party to any military aid program. While we are grateful for the access to this equipment, we have always paid for what we have bought. The other great benefit is our access to American intelligence gathering.

I would like to deplore the Prime Minister's statement made during his recent visit to the United States that henceforth the basis of the relationship between Australia and the US will be based on commercial interests and not security interests. That is a very false and shallow reading of the relationship between the two countries and one which, in the fullness of time, we will come to regret if anyone tries to implement it in a wholehearted way.

Chapter 5 deals with Australia's defence posture. It starts with the laudable statement that we have a responsibility to the Australian people to provide for our own defence. I wholeheartedly support that view. On page 41, under the heading `Planning for the defence of Australia', things start to become a little bit fuzzy. Paragraph 5.14 says:

SPEECH.PARA: In circumstances where Australia faces no identifiable military threat, priorities for the development of our defence capabilities are driven principally by Australia's geography, the different forms of conflict to which we would be required to respond, and the timescales in which various levels of pressure which could arise.
Paragraph 5.16 reads:

Australia's northern environment also presents potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited by an adversary. The use of limited military force to attack population centres or settlements and other targets around northern Australia, our offshore territories and resource assets, and shipping in proximate areas could pose significant problems for us.

That is a very defeatist statement and sends very much the wrong signals to the region. The simple answer is that we would not sit back and allow Australia's sparsely settled areas to be picked off at will by any marauding armed forces from another country. The facts are that no armed force comes out of the thin air. It comes from a base, and it comes from a base in a country. The message which should be clearly spelt out in our doctrine is that any armed intervention against Australia will be met by an instant retaliation against the base from which that force operates. If that does not stop it, it escalates from then on. There is no other option available to us. If we run around trying to appease people and argue the case in diplomatic circles, we will be exhausted. We cannot maintain our sovereignty on that basis.

PARA.TAB: The next part of the chapter deals with warning times and the difference between intention and capability. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Intent alone is an insufficient basis for defence planning, since intentions can change relatively quickly.

That misses the point altogether about intentions. One can measure capabilities of another country but one can never measure intentions. People or nations that have offensive aims in life do not make their intentions clear. The classical case was Iraq and its invasion of Kuwait. No-one could foresee that. It is quite wrong to claim intentions can change relatively quickly, and miss the major point that they cannot be measured.The chapter also has a section called `Major Conflict'. It says:
Further, Australia has a significant capacity to expand its forces.

One of the difficulties with all the planning that has gone on in the last 15 or 20 years is that no-one has taken seriously the case that we may be involved in something beyond low-level contingencies. With regard to a major war which might arise—even though it might be remote—planning for expansion, which is an essential task of the Department of Defence, simply has not been done. The worst-case scenario, where we might be fighting a major war on our own, is never contemplated.

PARA.TAB: We then come to a section entitled `Defence of Australia Roles'. On page 45 a number of qualities are listed. There is no argument about the topics listed, but the priority in which they are listed does reflect a degree of muddled thinking, because the first one is intelligence collection and evaluation. The second is surveillance of maritime areas and northern Australia. The list then continues as follows: maritime patrol and response; protection of shipping, offshore territories and resources; air defence in maritime areas and northern approaches; defeat of incursions on Australian territory; protection of important civil and defence assets, including infrastructure and population centres; and strategic strike.

The lessons of war as they apply to Australia are best shown up in the Second World War because that was a situation where national security was threatened in a way it never had been before. We had to fight in our own geographic region. It was quite different from fighting in France, North Africa and all the other places that Australian forces have been involved in. The lesson that came out of the Second World War was the pre-eminent role of air power in our environment. It showed flexibility, responsiveness, range, versatility for air superiority, strike, surveillance, transport, adaptability and concentration made air power predominant in our environment.

The other matter which I believe needs to be considered about air power and its neglect in Australian defence planning is that it is now more socially acceptable to use and develop air power than to be involved in the widespread carnage of the land battlefield, or ships being torpedoed and sinking in blazing fuel oil. Death in any form is to be deplored, and we want to avoid it. It is horrible in any sense. But the social climate of Australia, as I read it, is more prepared to see aircraft used in an offensive role to protect our interests than to see massed armies or navies going to sea to defend our interests.

Technological advances allow precision guided munitions to be used from air platforms, so that the collateral damage to civilians is limited. The aim of all these activities, of course, is to destroy an attacking nation's military potential. If that potential can be precisely destroyed without damaging either the human life or civilian structure of that other country, I think it is a more acceptable way to go.

In recent years, an imbalance has been created in the Australian Defence Force. We have put a huge amount of money into developing naval capabilities—the Collins submarines, the Minehunter program, the Anzac ships, to name a few—which have sucked up all the available capital. We have a huge investment in naval construction, now and in the future.

Before I leave this chapter I point out that while it talks about what Australia needs to do to plan for its defence, it carries with it the implication we have a clean sheet of paper, which is quite false. We do not have a clean sheet of paper at all. We are the inheritors of the mismanagement and bad policies of the Labor government. I refer particularly to what Mr Beazley did when he was defence minister, with his defence equipment purchases. He has dictated what capabilities the Australian defence forces will possess for the next 30 years. As to the Anzac ship program, not one ship has been launched. We will be running those ships 30 or 35 years down the track because we simply cannot afford to get away from it.

The chapter about Australia's defence posture should contain something about how we are going to use the capabilities that we have been locked into. Some of those have been as a result of the Cold War philosophy. The Anzac ship is a classic example of buying a capability for the Cold War.

There are many basic shortcomings of the Australian Defence Force, and they are not mentioned in the review. I hope when we get the next chapter in this saga, the white paper, some of the specifics of Australia's defence capabilities will be addressed in more detail than we have here. As I have said, this is a disappointing document. There is nothing new in it. I hope the follow-on white paper is a bit more intellectually developed. I hope it is not a blue paper, meaning written entirely with a view to the United Nations and foreign affairs and peacekeeping forces, but that it really does deal with the nuts and bolts of how we are going to defend this country in the next decade or two.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the public release of the Strategic Review 1993 as a step towards more openness in defence policy making. We also welcome the review's low-key emphasis and sober analysis of possible military threats from the region, although no doubt some of its more controversial conclusions have been cut to prevent antagonising regional neighbours. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has acknowledged that taking part in United Nations' operations and regional security cooperation are increasingly important contributors to national security. Subject to important reservations, which I will outline later, the Democrats would agree with that assumption as well.Indeed, I would like to place on record our admiration for the very fine contribution that Australian forces have made to peacekeeping operations with the United Nations in recent times.

PARA.TAB: We further support the document's statement that Defence should buy Australian to support self-reliance. It is to the shame of this government that it cannot apply the same philosophy to the defence of our economy. If other ministers and departments showed the same commitment to Australian industry, our unemployment rate and balance of payments would look a great deal better.

We disagree with the document in some key respects, which I will now discuss. The document fails to acknowledge that some forms of regional military cooperation, such as training, joint exercises, exports and aid, can undermine security by contributing to human rights abuses. Australian aid to the Papua New Guinea defence force has demonstrably contributed to atrocities on Bougainville during the first Papua New Guinea defence force military campaign against the BRA, and via the blockade which has resulted in many innocent deaths from preventable diseases.

Joint training with Indonesia's special forces links Australia with abuses committed by those forces on Aceh. The effect of human rights abuses is to undermine respect for and confidence in the regime which commits them. This undermines stability and is therefore not in Australia's security interests, even from a conventional viewpoint. The Democrats are not opposed to regional security cooperation, but it should be carefully designed to promote, not detract from, respect for human rights.

The section on regional security is fairly sanguine about the pattern of arms purchases in the region, although it identifies some potential for competition to undermine sound strategic judgment and distort force structures. What this ignores is the positive contribution that arms restraint could make to regional security and economic prosperity. This is not about to happen in the near future, but it would be appropriate for Australia to start raising the possibility and focusing regional minds on the benefits of arms restraint. We admit that there are many obstacles to regional arms restraint, not least China's force projection ambitions and the uncertainties surrounding its political evolution, but that is no reason not to start the debate.

The section dealing with national defence acknowledges that Australia faces no identifiable military threat. This has been the case for decades. Elsewhere, the review concludes that the likelihood that economic tensions and divergent growth patterns will spill over into military confrontation is not high. On the other hand there is an acknowledgment that trade in illegal immigrants is growing, becoming more sophisticated and requiring greater resources for its monitoring and prevention.

The review also spells out the various ways in which Defence provides aid to the community through non-defence activities such as disaster relief. However, I find no mention in the review of environmental threats, yet these are growing rapidly, just as regional military threats are declining. The review maintains the longstanding view that non-defence tasks should not determine the Australian Defence Force's overall force structure. Yet it is becoming less and less likely that the Australian Defence Force will be called upon to defend Australia militarily, given the growing importance of regional and global security institutions.

None of this is to suggest that we should not have a national defence system, but the Democrats would ask whether we could better combine military defence with defence against natural disasters, illegal immigration and environmental degradation. For example, the Democrats would ask whether the guided missile frigates will be as useful as a greater number of lighter and faster coastal patrol vessels costing the same amount. I note that Senator MacGibbon made a similar point. There is a widespread view that coastal patrol vessels would have been better able to defend against low-level military incursions while being far more useful for such peacetime tasks as fisheries patrol and the interception of smugglers and illegal immigrants.

We are strongly of the view that Defence should purchase a fleet of at least six Canadair CL-415 amphibious aircraft. These are brilliant water bombers which are also useful for coastal monitoring and patrol. There is a widely held view that the gallant men and women who fought the New South Wales bushfires deserved far more firebombing support than the helicopters which were provided. If Canadair aircraft are good enough for such diverse countries as France, Greece and Thailand, they are surely worth considering for Australia.

The review states that Defence needs to maintain close liaison with civil surveillance organisations and explore ways for them to assist in time of conflict. The Democrats would argue that if Defence provided more assistance to civil surveillance as I have just outlined, it would be much better served in times of conflict. It is a sign of the inadequacy of our coastal surveillance systems that a boatload of Chinese refugees can reach the Western Australian coast without being detected, and that a fugitive Malaysian prince and his children can drift for days through Australian waters without being intercepted.

The review concludes by warning that adequate sustained defence funding is needed to ensure that the ADF can protect Australia, contribute to regional security and support the United Nations. The Democrats would ask whether Defence has cut sufficient fat from its own budget. In these days of fiscal stringency it is remarkable that Defence is the only department to escape line-by-line budgetary scrutiny of the Department of Finance and the Expenditure Review Committee. We believe that that must change.

The minister has attacked the Democrats for objecting to his attempts to save money by contracting out services at Woomera under the commercial support program. We do not object to legitimate attempts to save money, but we are totally opposed to cost cutting by stripping employees of benefits to which they are lawfully entitled. Savings should be achieved humanely, in accordance with the government's own industrial relations principles.

The application of the CSP to Woomera is not the only case to raise such concerns. The federal Labor member for McEwen, Mr Cleeland, raised similar concerns about its implementation at the Puckapunyal army base in the Sunday Age of 13 February this year. I cannot vouch for the accuracy of Mr Cleeland's allegations, but I would urge the minister to ensure that industrial rights are not again trampled on under the CSP.

In summary, and in conclusion, there are some aspects of the Strategic Review 1993 with which the Democrats agree. However, it does not appear to have moved with the times or shown the flexibility and lateral thinking which our new strategic circumstances demand. There are opportunities for a responsible and productive change in course, but it seems to us that Defence remains too preoccupied with the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question to be asked about the strategic review before us is what is the point of it. Its stated outlook is three to five years ahead, while the other part of this assessment process, the forthcoming white paper, will be looking into the next century. It is extremely peculiar: why have a short focus document preceding the white paper, especially as the short-term focus of the 1993 review has to be subject to longer term views to be encompassed in the white paper? The relevance of the strategic review is questionable until the white paper is finished. Despite that, the government is presenting this as a serious look at Australia's defence policies, and I must highlight some of the serious concerns apparent in this review.

PARA.TAB: Regarding our own forces, the following point was made in the statement of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray):

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Defence Force of today is shaped by the rigorous application of planning principles enunciated in the Defence of Australia 1987.

But by the government's own admission in the force structure review, 25 per cent of the program is not achievable. If this is a rigorous application, I would hate to see sloppy application of planning principles.

PARA.TAB: The review states that Australia's current military relationship with the United States helps maintain US strategic links in this part of the world, and therefore contributes to regional security. That is an absurd leap of faith when one considers the destruction and following security problems wreaked in the pursuit of US national interests in Korea, Vietnam, Iraq and central America, to name a few. A more secure region might be gained through an understanding of the US-Japan relationship, but there is little investigation into how the department feels about that relationship, and the possibilities of Japanese rearmament and even nuclear weapons capability, as flaunted in the Korean nuclear crisis.

Also in relation to the United States, rather strange mention is made of our obligations under ANZUS. I ask the question: what exactly are our obligations under ANZUS? It has long been considered and accepted that our obligations were to accept without question, and not necessarily with a great amount of prior information, the visits of nuclear-powered or armed warships. This never has been and never will be part of the ANZUS agreement as it stands. Yet New Zealand was punished for disobeying part of an agreement which did not exist.

So our ANZUS agreement required us to provide information only to each other, information which did not seem to be always forthcoming from the United States. It seems as though it was used against us by the US saying, `You'—that is, Australia and New Zealand—`must accept the visits of nuclear-powered or armed warships without question, otherwise you have broken the agreement'. It was a nonsense argument then, and is a nonsense argument now. Yet it is still being used in current military reviews.

There is also mention in section 4.3 of the report entitled Strategic Review 1993 that Australia provides opportunities for the United States military at little cost to US taxpayers. I can say that but page 37, section 4.11, actually suggests that we offer more. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We should also encourage the United States to use Australian facilities for maintenance and support to assist its continued maritime presence in the region.
What does this mean? Considering the closure of the Philippines bases, does this mean an invitation to establish full-time United States naval bases in Australia?

PARA.TAB: I return to other questions. Focusing on the near region, the current and longstanding policy is, first, to prop up the post-colonial state of Papua New Guinea against internal threats, such as those in Bougainville, and the external, but hardly ever mentioned, threat from Indonesia; and, secondly, to befriend Indonesia. This policy has prevailed over considerations of self-determination and human rights, and evidently there are no signs of its improving.

The review places importance on the strategic commitment to Papua New Guinea and on increasing the capacity of south-west Pacific nations to deal with security problems. It must be recognised that the major security threats to Papua New Guinea begin with ecological and internal social problems, escalating because the Papua New Guinea administration believes it can deal with them through a military response and is supported in this belief by Australia. This current strategic commitment is resulting in significant upheaval in Papua New Guinea and is causing regional concerns with Indonesia, which is wary of any ethnic groups gaining a right to self-determination, and the Solomon Islands, where the PNG military have made incursions and possibly killings while engaged in Bougainville.

The Strategic Review has not considered that the environmental destruction by international companies, resulting in dislocation of peoples from their lands, spreads the seeds of dissent and fuels arms struggles which when met with excessive military response, do indeed turn into a military problem. This is why a huge crisis began in Bougainville. One only needs to look at the environmental and consequential social upheaval throughout PNG, the Philippines and elsewhere if they wish to avert similar security problems.

Because the Strategic Review does not address the necessary steps to end our support for PNG disintegration and Indonesian repression, Australia's actions are a source of insecurity for people in our immediate region. I can quickly outline some points in which Australia can have a role in enhancing security—steps which are not unknown to the government and Department of Defence, steps that have been outlined by academics and non-government organisations, steps that the department could have seen fit to include had it seriously undertook consultations on the regional security problems.

First, Australia must support regional self-determination, support democratic, non-corrupt movements in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. Practical elements of this would be formulating proposals for resolution of the conflicts in East Timor, west Papua and Bougainville—this does not imply thrashing the local people into fearsome submission—suspending the Timor Gap treaty until there is an acceptable resolution of the problem in East Timor, and phasing out military aid to Indonesia.

Secondly, Australia needs to tackle controversial issues such as human rights, self-determination and the environment, acknowledging the value of the non-government network. Thirdly, Australia needs to look at some sort of peace building commitment to PNG over the border with Irian-Jaya. I am astounded that the problem in west Papua concerning Indonesia, PNG and Australia receives no special mention, considering the trilateral nature of the problem.

Australia must also forestall the regional arms build-up, despite the minister's denial of it. I will give honourable senators some examples from the report. I refer to the introduction on page 1. Key factors of change within the region include `the force modernisation underway in many countries in the region'. That is upgrading, keeping up with the Joneses. Page 11, section 1.32, mentions a switch in emphasis from ground forces orientated to internal security in the region to a `focus on modern maritime and air forces to support new economic and security interests'. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: New prosperity will mean that real growth in defence spending is likely to continue, allowing the introduction of high-technology weapons systems. The glut of weapons on the current world arms market will facilitate this.
Section 1.35 suggests that this accelerated arms race, or buyers' market, will `enhance regional stability' against pressures from `further afield'. Who and how will it be enhancing security from?

PARA.TAB: What is more, page 49, section 5.53, suggests that Australia's standing in the region requires that we keep an edge on `skills in acquiring and adapting high technology for national defence'. If our military thinks this, surely that is also what others in the region believe—namely, that their military standing depends on the nature of the war toys that they can acquire.

In reality, the most effective way to forestall the regional arms build-up is to include curbing the long-range naval and air strike capacity and seeking comprehensive arms control agreements. The always anticipated boom in exports sales from the arms industry is not achievable, as was highlighted in the recent hearings of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I do not know why the department insists, as it does in sections 1.32 and 1.33 of the review, that there is a strategic and economic potential in the regional arms market. The flood of available arms from around the globe keeps our market down to a few specialised goods and services, and anyway serve only to facilitate the abuse of human rights.

Fifthly, going wider than the limited approach presented in this review, Australia must use its aid budget to avert the two major non-military security threats facing Papua New Guinea: resource destruction and environmental degradation, and political disintegration. This would involve stipulating that aid cannot continue under conditions of gross corruption, as examined in Tos Barnett's report a few years ago, and rechannelling aid through non-government organisations to avoid the unaccountability of the current administration. Sixthly, Australia could help establish and fund a conflict mediation service run by the South Pacific forum where government administrations find resources for conflict resolution in short supply or of a biased nature.

This brings me to my last point for the moment, the question of peacekeeping. Again, the review is narrow and unimaginative in its approach to security problems. It places peacekeeping and the vague term of `peace support operations' within the direct defence of Australia. Surely the Department of Defence must realise that peacekeeping in the region is an exercise carried out long before the tensions or conflict reach the stage of threatening Australia's direct interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the implications of United States policies for Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Government Response to The Report of The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Implications of United States Policies for Australia
Introduction

The Government welcomed the Senate's decision on 16 September 1992 to direct the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to conduct an inquiry into the implications for Australia of United States policies in the context of the 1992 Presidential election campaign.

The Committee's Report was tabled in the Senate on 16 December 1992. Its terms of reference focused on key issues of concern to Australia, including the likely direction of US trade policy, US security policy in the Asia-Pacific region and the US/Japan relationship.

The Government welcomed the Committee's Report as a contribution to analysis and public debate on the likely directions of US policy under the new Clinton Administration. The Report, though based on hearings and testimony provided prior to the inauguration of President Clinton, remains relevant in its identification of key issues and their implications for Australia.

The Report's recommendations are consistent with, and build upon, the broad thrust of current policy. The Government's responses to each of the Committee's recommendations are included at the end of this report. Before addressing these recommendations in detail, it is appropriate to offer some broad judgements on the policy directions taken by the Clinton Administration and on their implications for Australia.

Australia and the United States have a substantial and wide ranging political, economic and security relationship. Linked by formal alliance for over forty years, both share a deep commitment to democracy, international security and an open world trading system.

The relationship today is undergoing a process of change. While defence and security ties remain strong, the end of the Cold War, and the growing importance to both countries of the Asia Pacific region, has seen a shift away from the previous emphasis on Western alliance and towards building on common interests in a closer engagement with Asia.

The accession to power in both countries of a new generation of political leaders from the post-World War II generation—and the advent of a Democratic Administration after twelve years of Republican control of the White House—further marks the onset of a new chapter in the relationship.
The Australian Government has moved quickly and effectively this year to ensure that Australian concerns and interests were signalled, clearly and early, to the new Administration and Congress.

The year so far has seen a succession of productive contacts, including numerous Ministerial meetings, the inaugural Trade and Investment Council meeting, a successful Parliamentary delegation visit, the Prime Minister's visit to the United States in September and his subsequent visit to attend the meeting of Economic Leaders of the Asia Pacific Cooperation Forum (APEC) in Seattle in November. These contacts have afforded Australia an excellent opportunity to impress upon the new Administration our concerns and interests.

The Administration has provided excellent access to Australian Ministers, members of Parliament and officials, and has shown itself to be receptive to Australian ideas. Senior Administration officials have recognised Australia as an important partner on a range of bilateral, regional and international issues.

The Prime Minister's discussions with President Clinton confirmed and gave renewed impetus to the traditional patterns of friendship and bilateral and international cooperation between our countries. At the same time, their discussions demonstrated that shared interests in the Asia Pacific region are now central to the relationship, with Australia's importance in regional affairs clearly acknowledged by the United States.In the Asia Pacific region, the Clinton Administration has emphasised that the United States intends to share in the development of a "New Pacific Community" to foster security, prosperity and democracy.

In his visit to Japan and Korea in July, President Clinton reaffirmed in the clearest possible terms the United States's security commitments in the region, both with respect to existing treaty ties—including with Australia—and also in terms of US support for new forms of multilateral security dialogue. The latter represents a significant step forward in US policy, and one that is fully consonant with Australian objectives.

The Administration has also made a strong commitment to APEC as the region's pre-eminent forum for economic cooperation. President Clinton's decision to convene a meeting in Seattle of APEC Leaders at the time of the Ministerial meeting was welcomed by Australia, the Prime Minister having proposed such meetings since January 1992. Again, during the Leaders meeting, the Administration made clear the value it attaches to Australia's contribution to the formation and development of APEC. The Leaders meeting was very successful in consolidating support for APEC and its future agenda and reaffirmed the importance of a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round.

The Clinton Administration's approach to trade policy has become clearer as the year unfolded. There has been a welcome reaffirmation of US commitment to an open multilateral trading system, including through an early and successful close to the Uruguay Round.

The Clinton Administration was successful in securing Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), despite strident opposition. This was seen as a litmus test of the direction of US trade policy: defeat for NAFTA would have been an indication that protectionist sentiment was becoming more influential.

NAFTA is likely to have mixed implications for Australia—on the one hand NAFTA will stimulate growth in North America and thus create additional trade and investment opportunities; on the other, NAFTA's rules of origin and local content provisions have the potential to divert trade and investment flows to the detriment of third countries.

Alongside its Uruguay Round and NAFTA commitments, the Administration has also placed the highest priority on pursuing a results-oriented trade policy and on reducing its trade deficits with major Asian trading partners, especially Japan. Again, the record is not yet complete enough to form a definitive judgement. Australia has registered very clearly with the USA that we are opposed to any form of managed trade or discriminatory bilateral arrangements.

On the bilateral trade front, we continue to have serious concern over a range of US actions and policies which either limit Australian access to the US market or damage our interests in third markets. The Government has put these to the Administration with persistence and vigour.

The Clinton Administration has acknowledged that Australian representations in regard to the bilateral trade imbalance—which is proportionally larger than the US imbalance with Japan—have some validity. The Administration has also agreed on the need to engage in substantive and serious dialogue on addressing mutual trade concerns, including through the Trade and Investment Council which met at Ministerial level for the first time in June this year.

President Clinton specifically acknowledged Australian concerns with regard to the Export Enhancement Program (EEP) in his joint press conference with Prime Minister Keating, giving assurances that his Administration would "go out of its way" to avoid conflict with Australia's trading interests. The Government is seeking to ensure that these assurances are fully reflected in the administration of the EEP.

Internationally, the Administration has placed non-proliferation concerns at the top of its agenda, an approach which Australia strongly supports. The Government also welcomes the steps the Administration has taken in extending its nuclear testing moratorium and its preparedness to commence negotiations for a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

The Administration is also strongly committed to reforming and strengthening the United Nations and its peacekeeping and collective security activities, objectives to which Australia too is strongly committed and where our credentials as a valued international partner are clearly recognised by the United States.

On balance, then, the policy directions of the new Administration contain much that is consonant with Australian interests. While our differences on some trade issues remain of serious concern, it is inevitable, in a relationship as substantial and broad-ranging as ours, that some differences will occur.

The Government has succeeded in establishing a sound and cordial relationship with the new Administration and looks forward to a positive and constructive dialogue to address mutual concerns and achieve progress on shared objectives, especially in the Asia Pacific region.
THE CLINTON ADMINISTRATION: POLICIES AND PRIORITIES
Foreign Policy Priorities

President Clinton is the first President of the post-Cold War era and faces the difficult challenge of giving new purpose and direction to US foreign policy now that the organising principle of the past four decades—containment and defeat of Soviet communism—is a thing of the past.

This will be no easy task. The monolith of the Soviet threat has been replaced by a mosaic of regional, ethnic and religious conflicts whose causes are complex and whose solutions elusive—and in which direct American interests may be hard to discern. Economic competition is gaining importance in world affairs, placing new stresses on Cold War alliances.

In addressing these challenges, President Clinton must also take account of the changed national mood in the United States. After fifty years of engagement and leadership against fascism and totalitarianism, the American public is now looking first and foremost to the home front—to domestic social and economic issues such as deficit reduction, health care reform and economic recovery—issues which President Clinton has also identified as key priorities.

President Clinton is firmly committed to continuing US engagement in world affairs, arguing that as a leading democracy, a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, the world's largest national economy and its only military superpower, the United States has vital interests and a fundamental obligation to remain actively engaged in world affairs.

In his first nine months in office, President Clinton has had to wrestle with a wide range of complex and difficult international problems, including Bosnia and Somalia. The Administration's handling of such issues has generated debate and controversy over the appropriate scope of US engagement and the extent to which US interests are at stake.

While these issues have tended to dominate public debate in America on President Clinton's foreign policy, the Administration can legitimately point also to issues where the United States has played a positive role, including support for reform in Russia, reactivating the Middle East peace process and assisting in the achievement of the historic agreement between Israel and the PLO.
From Australia's perspective, there have been a number of foreign policy developments under the Clinton Administration which accord with Australian interests and objectives.

The Administration's emphasis on closer engagement in the Asia Pacific region, which will be discussed in more detail below, is an important and welcome development at a time when Australia is integrating more closely with the region and when doubts existed over the level of US interest in the region.

President Clinton has also given priority to preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. While the end of the Cold War has greatly reduced the threat of strategic nuclear conflict, the threats posed by the spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons, and of the technologies for delivering them—especially through use of ballistic missiles—has emerged as a fundamental challenge to peace and stability in the post-Cold War world.

In his address to the United Nations General Assembly on 27 September 1993, President Clinton outlined his Administration's policies on curbing the spread of weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems. The Australian Government is at one with the United States in viewing this threat with the utmost concern.

Australia plays a significant role in the fields of arms control and non-proliferation, and has worked closely with the US and others to achieve major arms control objectives, most recently the successful negotiation of the Chemical Weapons Convention. We share strong support for the global nuclear non-proliferation regime, based on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) and for the nuclear safeguards system of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

The indications so far bear out the Committee's judgement (2.51-2.60) that a Clinton Administration will accelerate movement on a range of arms control issues. The Clinton Administration is maintaining the Bush Administration's policy of attaching the highest priority to ratification and implementation of the START agreements by Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan and their accession to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty as non-nuclear weapons states.

The Administration has extended the moratorium on nuclear testing embraced, with some reservations, by the Bush Administration last year and is fully supporting negotiation of a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. The indications are that the Administration is also developing a commendably broad-based approach in dealing with problems posed by the proliferation of exotic weaponry.

President Clinton has also given priority to enhancing the capacity of the multilateral system in addressing global problems, including through reforming and strengthening the United Nations in its capacity to meet the ever expanding demand for peace-keeping operations, and in reviewing the membership of the Security Council.

President Clinton has taken important initiatives on international environmental negotiations, including signing the Biodiversity Convention and adopting a more positive approach to the obligations of the Climate Change Convention.
THE ASIA-PACIFIC REGION
The Clinton Administration has articulated a broad policy framework for the region which contains much that accords with Australian policy.

The first major exposition of the Administration's Asia-Pacific policy framework came in the testimony of the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, Winston Lord, in his Senate confirmation hearing on 31 March. In July, President Clinton underscored US commitment to the Asia-Pacific region in major speeches in Japan and Korea—significantly, President Clinton's first overseas trip was to Asia. In November, President Clinton hosted in Seattle the inaugural meeting of the Economic Leaders of the APEC Forum—a very successful initiative which drew the Leaders of economies accounting for half the world's production.
