President Clinton and his senior officials have laid particular emphasis on the concept of a "New Pacific Community", reflecting the Administration's support for the growing sense of community among regional states, embracing firstly economic relations but also beginning, in various forums, to include political and security relations as well.

The United States has a major stake in the continued prosperity and security of the region. Forty per cent of US trade is now with this region, half as large again as American trade with Europe. As Asian economies enjoy some of the highest growth rates in the world, the United States economy has much to gain from participating fully in the expanding commercial ties with the region. The Australian Government strongly welcomes the Administration's commitment to participating in the evolution of a Pacific community of nations.
REGIONAL SECURITY

The Clinton Administration has strongly reaffirmed its existing bilateral security commitments, including to Australia through ANZUS, while also taking on a more active role in the development of a more broadly based dialogue among regional states on issues of common security concern.

In his speech before the Korean National Assembly on 10 July, President Clinton affirmed his Administration's commitment to regional security, including the importance attached to multilateral security forums.

Australia has been a leading player in fostering the development of regional security dialogues, which can make an important contribution in consolidating peace and security in the fluidity of the post-Cold War world. The multilateral dialogue is designed to complement and build upon the existing bilateral ties between the United States and selected regional states and to strengthen confidence and patterns of cooperation among regional states.

While the Bush Administration initially held some reservations about participating in multilateral security dialogues in the region, it subsequently began to show more enthusiasm for this approach. It is encouraging that the new Administration has moved quickly in committing itself to this process, which has centred upon the annual ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference (PMC), and will in future increasingly focus on the ASEAN Regional Forum, established during the last ASEAN PMC in Singapore from 26-28 July. The ASEAN Regional Forum includes, for the first time, China, Russia, Vietnam, Laos and Papua New Guinea in a new dialogue process.
It is a sign of US commitment to multilateral security dialogue that the US strongly supported the creation of this new and inclusive body.

The Clinton Administration played a key role in persuading North Korea to suspend its decision to withdraw from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. As a permanent member of the UN Security Council and as a leading force for countering proliferation, the United States will continue to have a major role to play in addressing this complex and serious problem.

While the Clinton Administration has reaffirmed its security interests and commitments in the region, it is nonetheless legitimate to ask whether the substantial defence cuts foreshadowed by the Administration will over time weaken the capacity of the United States to project power and deploy forces in the region.

The Government shares the judgement arrived at in the Committee's report, namely that in the short term at least, the nature and scope of US force reductions in the region should not diminish the ability of the United States to meet security demands and foreseeable contingencies (2.31). This has been confirmed in the Clinton Administration's "Bottom-Up Review" of US force structure released in September this year.

The United States has strongly reaffirmed its security commitments to Japan and Korea. In his visits to Japan and Korea in July, President Clinton reaffirmed in the clearest possible terms the US's commitment to its Asia-Pacific treaty partners (including Australia) and also reiterated the US intention to maintain its forward force deployments which continue to play a key role in regional stability.

The maintenance of strong US forward deployments in Japan and Korea is assisted by the generous levels of support provided by those countries as hosts to US forces and facilities. Japan meets around three quarters of the non-salary costs of US forces deployed there, amounting to over $3 billion per annum (and equivalent to about ten per cent of Japan's defence budget). Korea provides a similar level of support.
APEC

The Australian Government has played a leading role in the formation and evolution of APEC which has now established itself as the pre-eminent forum for economic cooperation in the region. It has also given impetus to efforts to free up world trade through the Uruguay Round and has made a start towards liberalising trade among its own members.

The Government fully shares the view expressed in the Committee report that the United States should be encouraged to continue to play an active role in APEC. It is therefore gratifying to observe that the Clinton Administration has signalled a very clear commitment to the APEC process and has elevated APEC to the forefront of its regional trade strategies. The United States held the chair of APEC in 1993, hosting the Ministerial meeting in Seattle in November and the inaugural meeting of the economic leaders of APEC, providing an excellent opportunity to reinforce United States commitment to the region.

Australia welcomed President Clinton's proposal to host a meeting of APEC leaders in Seattle in November 1993. The meeting resulted in support for the continued development of APEC as a forum dedicated to producing tangible economic benefits for the region. Leaders agreed to convene a meeting of Finance Ministers, establish a Pacific Business Forum, strengthen policy dialogue on small and medium sized businesses, establish an APEC education program and an APEC business volunteer program.

The Australian Government is strongly committed to pursuing a broadranging agenda of trade and investment facilitation through APEC and is also working closely with the Clinton Administration in this regard.

Through its Embassy in Washington, the Government has also sought to encourage Congressional interest in and awareness of APEC. The Chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Lee Hamilton, is among a number of members of Congress who are taking a keen interest in APEC.

There is clearly a role here for members of the Australian Parliament to reinforce with members of the United States Congress, through formal and informal links, the vital importance of APEC for the region, and to encourage an active, constructive and ongoing US role in APEC.
US/JAPAN RELATIONS

No relationship is more important for the security and prosperity of the region and for Australia than the US/Japan relationship. Together Japan and the United States provide nearly forty per cent of world output. Two-way trade is around US$140 billion. The US/Japan security relationship has played, and continues to play, a critical role in maintaining the stability and security of the region.

The relationship between the United States and Japan has particular significance for Australia. They are our two largest trading partners and the United States is our most important ally and treaty partner. Both are key players in the future of the region, for example through the roles they play in APEC and in regional security. Internationally, the policies of the United States, and increasingly those of Japan, materially affect issues of vital importance to Australia, ranging from the Uruguay Round, UN reform, peace-keeping, development assistance, and efforts to tackle transnational issues such as the environment.

The Clinton Administration has signalled clearly that it regards no relationship as more important than that with Japan. During the visit to the United States by Prime Minister Miyazawa in April, in President Clinton's visit to Tokyo in July, and in the meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Hosokawa in Seattle, both sides reaffirmed their commitment to the three key elements in the relationship—security ties, trade and global partnership.

On the first and third of these elements, the outlook remains positive. With respect to trade, the United States and Japan are again in a period of increased tension. Both sides will have to adopt a reasoned and balanced approach if these problems are to be handled in a manner which will avoid undercutting the Uruguay Round negotiations and the positive evolution of APEC and also avoid generating uncertainty over the regional economic outlook.

The Clinton Administration has said that in the post-Cold War period, the economic relationship with Japan has acquired an increased importance. The Administration, indeed, describes Japan as a special case, arguing that the size and persistence of the United States trade deficit with Japan is proof that Japanese economic practices and policies result in unfair limitations on US exports to Japan of goods and services.

The Administration is placing emphasis on a results-oriented approach, and during the Miyazawa visit it was agreed that a sectoral/structural agreement would be negotiated by the time of President Clinton's visit to Tokyo for the G-7 Summit in July.

The agreement, known as the US-Japan Framework for a New Economic Partnership, was announced in Tokyo on 10 July. The agreement is based on reciprocal macro-economic undertakings, with Japan agreeing to make "highly significant" reductions in its trade surplus and to boost imports, and the US promising to cut its budget surplus and work to improve its competitiveness.
In addition to these broad pledges, the Agreement identifies five areas where further sectoral or structural negotiations or consultations will be undertaken, with various timetables for completion.

The Framework Agreement leaves ample scope for differences of interpretation and implementation and there is no guarantee that it will lead to successful resolution of US-Japan trade frictions. Nevertheless, the Agreement is a positive development in that it provides a framework within which the world's and the region's pre-eminent economies can work constructively in addressing economic problems.

The Australian Government awaits a clearer picture of the sectoral/structural negotiations and their implementation arrangements. In discussions with both countries, the Government will continue to make clear its concern that in addressing bilateral problems there should be no resort to discriminatory managed trade.
US TRADE POLICY

The United States has been one of the pillars of the free trading system which has contributed so much to world growth since World War II. Continued American commitment to free trade and to GATT principles is imperative.

The advent of a Democratic Administration has given rise to concerns over the direction of US trade policy, since historically the Democrats have been seen as more inclined to protectionist or aggressive trade policies.
During its first year of the Clinton Administration has sent out some conflicting signals, creating uncertainty over the broad thrust of US trade policy.

On the one hand, the Administration has strongly reaffirmed its commitment to free trade principles. In his first major address on trade policy, President Clinton said at the American University on 26 February that the truth of our age is this—open and competitive commerce will enrich us as a nation. It spurs us to innovate. It forces us to compete . . . in the face of all the pressures to do the reverse, we must compete, not retreat.
No clearer affirmation of free trade could be wished for.

President Clinton has also stressed, including in his American University speech, that the United States must acknowledge that many of its deficiencies in competitiveness are "made in America" and can only be redressed by American efforts and not by shifting blame onto trading partners.

The Administration has also given priority to pursuing a successful conclusion to the already protracted Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations. The Administration introduced a bill in Congress on 27 April to extend fast track authority until 15 December and Congressional approval was completed on 30 June. President Clinton reaffirmed US commitment to a successful and balanced Uruguay Round outcome in his meeting with Prime Minister Keating in September.

Against this welcome reaffirmation of free trade and the rules-based GATT system, however, there are also more ambivalent signals. The Administration is placing great emphasis on achieving quick results in opening foreign markets and has signalled that it is prepared to use whatever methods seem necessary to achieve this, including unilateral ones. The danger here is that the Administration will resort to methods which will offer the illusion of short-term gain but at the risk of damaging bilateral and multilateral trading relationships in the longer term.

Senior Administration officials have indicated, for example, that they favour reviving the currently lapsed "Super 301" provisions of US trade legislation, which would allow the United States to identify countries it thought were maintaining unfair trading practices, and impose mandatory negotiations, and possibly unilateral sanctions, if the negotiations did not meet US goals. Legislation of this kind also has strong supporters in Congress.

The Administration has also signalled, particularly with regard to Japan, a results-oriented approach that involves sector-specific identification of appropriate criteria for assessing the level of access for American goods and services. While the Administration denies that this approach is tantamount to "managed trade", there are certainly grounds for concern that this might be the ultimate outcome.

The Australian Government is concerned that widespread resort to unilateralism or managed trade along these lines by the United States would have a profoundly unsettling and negative effect, particularly in our region where some of the largest US trade deficits exist. If countries like Japan are required to tailor access to their markets to satisfy US demands, third parties are likely to be disadvantaged.

Senior members of the Administration, including the President, have said that they regard distinctions between unilateral, bilateral, regional and multilateral approaches as a "distracting debate" and have emphasised that it is results that count.

The emphasis on a results-oriented trade policy, though more explicit than that enunciated by the Bush or Reagan Administrations, is a continuation of a shift in emphasis in US trade policy that first emerged in the early 1980s. In its multi-stranded trade policy the United States began to focus more attention on bilateral agreements and vigorous pursuit of unilateral action, in addition to its support for the GATT.

This change in emphasis was reflected in negotiation of bilateral free trade agreements with Israel (1985) and Canada (1988) and the trilateral NAFTA agreement signed with Mexico and Canada in 1992. Congress also passed amended trade laws (including the so-called "Special 301" and "Super 301") that either required or provided scope for the Administration to apply unilateral sanctions more widely.

The Australian Government accepts that a range of different trade policy approaches may be pursued simultaneously. What is essential, however, is that the various instruments being used should all be consistent with rules-based GATT principles. Unilateralism and multilateralism are not simply two of a range of equally valid alternative trade strategies, and the US Administration needs to address this squarely and make clearer to its trading partners that it remains committed to the rules-based GATT principles which have served the world, and the United States, so well for the last four decades.
NAFTA
The Committee report devoted considerable attention to the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), signed by Presidents Bush and Salinas, and Prime Minister Mulroney, on 17 December 1992.

Following intensive lobbying and public debate, legislation to implement NAFTA was passed by the US House of Representatives on 17 November and the US Senate on 20 November. The agreement will come into effect from 1 January 1994 following ratification by the Mexican Senate on 22 November and proclamation of Canada's legislation—the new Canadian government sought reassurance from the USA on some issues before doing so.

The US Administration was successful in securing the necessary Congressional votes, but only after making the issue a critical one for the future of the Clinton presidency. This, plus the Administration's concerted lobbying campaign and willingness to bargain for votes, proved sufficient to overcome the concerns of Congressional representatives about job losses, reductions in US workers' rights and environmental standards and a prominent campaign by former Presidential candidate Ross Perot, high ranking Democrats in Congress and the US trade union movement. The vote on NAFTA was seen by many international observers as a litmus test of the strength of protectionist and isolationist sentiment in the USA.

The implications of NAFTA for Australia and other countries in the Asia-Pacific region appear likely to be mixed. On the one hand, NAFTA is likely to stimulate growth throughout the large North American market (370 million people), increasing opportunities for trade and investment there. On the other there is the potential for trade and investment diversion which would affect Australia and other countries in the Asia Pacific region.

For Australia, the direct trade and investment effects of NAFTA are in general not expected to be great, but there are potentially serious implications for our exports of meat, sugar and dairy products.

Many of Australia's exports to the USA, including meat, steel, sugar and dairy products, and some to Canada (beef) are subject to restrictions imposed by the US or Canadian governments. NAFTA will not alter any of these restrictions.

The indirect effects (i.e. on our trade and investment in third countries) are likely to be more significant for Australia than the direct effects in the longer term. In particular, the stringent local content and rules of origin provisions of NAFTA (a surrogate industry policy) are likely in effect to raise trade barriers for third countries and thus cause trade diversion. The local content provisions appear likely to have a particularly strong effect on some major sectors of interest to Asian producers, including textiles, autos and auto parts, with possible flow-on effects for Australian inputs into those exports (e.g. coal, iron ore, wool, and automotive components).

NAFTA may also have both beneficial and adverse effects on the international trading system. NAFTA establishes high standards in a number of areas which will establish important precedents for future trade agreements, including the GATT.

However, there would be concern if NAFTA were to encourage the proliferation of preferential (and therefore discriminatory) trade agreements or the division of the world into a few trading blocs, and reduce support for the liberal, multilateral trading system. This would be exacerbated if NAFTA were to form the basis of `hub and spokes' arrangements (i.e. one where the hub—e.g. the USA—has different agreements with the spokes, which do not have similar agreements among themselves).

A key issue for the future will be expansion of NAFTA. The US implementing legislation requires the President to report to Congress on or before 1 July 1994 and again before 1 July 1997 with recommendations for free trade negotiations with countries nominated by the President. These countries are required already to be providing access for US goods and investment beyond that required under the GATT or to offer significant opportunities for US trade and investment.

Expansion of NAFTA would be likely to have a greater effect on Australia as some Latin American countries such as Chile (which is expected to be the first country to join an expanded NAFTA) are competitors for Australian exports to North America in a larger range of goods and services.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is completing a study which analyses the implications of NAFTA for Australia's current main exports to North America. The study is expected to be released publicly in the near future.
SCHEDULE OF RECOMMENDATIONS AND RESPONSES

5.16 Recommendation one: The Committee recommends that the Prime Minister of Australia make a visit to the United States as early in the new presidency as possible and that an early invitation be extended to President Clinton to visit Australia. One purpose of these visits should be to inform the President of the importance Australia attaches to the continuing engagement of the United States in the Asia-Pacific region.
The Government endorses the Committee's view on the importance of high-level contacts to ensure that Australian perspectives on the Asia-Pacific region are clearly understood in Washington.

The Prime Minister conducted a highly successful visit to the United States from 12-16 September 1993, holding discussions with President Clinton and senior members of his Administration including Secretary of State Christopher, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bensten, Defense Secretary Les Aspin, United States Trade Representative Mickey Kantor and the Director of Central Intelligence James Woolsey. Mr Keating also met senior Congressional leaders from both parties.

The Prime Minister's visit was successful in establishing a close working relationship with President Clinton. Their discussions reaffirmed the longstanding patterns of cooperation between the two countries, and gave clear expression to the interests we share in working together in the Asia Pacific region to strengthen and expand economic, political and security links and in achieving a successful and balanced outcome to the Uruguay Round.

The Prime Minister met President Clinton again in Seattle in November. Their discussions highlighted a mutual vision for regional economic cooperation. The Prime Minister also conveyed Australia's interest in a visit to Australia by the President at a mutually convenient time.

Ministerial contacts are also a key element in Australia's pursuit of its interests in the relationship. The Australia/United States Ministerial Talks (AUSMIN), in which Australia is represented by the Foreign and Defence Ministers and the United States by the Secretaries of State and Defense, take place about every twelve months and provide a highly effective forum for discussion of bilateral, regional and international issues of mutual concern.

Ausmin Talks were scheduled to take place in Australia at the end of July but had to be deferred until early 1994 when Secretary of State Christopher was recalled to Washington by President Clinton for urgent consultations on the Middle East and Bosnia.

There have already been numerous Ministerial contacts with the Clinton Administration this year. The then Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, and the then Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr Kerin, visited Washington in January and February. Soon after the Australian general election, the Foreign Minister Senator Evans visited Washington, and he has met with Secretary of State Christopher on several occasions subsequently.

The Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, visited the United States in June 1993 where he met with five key Cabinet members and held the inaugural Ministerial talks under the Australia/US Trade and Investment Framework Arrangement (TIFA). Senator Cook's visit was important not only in terms of the bilateral trade relationship but more broadly in terms of underlining and cementing support for APEC.

Senator Evans and Senator Cook also attended the APEC Ministerial meeting (APEC V) in Seattle in November which dealt, in a forward looking way, with APEC's longer term goals, its mechanisms and work programs, particularly through the Eminent Persons Group Report and the endorsement of a permanent Committee on Trade and Investment (CTI).

Other Ministerial visits include those by the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories Ms Kelly, the Treasurer Mr Dawkins, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy Mr Crean, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training Mr Beazley, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Arts and Administrative Services Senator McMullan and the Minister for Social Security Mr Baldwin.

There is also an important role for the Australian Parliament to play in fostering American understanding of Australian policies and interests. A Parliamentary delegation under the leadership of the Speaker Mr Martin completed a highly successful visit the United States in June, which included a meeting with Vice President Gore and the Congressional leadership.

Through Ministerial contacts and through other channels, the Australian Government is well placed to impress upon the Clinton Administration the importance of the United States developing a coherent policy framework towards the Asia-Pacific region and applying that framework in a consistent fashion.

5.18 Recommendation two: The Committee recommends that the Government give a high priority to reviewing possible ways of drawing the United States into multilateral dialogue on security issues in the Asia-Pacific region.

The Government strongly endorses this recommendation, which is consistent with the Government's established policy of fostering multilateral security dialogue in the region and of encouraging a constructive US engagement in that process.

Under the Bush Administration, the Government sought to allay US concerns about multilateral dialogue by arguing that multilateral forums would complement and support, rather than challenge, the existing network of largely bilateral security arrangements in the region which mostly involve the United States.

The Government strongly welcomes the shift in policy under the Clinton Administration, which has become an active and fully committed partner in the broadening of the regional security dialogue including through creation of the ASEAN Regional Forum. There is now a wide area of agreement between Australia and the United States on the question of multilateral security dialogue in the region and we look forward to further close cooperation with the Administration in this important area.
5.21 Recommendation three: The Committee recommends that the Australian government continue to pursue a threefold strategy of:
.encouraging United States commitment to multilateral free trade;
.drawing the United States as fully as possible into the economic networks of the Asia Pacific region; and
.identifying the most effective means available to ameliorate the bilateral and other trade problems between the United States and Australia.

In the light of the change in leadership in the United States, the Committee recommends that there be an increase in the effort devoted over the next twelve month period to achieving these objectives, particularly with regard to the second and third objectives.
The Government supports this recommendation, which is consistent with strategies already being pursued by the Government.
Recommendation 3.1

It has been the established policy of this Government to encourage United States commitment to upholding and strengthening an open multilateral trading system, including giving the highest priority to the GATT and to early and successful completion of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations.

The indications so far are that the Clinton Administration will maintain a policy of strong support for the multilateral system. President Clinton and the US Congress are committed to early completion of the Uruguay Round through legislation extending the Administration's "fast-track" negotiating authority until 15 December 1993. The President's commitment was reaffirmed in his meeting with the Prime Minister in September and at APEC.

The Australian Government considers that the extension of fast track to mid-December provides a credible time-frame for conclusion of the negotiations, while maintaining a sense of discipline and urgency. The Government welcomes the fact that fast track extension was not encumbered with conditions, such as renewal of "Super 301" or similar unilateral trade measures.

Beyond this broad commitment to free trade principles, however, the future direction of US trade policy remains uncertain. The signals emerging from the Administration thus far have been somewhat mixed, giving rise to some concern among trading partners over the likely evolution of US trade policy.

In a major speech at the American University on 26 February, President Clinton strongly endorsed free trade. Saying that the United States must compete, not retreat, he acknowledged that many of America's economic problems were "made in America" and should not be blamed on trading partners.

In the same speech, however, the President said that American trade policy would bypass what he described as "distracting debate" over whether efforts should be multilateral, regional, bilateral or unilateral. This is a view being echoed by other senior figures in the Administration, including US Trade Representative Mickey Kantor and Commerce Secretary Ron Brown.

The Australian Government accepts that a flexible approach to trade policy mechanisms is appropriate and that bilateral, regional and multilateral initiatives are not mutually exclusive. It is vitally important, however, that whatever trade strategies the United States chooses to employ should be fully consistent with its international obligations and with rules-based GATT principles.
Recommendation 3.2

With regard to the second part of the recommendation, the real issue is perhaps not so much drawing the United States into the economic networks of the region, as it is ensuring that the United States's economic relations with the region develop along cooperative rather than confrontational lines.

The United States is already a major player in the region's economic dynamism. Forty per cent of its trade is with the region, half as much again as US trade with Europe: only a decade ago these trade flows were about equal. The United States is an active member of APEC and closely engaged with ASEAN through the dialogue relationship. The United States has reacted strongly to any suggestions that it might be left out of regional economic arrangements.

The United States continues to play a strong and constructive role in APEC and held the APEC chair in 1993, passing it to Indonesia at the Ministerial meeting held in Seattle in November. This meeting, the fifth APEC Ministerial meeting, was followed by an inaugural meeting of the leaders of APEC economies. Australia welcomed the US proposal to host the leaders meeting which was attended by fourteen APEC member economic leaders.

Australia and the United States have been working together constructively with other APEC members to expand APEC's regional trade and investment agenda. The Seattle meetings endorsed a Trade and Investment Framework which established a permanent Committee on Trade and Investment and approved a solid work program with initial focus on trade facilitation.

A key aspect of the framework has been to identify the goal of creating an open, integrated market in the Asia-Pacific. The framework has also provided the vehicle for a medium to long term work program designed to expand opportunities for, and address the impediments to, greater regional integration as enunciated by the Prime Minister earlier this year. These initiatives build on the important progress made in the former informal APEC Group on Regional Trade Liberalisation (RTL) and the ten APEC Working Groups.
Recommendation 3.3
With regard to amelioration of bilateral trade problems, the Government has been pursuing an active role in seeking solutions to what are admittedly longstanding difficulties.

An important element in the Government's strategy has been the establishment of appropriate channels through which Australia can convey its concerns and pursue its interests with the United States Government.

Australia and the United States agreed in December 1992 to establish a Trade and Investment Framework Arrangement (TIFA) as a high-level forum for addressing trade and investment issues. Under the TIFA, a Trade and Investment Council is to meet approximately annually at Ministerial level. Australia is represented by the Minister for Trade and the United States by the US Trade Representative.

The initial TIFA Council meeting was held on 9-10 June in Washington, with the Minister for Trade Senator Cook representing Australia. The Government was pleased with the positive discussions at the initial TIFA meeting and will make every effort to ensure that the TIFA becomes an effective forum for protecting and promoting Australian interests in the trade and investment relationship.
With regard to agricultural trade, the Government is pursuing a range of initiatives as part of an interrelated strategy.

In 1991 the Government, through the Joint Parliamentary Delegation led by Dr Blewett, proposed to the United States the establishment of a consultative mechanism on agricultural trade issues. Following United States agreement, the first round of talks, at senior officials level, was held in August 1991. The fourth round of talks was held in Washington on 26-27 May.

The Government considers that these consultations have been helpful in giving Australia a forum for full and frank discussion of our concerns. The advent of a new Administration in Washington adds to the importance of using these consultations to register our concerns in an effective fashion.

In the shorter term, our efforts are directed to getting the United States to administer its current laws in a manner which increases market access for our exports to the United States (for example for meat, sugar and dairy products) and which minimises the impact of US export subsidies (for example the Export Enhancement Program or EEP, the Dairy Export Incentive Program or DEIP and the cotton program).

In seeking to limit the damage caused by current US programs, the Government works closely with Australian industries to identify pressure points and develop effective strategies to pursue with the US Administration. Australian representations have had some effect, albeit at the margin, in that the 1993-94 EEP and DEIP programs have not been extended to key Asian markets of most concern to Australia.

Senior Administration officials have acknowledged that Australian representations have had some influence on the final shape of their agricultural export programs this year. Some Administration officials also acknowledge that US policies and actions damage Australian interests. Winston Lord, for example, readily acknowledged in an interview on 18 August that "there are areas here that are somewhat less than free trade in the US regime and it does seem to hit Australia more than other countries. Australia has a major deficit with us".

During the Prime Minister's visit to Washington in September, President Clinton acknowledged Australia's standing as an agricultural free trader and gave assurances his Administration would "go out of its way" to implement the EEP in such a way as to avoid damage to Australian trade interests.

While these statements are a welcome indication that Australia's voice is indeed heard in Washington, there are no grounds for complacency. Concerted and sustained Australian pressure, through official and private sector contacts, will be required to ensure that assurances given are carried through.

In the longer term, we need to seek fundamental reform of currently mandated US agriculture programs, especially the Food, Agriculture, Conservation and Trade Act of 1990 (usually referred to as the Farm Act) and the Meat Import Law (MIL).

The stated commitment of the Clinton Administration to improve US competitiveness and reduce the Federal budget deficit, as well as the Congressional process for renewal of the Farm Act in 1995, provide a focus for seeking amendment to US farm policies and legislation which adversely affect Australia.

The elevated priority being given to reducing the Federal budget deficit may lead to a more rational allocation of resources under the next Farm Act. In the lead up to the 1990 farm legislation, efforts were made, including by consumer advocates and proponents of fiscal responsibility, to highlight the costs to the wider US community of farm programs which in some instances had their origins decades ago in entirely different circumstances. One of our priorities over the next two years will be to seek to influence debate within the US about the domestic and international impact of US agricultural policies in the lead-up to the 1995 Farm Bill.

5.24 Recommendation four: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government pay particular attention to identifying United States' self-interests, and how they may coincide with Australian interests, in any trade proposals or representations we make, both bilaterally and in APEC, and ensuring that the matters identified are widely known within the United States, particularly by potential allies within the United States.
It is an established element in Australian trade policy to make use of strategic alliances and coalitions with specific interest groups in the United States.

A strategy of this kind, of course, needs to be handled with sensitivity. There are occasions when interest groups in the United States are happy to have the support of foreign corporations or governments in their efforts to influence US policy or laws; equally there are going to be occasions when a highly visible campaign by a foreign government or industry might be seen as inappropriate or counterproductive.

There is considerable sensitivity in the United States in relation to the activities of lobbyists on behalf of foreign interests, particularly where former Administration officials are concerned. This sensitivity has been reflected in the formulation by the Clinton Administration of a new code of conduct for Administration officials, with a specific focus on limiting the scope for officials working on behalf of foreign interests soon after leaving office.

There is a wide-ranging debate in the United States—within the Administration, within the Congress, within the private sector, and within universities and think tanks—on what sort of trade strategies the United States should pursue. A key element in Australia's strategy is to impress upon the United States the costs and risks entailed in pursuing trade strategies which rely on unilateral or coercive methods or which involve managed trade, and to stress the benefits of maintaining an open multilateral trading system.

APEC also addresses the concerns underlying this recommendation in a number of ways, particularly the interests of all Asia-Pacific players (including the US) in fostering a healthy economic climate. Through its advocacy of the principle of open regionalism, APEC recognises the fact that the key to continued growth of Asia Pacific economies lies in promoting an open liberal trade environment which places emphasis on a cooperative trans-Pacific environment rather than one characterised by confrontation and bilateral disputation. As the Minister for Trade Senator Cook said to the Malaysia-Australia Business Council in Kuala Lumpur on 26 April :
We equally believe that in an environment of possible trade tension between the United States and Japan or other East Asian economies that APEC could be of great value.

The strong commitment of the Clinton Administration and the US Congress to deficit reduction is also a factor that should favour a more rational approach to resource allocation and may help rein in domestic programs and export subsidies that distort the market, penalise US consumers and hinder the overall competitiveness of the US economy.

5.25 Recommendation five: The Committee recommends that the existing programs of exchange of visitors between Australia and the United States be intensified. In particular the Committee recommends that the major emphasis be placed on identifying well informed Australian experts, both government and non government, in the fields of most concern to us.

The Government maintains a range of visitor and exchange programs which include the United States. The Special Visits Program (SVP) and the Visit Australia Program (VAP) have brought a range of influential United States personalities to Australia in recent years.

The main purpose of the SVP is to build an understanding of Australia and its place in the world through visits to Australia by individuals who are eminent in their fields and are in a position to contribute to greater awareness of Australian policies and concerns.

Prominent Americans to visit Australia in recent years under the SVP include Dean Kleckner, President of the American Farm Bureau Federation; Laverne Hubert, Legislative Director of the House of Representatives Committee on Agriculture; Charles Riemenschneider, Chief of Staff of the Senate Agriculture Committee and Gerald Curtis, Professor of Political Science and Director of the East Asian Institute at Columbia University.
It will be clear from the above that Australia's agriculture and trade interests, as well as our Asia-Pacific priorities, figure prominently in our criteria for the SVP.

Significant recent visitors under the VAP include Dr Fred Bergsten, who visited Australia in 1991. Dr Bergsten has had a distinguished career in international economics, serving as Director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington DC. Dr Bergsten has been appointed as the US representative to the APEC Eminent Persons Group of which he acts as Chairman.

Also worth noting was a visit in May this year by six influential US agricultural reporters. The group made an extensive tour of Australian farming districts and met a range of Government and private sector contacts, including the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the National Farmers Federation as well as visiting farms and rural areas. The visit has resulted in a number of media reports, including in the influential US Farm Report, favourably portraying the Australian farming sector and acknowledging the damage done to Australian farmers by US trade policies.

Another significant public affairs success this year was a series of six live two-hour broadcasts from Australia of the Good Morning America program. Subjects included tourism, multiculturalism, the political system, Aboriginal culture and the medical system. An interview with the Prime Minister was also broadcast. The programs generated keen interest in the USA with a surge of tourism enquiries.

The Department of Defence also actively encourages an exchange of visitors between Australia and the United States, including senior US Defence officials, members of Congress, academics and representatives from US services and service colleges. In 1992 there were 59 VIP visits to Australia including a visit by Secretary of Defense Richard Cheney for the fiftieth anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea. Thirteen senior Australian Defence officials visited the United States last year, including the Minister for Defence and the Chief of the Defence Force.

Programs of this kind clearly have an important role to play. An intensification of such programs with respect to the United States, as advocated by the Committee, has obvious resource implications and also raises questions over the relative priority to be attached to visits from the United States as compared to visits from other countries. The key to the success of these programs is to ensure that the selection of candidates is well targeted in accordance with Australian priorities and that the visitors' programs are thoughtfully prepared so as to maximise the benefit to Australia.

5.26 Recommendation six: The Committee recommends that an in depth study be undertaken to identify the costs to the United States economy overall, and the costs to particular sectors, of the continuation of the United States agricultural subsidy program and other forms of protection of domestic agricultural producers. This study should seek to identify specific interest groups whose interests would most coincide with Australian interests in seeing an end to these subsidies, for example those who bear the cost of these subsidies, and forming strategic alliances with these groups.

The Government acknowledges the value of studies of the kind identified in this recommendation. Indeed, much work has been done, both in United States and elsewhere, on such issues. Some of this work was referred to in evidence before the Committee by the Director of the Centre for International Economics, Dr Andrew Stoeckel (Committee Hansard page 510, 511), who also provided to the Committee a copy of the book "Macroeconomic Consequences of Farm Support Policies", published in 1989 and edited by Stoeckel, Vincent and Cuthbertson.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) also produced a major analysis on the impact of US grains policies in 1989 and is currently doing further work on the effects of the Export Enhancement Program—an ABARE Issues Paper on this subject was published in the June 1993 issue of the Agricultural and Resources Quarterly.

The Government recognises there may be merit in further studies of this kind. Given the volume of already published material, any additional work which the Government might commission would need to be carefully considered in the light of existing research and in the context of an overall strategy for pursuing our agricultural trade objectives with the United States.

The Government shares the Committee's concern to ensure that these important issues receive greater exposure in the public domain to maximise the impact on US policy makers. This is particularly important given that comprehensive farm legislation will again be considered in 1995 against a background of mounting concern over the size of the US budget deficit.

The Government supports the Committee's proposal concerning formation of strategic alliances with interest groups whose interests coincide with ours. This is already an established element in Government strategy, but there is always scope to refine and expand our activities. We should seek not just to work with traditional allies, but also to identify others, such as environmental or welfare groups whose interests may also be affected adversely by the misallocation of resources through certain farm support programs.

Australian industry also has important contacts in the United States and these linkages also contribute to the formation of strategic alliances and coalitions. Some Australian industry groups have embarked on programs to seek to identify and to energise US partners and associated interests to develop a US constituency for the trade relationship.

At the research level, good linkages already exist between ABARE and US agencies and organisations undertaking research into agricultural economics. There may be scope for developing these linkages further.
5.28 Recommendation seven: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government continue to make every effort to promote the rapid achievement of concrete trade liberalising outcomes through APEC.

This recommendation is fully consistent with Government policy and the Government welcomes the role which the Committee has played in helping to focus attention on APEC as the preeminent forum for economic cooperation in the region.

APEC lies at the heart of the Government's strategic approach for Australia's integration into the economic dynamism of the Asia-Pacific region. One of the Government's primary objectives for APEC has been to develop a substantial trade policy agenda, in terms of both an effective policy dialogue and measures to liberalise trade in the region.

Regional trade liberalisation will continue to be the major focus of APEC in 1994 and beyond. The work program agreed by Ministers in Seattle will be considered by the new Committee on Trade and Investment at its first meeting in Jakarta in January 1994.

The APEC work program comprises a forward-looking agenda of trade and investment measures including on investment, non-tariff measures, standards and conformance, tariff database, customs as well as a post-Uruguay Round review, measures from the Eminent Persons Group Report and work on small and medium enterprises in the region. This work program embraces a number of ideas advanced by the Prime Minister including on investment, standards and conformance and customs measures.

Ministers in Seattle also endorsed the thrust of the report by the APEC Eminent Persons Group. The EPG has been mandated to elaborate further on aspects of its long term vision over the course of 1994 and report again to Ministers in Indonesia next year.

5.29 Recommendation eight: The Committee recommends that Australia seeks to encourage the further development of APEC as an important tool in reducing the risk of fracture in economic relationships across the Pacific. One specific measure should be the early inclusion of Mexico and Chile in APEC.

The Government fully supports the main thrust of this recommendation with respect to developing APEC as a forum for cooperation and partnership in the region, and as a mechanism for containing and reducing the potential for confrontation and division.

In principle, participation in APEC is open to economies in the Asia Pacific region which have strong regional links and are firmly committed to its objectives. Decisions on the expansion of membership in APEC are taken by consensus.

The APEC Ministerial meeting in Seattle in November agreed that the expansion of membership should not, however, detract from the development of a strong policy focus, particularly on major trade and investment issues. At APEC's current stage of development there is significant merit in placing emphasis on `deepening' the APEC process rather than on `broadening' it too hastily.

APEC members agreed in Seattle to the immediate membership of Papua New Guinea and Mexico, with Chile to join at the Ministerial meeting in November 1994, followed by a three year moratorium on membership to allow APEC to consolidate.

5.30 Recommendation nine: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government include in its ongoing dialogue with Japan and China, particularly at the ministerial level, the impact of unilateral trade measures on the region's economic performance. Furthermore, the Committee recommends that the Australian Government lend its good offices to assist the United States, China and Japan avoid any dislocation of the current positive elements of their security and economic relations.

The Australian Government has well established mechanisms for regular Ministerial contact with the Governments of Japan, China and the United States. Discussion of trade policy issues plays a major role in our high-level consultations with all three. The Government will continue to use all channels available to it, at bilateral, regional and multilateral levels, to promote the advantages of open, rules-based trading arrangements and cooperative rather than confrontational trade strategies.

Over recent years, Australia has been successful in raising the level of our dialogue with Japan to a level similar to that we have with our other most important partners. In addition to frequent Ministerial and senior officials' exchanges, the Australia-Japan Ministerial Committee (AJMC), the most significant forum to facilitate dialogue on Australia's relations with Japan, provides a regular opportunity to canvass bilateral issues at the highest levels. The impact of unilateral trade measures and Australia's concern about managed trading arrangements have been included in these discussions.

At the High Level Consultations on Asia-Pacific Cooperation, held in Canberra in February this year, regional economic integration and the implications of regional trading arrangements were discussed in detail. Australia and Japan agreed at those consultations to share the results of studies currently being undertaken into the impact of regional trading arrangements and Japan has welcomed Australia's interest in expanding dialogue on these issues.

It has been the position of the Australian Government since the early 1980's that Japan should, within domestic and regional constraints and within the context of Japan-United States security arrangements, take on a greater share of the burden of defending itself and contribute to regional security interests.

The fact that Japan (and also Korea) bear a large share of the costs of forward deployment of US forces should help insulate these deployments to some extent from the pressures to reduce defence spending. Japan contributes around 75 per cent of the non-salary costs of the US forces stationed there (over US$3 billion, equivalent to about 10 per cent of Japan's defence budget), by far the highest contribution of any host nation for US overseas forces.

The Government has consistently emphasised to Japanese and American interlocutors Australia's concern that the resolution of any tensions in Japan-United States bilateral relations take account of the totality of the relationship, including the crucial security dimension. The Government has also stressed the vital importance that Australia attaches to the maintenance of sound and constructive relations between Japan and the United States as a key element in global stability and economic prosperity. Australia has also sought to encourage Japan to take on a greater share of international responsibilities more commensurate with its economic strength.

Part of Australia's high-level policy dialogue with the United States is to argue for unconditional MFN status for Chinese imports. Withdrawal of MFN would have an adverse impact on economic reform in China and countries in the region, particularly Hong Kong. Australia's own MFN Trade Agreement with the People's Republic of China should ensure that trade concessions gained by the United States automatically flow to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government response tabled today is a substantial one. It reflects the government's very positive welcome to the Senate's work through the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and its study of the United States election debate a little over a year ago. As one of the senators who contributed substantially to this original report, I take this opportunity to make some comments on the government's response. It was written one year after the original Senate report. The government normally responds within six months to any report of a Senate standing committee. In this case there are probably two reasons why it did not report in that time, although they are not alluded to in the remarks of the government that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner) has just incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, we had an election in March 1993. Effectively, this put us back six months in terms of the government's responding to Senate committee reports. Secondly, there is the quite substantial series of visits that were made by ministers of the government and, indeed, of the parliamentary delegation led by the Speaker. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) visited in September and November 1993. Given three or four of the matters I wish to raise, it certainly seems convenient and timely for the government to make this response after those visits and, in particular, after the Seattle meeting of ministers representing APEC nations in November last year.As I will show, some of the matters which the government needed to respond to were more maturely put in December of last year than the government would have been able to put had it responded earlier than the APEC meeting.
I start by referring to the statement that the government has made in its introduction to the statement tabled today. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government welcomed the Committee's report as a contribution to analysis and public debate on the likely directions of US policy under the new Clinton Administration. The Report, though based on hearings and testimony provided prior to the inauguration of President Clinton, remains relevant in its identification of key issues and their implications for Australia.

In `governmentspeak', that is about as praiseworthy as any government would be towards the work of a Senate committee. It shows that the government values this report of the Senate and has warmly and positively responded to its conclusions and recommendations.

PARA.TAB: There are nine recommendations in the Senate's report. They touch upon the likely direction of US trade policy, US security policy in the Asia-Pacific region, the US-Japan relationship and the US-China relationship. The common thread through it all for us in our inquiry was the implications of these developments within the United States for Australia. The Australian Senate wanted to look at the debate occurring in the months leading up to the presidential election in the United States to see what references were being made to the Asia-Pacific region, what implications from these references there are for Australia, and what steps we ought to take to ensure that our voice is heard and our interests are understood, and that we do not see any deterioration in the United States' positive engagement in our region.

Most of the Senate report was written prior to the election. It looked very seriously at the speeches that were made by the candidates, President Bush, Governor Clinton and Mr Perot. Two basic concerns undergirded our view of the presidential debate. Firstly, with the end of the Cold War, would the United States become more isolationist? Would the disposition of US security engagement in the region change purely as a result of the less pressing circumstances, the Cold War being over? The second concern was the very considerable domestic economic concerns of the US people as reflected in the priorities given in the debates by Governor Clinton and, indeed, his quite explicit first priorities of prosperity, employment and improvement of the economy of the United States.

A third area of concern was that with what we felt would be the likely success of Governor Clinton, we would have a person who did not have a marked track record of personal involvement in the Asia-Pacific region—Japan, China or Australia—to the extent that had been the case with the much older generation of Presidents Bush, Reagan, Carter, all the way back for some 30 or 40 years. It was this concern that there might be some lapse of the quite considerable US priorities in our region that we wished to address. We analysed the debate in the US, looked at the implications for our region, and came up with various conclusions and these nine recommendations.

The government of Australia has responded very positively to most of those nine recommendations. However, it has made a subdued or even lacklustre response to two or three of them, and it is those that I now wish to refer to. I, of course, welcome the government's acceptance of the great bulk of the committee's findings. The committee's report represents a bipartisan view about the importance of the United States continuing to have a positive role in security and trade in our region and to give full attention to the interests of Australia.

The areas of Australian government response that I find inadequate, to some extent, relate to EEP trade subsidies, particularly for wheat, which the United States has so unfairly followed for many years now and which have led to the united protests of every part of the Australian parliament, not least from my colleagues in the Liberal-National parties. I do not wish to be in competition with the government on this matter but I do not find in the government's response—for instance on page 4—the kind of urgency and priority that is shown in the government's track record in recent years in putting the view squarely to the United States that the United States has not lived up to its promises to consult with us and to ensure that its EEP does not harm Australia. When such action does, by various escalations, harm Australia, the response of the United States to our protests has been that it was unintended—`It's not aimed at our good friend Australia'. Although Australia continues to protest, I do not find the appropriate decibels in the following words on page 4:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has registered very clearly with the USA that we are opposed to any form of managed trade or discriminatory bilateral arrangements.

In the paragraphs that follow, whilst rightly opposing managed trade on the part of the United States, I believe we ought to be much more emphatic and consistent in the bipartisan and united approach of the government and the opposition by insisting that there be a definable end to the United States subsidy on wheat and other elements of EEP.

PARA.TAB: On page 5 there is what could be described as almost a set of excuses. The government of Australia has these words:

SPEECH.PARA: On balance, then, the policy directions of the new Administration—
talking about President Clinton's now-established government throughout 1993—

contain much that is consonant with Australian interests. While our differences on some trade issues remain of serious concern, it is inevitable, in a relationship as substantial and broadranging as ours, that some differences will occur.

Those words could be taken literally as reinforcing our close alliance with the United States; but they do not have the right number of decibels about our very serious concern about some trade issues that discriminate against Australia.

PARA.TAB: The second issue concerns what we in the committee proposed, in part, to do about that. Our recommendations 4 and 6 speak about Australia identifying specific US interest groups which are also harmed by EEP, the subsidies program. The recommendations suggest that we should be pointing out to those interests in the United States that they ought to hear our analysis of this discrimination and ensure that we work together in putting forward the arguments that Australia puts internationally—arguments which these allied interests within the United States could put domestically. The government's response is:

SPEECH.PARA: A strategy of this kind, of course, needs to be handled with sensitivity.

That is Australian Public Service speak for, `We're not going to do this. We wouldn't want to tread on any toes in being so specific in lobbying for Australia's objectives'. I do not think I have this out of context. I ask the government to think about this again and implement the committee's recommendation on this matter, which was:

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government pay particular attention to identifying United States' self-interests, and how they may coincide with Australian interests, in any trade proposals or representations we make, both bilaterally and in APEC, and ensuring that the matters identified are widely known within the United States, particularly by potential allies within the United States.

We have already done this in Europe, I believe with some reasonable success. The green book put the argument for freer trade and for the Europeans to lower their subsidies. It was all a part of our arguments within the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade which was concluded late last year; but it was very well listened to amongst a number of interests within Europe.

PARA.TAB: For several weeks a couple of years ago I happened to be deputy leader of the parliamentary delegation to Strasbourg and Brussels, the European institutions. We had the green book in our hands every day. We were reinforcing as parliamentarians to parliamentarians and to other interest groups in the parliament of Europe, the European Union as it is now known, that the Australian arguments were enormously confirming of the interests of consumer groups for lower prices of goods and even of some of the environmentalists and those concerned with freer trade and a fair go for Third World countries.

The actual argument with regard to price was the most compelling self-interest argument that we could put to interest groups within Europe. There is a majority forming, I believe within the parliament in Strasbourg, to endorse the Australian point of view. This needs to be an explicit part of Australia's quite honest, genuine—there is nothing covert, controversial or conspiratorial about it—open addressing of our interests, our objectives, by aligning ourselves with interest groups within the United States that agree with us.
I will not read recommendation 6 but I note that it refers to seeking to `identify specific interest groups' and so on. I think the government's response on these two recommendations is inadequate.

I refer to recommendation 8 which, quite squarely on the evidence that was before the committee, recommended that the Australian government continue to make every effort to promote the rapid achievement of concrete trade liberalising outcomes through APEC, and that one specific measure should be the early inclusion of Mexico and Chile in APEC. Happily, the November meeting of APEC in Seattle admitted Mexico and Papua New Guinea, and agreed to admit Chile from November of 1994, after which there will be a three-year moratorium on membership to allow APEC to consolidate.

I very much welcome the APEC decision. The admission of these three members will be the final admission for the time being. I have to note that it was with some embarrassment to me, personally, as the President of the Australia-Chile friendship group within this parliament, that on the occasion of President Aylwin's visit to this parliament and to the government in this building—indeed to Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne—in September or October last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was still to be convinced about that matter with regard to Chile.

It was a golden opportunity for the Prime Minister to have given a naturally warm welcome to a visiting head of state—it was the first time the President of Chile had visited this country. It would have been appropriate as Chile had returned to democracy, to an open-door approach to the world economy, to being world competitive and to having a disciplined economy. But when President Aylwin came on such an historic visit it took a little of the edge off when we learned that the Prime Minister was still to be convinced about the admission of Chile, along with Mexico and Papua New Guinea, in the round that was to take place a matter of weeks later in Seattle.

I will concede that the then Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, were very much warmer to the positive reasons for Australia advocating Chile's inclusion in that decision. I greatly regret the loss of an opportunity for a totally successful diplomatic closeness at the prime minister to president level that could have been achieved had there been a bit more vision on the Prime Minister's part.

If this government response had been given in September, nearer to the time in which we expect responses in the Senate to our committee reports, I think the government would not have responded as forcibly as it did in December of last year, post Seattle. I have the consolation though that APEC more readily lived up to the Senate committee's aspirations than did the Australian government at that time, with its confused position. I am very glad that the three countries that, most appropriately, were to be members of APEC; Mexico, Papua New Guinea and Chile, are already—or will be this year—members. I am very proud that the Senate committee made such a recommendation.

My last reference is to what is in many ways the most important finding of the Senate committee, and that is recommendation 9, which refers to the United States relations with Japan and China, and the positive role that Australia can play in both those important relationships as an enhancer of harmony and good outcomes in security and trade terms.

Since this recommendation—to which the government very warmly responds—was brought down, we have seen the development of difficulty and even potential deadlock between the United States and Japan on trade matters. I do not see a parallel risk in security terms. The United States-Japan security treaty is one of the most important defence relationships in the world. I believe it is very much intact. Whatever immaturities there might be from, or unilateral actions taken by, the United States or Japan in their trade conflict, I believe they will not see any ripples widening to in any way change that very important security arrangement.

The security arrangement is in fact the most important foundation for the security of the peace that has undergirded the north-east Asian region over the last 40 years. On it has been built the prosperity of Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and the increasing prosperity, too, of China. So the importance of the security relationship is undergirding the economic relationships of the region, and the countries that I have just mentioned include our most important trade partners; that is, from Australia's point of view.

In security terms, Australia has, as its first ally, the United States. The ANZUS alliance is confirmed on all sides of this parliament, as I understand it—certainly by the government and the coalition. As recently as an hour or two ago it was confirmed in the statement by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), entitled Strategic Review 1993.

Australia's security relationship with the United States is another of the foundations for our involvement in the whole Asia-Pacific region, I believe to the better stability of that region, both strategically and in economic terms. Where the crunch comes is that we need coherence on the part of the Australian government and all of its ministers and representatives in defusing these potential difficulties in trade between the United States and Japan, or between the United States and China.

I believe that Australia is an honest broker in this matter. Of course we have our self-interest, to see the whole region so stable that it prospers and we prosper along with it. But we do warn against unilateral trade measures on the part of the United States. The role that Australia can play may well be crucial to the continuation of the situation we have been so happy to observe in the last 20 years in our region.

Accidents happen in trade or in security matters. There are unforeseen developments which could have been avoided by reinforcement at an earlier stage. It does mean that Australia needs to live up to the kind of response that the government has made to recommendation 9 in this committee report.

I conclude by referring to the large number of visits by Australian ministers to the United States in the first year of Mr Clinton's presidency. They have been made very welcome. I have the impression that all these ministers went to the United States with the Senate committee report in their pockets. I say this to commend the government. I think that whilst there have been lapses and a lack of full coherence from Mr Russell and Mr Calvert, our ambassadors in the United States and Japan, and in statements made by ministers back in Australia with regard to last week's developments in Japan-US trade relations, the actual visits of ministers of this government to the United States in the last 12 months have been constructive.

Whilst I am loath in certain circumstances to commend the Prime Minister, I want to give him full credit for the personal rapport which clearly he has established with President Clinton. The demonstration of that is in their joint press conference, in the Prime Minister's reference to NAFTA, and in health policy, quite apart from all the matters that have been the subject of this report. I believe that has helped to build a personal relationship between President Clinton and Mr Keating which is good for Australia.

What I am saying is that we should not let events of the last week and our inadequately coherent responses to that take away from the foundation that has been well established in 1993, and which has been so much called for by the Senate report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me welcome the government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I think Senator Teague may have gone through the report in a very careful way and, as a former member of the committee, no doubt he was well aware of its contents. I support a lot of the remarks made by him.
—Still a member.

—He is still a member of the committee. The committee reported on the implications for Australia of the United States policy in the context of the 1992 presidential election. It is worth remembering that the Senate referred the matter to the Senate foreign affairs committee on 16 September 1992 and the committee tabled the report to the Senate on 16 December 1992. If one takes those dates into consideration and now looks at the response, one could be forgiven for believing that history has passed the committee report by. The committee at that stage was under the chairmanship of then Senator Graham Maguire, who has now left this place. I believe that had he been here he would have dearly liked to have commented on the government's response.

PARA.TAB: The report itself brought down by the committee covered a number of fairly important subjects: the presidential election in the US, APEC and NAFTA. A look at just part of the contents shows that the committee investigated a very wide ranging area in that short period between when the matter was referred to it, and its report was brought down in the Senate.

Looking at the introduction and security issues in the Asia-Pacific region, we see a coverage of the policies of the presidential candidates; President Bush's position; Governor Clinton's position; likely outcome and implications; the implication of shrinking US military presence; and arms control implications. One could go further but I do not think one needs to repeat all the contents of the committee report. But if one remembers them, then my statement that history has passed the committee report by is valid; a lot has happened since the committee brought down the report and made its recommendations.

The government's response to the Senate foreign affairs, defence and trade committee's report on the implications of the United States policy for Australia shows, I believe, in particular, the government's acknowledgment of the contribution that the report made to the analysis and the public debate on the likely direction of the US policy under the new Clinton administration. At the same time, I must express disappointment that the government has taken more than 12 months to put forward its response.
As I said before, the membership of the committee has changed considerably. I know that Senator Teague is still a member of the committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —Still deputy chair.

—That is right; he is still on that side of the house. The chairman at the time of the inquiry was the former Senator Maguire. I am sure he would have wished to comment on the government's response. Equally importantly, many significant developments have occurred in the areas canvassed in the report, including APEC, NAFTA and the Uruguay Round. The value of dialogue on the report within the parliament diminishes if too much time passes between the committee's report and the government's response. In all fairness—and I think Senator Teague made this comment—I should note that over the past three years the government has been quick and thorough in its response to committee reports and, in this instance, one would have to say that the holding of an election certainly slowed down any response by the government.

PARA.TAB: From a very quick perusal of the government's response, I am pleased to see the government recognises the broad validity of the committee's analysis of likely developments as the Clinton administration settles in. The response gives a useful account of the way in which the United States' policies have evolved over the past year. I am also pleased to see that a serious effort has been made by the government to develop strong links with the new American administration. This is something that the committee strongly advocated.

Two areas of continuing concern, notwithstanding the successful completion of the Uruguay Round, are the continuing difficulties for Australia arising from the United States agricultural subsidies barrier to Australian exports and the possible adverse consequences arising for Australia from NAFTA. In this regard, I particularly welcome the government's support for the committee's proposal concerning the formation of the alliances with groups whose interests coincide with ours. As the response says, it is important not just to work with traditional allies but also to identify others such as environmental or welfare groups whose interests may also be affected adversely by the misallocation of resources through certain farm support programs. It is to be hoped that adequate resources will be dedicated to identify and link up with new allies.

It is also evident that the government will need to continue to monitor very closely the detailed implication of the NAFTA agreement and take prompt action to bring to the attention of the US government any damage that the practical application of the agreement might inflict on Australia. Finally, the Maguire report certainly shows where Australia stands on some of the issues although, as I said before, I think history has passed the committee report by.

I take this opportunity to thank the staff of the committee for the way in which they worked to put together the report and have it tabled in the Senate by 16 December 1992, soon after 16 September 1992. One would have to say that the committee staff worked very hard to complete that report and put it before the Senate in that short period.
