SPEECH.PARA: I table a revised explanatory memorandum and correction and I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The charter of the Department of Social Security is to deliver social security entitlements with fairness, courtesy and efficiency. With this in mind, this bill contains a range of omnibus amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 to further refine the Government's carefully balanced income support programs administered under that Act. The bill also provides for the implementation of a 1993 Budget initiative.

The Social Security Act currently provides for the payment of mobility allowance to disabled persons who have job search as part of their agreed activity plan but who cannot use public transport without substantial assistance because of their disability. This bill amends the Social Security Act to ensure that disabled persons undertaking job search activities under a Competitive Employment, Placement and Training Program will also qualify for mobility allowance.

Under the Social Security Act, a person does not have to make a proper claim for sole parent pension if the person is receiving a wife pension or a carer pension, the person's partner dies, immediately before the end of the bereavement period the person is qualified for wife or carer pension respectively and immediately after the end of that period the person is qualified for sole parent pension. However, this is not the case for a person in similar circumstances who qualifies for widow B pension. The bill corrects this difference by amending the Act to allow a person to be granted a widow B pension without the need to make a proper claim in similar circumstances.

It is with much pleasure that I inform the Senate that this bill gives effect to a new international social security Agreement between Australia and the Republic of Italy. The new Agreement follows a review instigated by Australia and encouraged by Australian-Italian community groups and representatives.

The Social Security Act provides that if there is a charge or encumbrance over a particular assessable asset of a person that is not used for primary production, the value of the asset is reduced by the value of that charge or encumbrance.

This reduction is not allowed to the extent that the charge or encumbrance is a collateral security or was given for the benefit of a person other than the person or the person's partner. If the charge or encumbrance is over a mix of assessable and exempt assets, it is apportioned between those assets. Assets cannot be reduced by the value of unsecured liabilities and, if a secured liability exceeds the value of the unencumbered asset, the excess is not an allowable deduction.

Amendments were made to the Social Security Act in 1991 to allow more generous rules to apply to primary producers by providing that the aggregate value of primary production assets could be reduced by the aggregate value of their liabilities that are related to the carrying on of primary production. This means that the value of their primary production assets can be reduced by the value of their unsecured liabilities, as well as by the amount that a secured liability exceeds the value of the asset that provides the primary security. However, it was always intended that where a liability exists in relation to an asset that is in any part exempt for the purposes of the assets test, then the apportionment rule should apply. This bill gives effect to that intention.

The Social Security Act provides for certain assets to be disregarded in calculating a person's assets for the purposes of the pensions and benefits assets tests. One type of asset that is disregarded is a life interest unless it is a life interest in the principal home of the person or the person's partner or it has been created by the person or the person's partner. The intention in not allowing these latter types of life interests to be disregarded was to prevent people from gaining an unfair advantage under the assets test by converting absolute interests in property into a life interest. A recent decision of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) highlighted a deficiency in the legislation in situations where a life interest is created under the will of a deceased person who, immediately before their death, was the partner of the life tenant. The bill corrects this deficiency to ensure that these life interests will not be disregarded in calculating the value of a person's assets.

The Social Security Act currently allows the assessable period of a client to be taken into account when the client realises a `saved' non-superannuation investment. Amendments contained in this bill ensure that the assessable period of a non-client partner will also be taken into account.

The Social Security Act will also be amended to clarify the existing definition of retirement village. This amendment aims at preserving the original intention underlying this definition. It ensures that accommodation primarily intended for persons who are at an age that is more than 55 years is treated in the same way as accommodation primarily intended for persons who are at least 55 years of age, that is, as accommodation in a retirement village.

This bill makes further amendments to the confidentiality provisions of the Social Security Act as part of an ongoing vigilance by the Department of Social Security to safeguard a person's privacy. One of the key amendments relating to confidentiality that is contained in the bill provides for the extension of the definition of "protected information" to protect the information that the Department has no information about a person, for example, that the person is not a client of the Department. A further amendment tackles a loophole in the provisions. At the moment, it is not an offence under the Social Security Act for a person to disclose protected information if that information has been obtained by the person through innocent means—for example, if a person finds Departmental papers about a client in the street and then tells another person about the details contained in those papers. This bill provides that, should a person obtaining the information know that it is protected information and intentionally record, disclose or otherwise use it, that person will be committing an offence.

A decision by the SSAT must usually be implemented by the Department of Social Security regardless of whether a further appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) is lodged by either the Department or the client. If the SSAT decision is to be delayed in its implementation one of the parties must successfully seek a stay order from the AAT. The Department seeks a stay order when it is unsuccessful at the SSAT and appeals to the AAT in situations where implementation of the decision would be detrimental to the longer term interests of the Commonwealth. A client seeks a stay order where they are unsuccessful at the SSAT, intends to appeal to the AAT, and wish to continue to receive advantages that would cease if the SSAT decision were implemented.

Problems arise where the SSAT has affirmed an original Departmental decision. The decision on appeal to the AAT is then not the SSAT decision. Rather it is the Departmental decision as affirmed by the SSAT. In several cases, the AAT has commented on this as a curious situation because it means that there is no decision of the SSAT's own that it can stay. It is anomalous that Departmental clients in a similar situation could be treated differently by the law depending on whether the SSAT and the Department happened to be in agreement. This bill overcomes this anomaly.

The Social Security Act lists all situations where an overpayment can be described as a "debt due to the Commonwealth" and so be recoverable. At present that list does not include a debt that has arisen because of social security payments made pursuant to an AAT stay order granted at the client's request where the client ultimately loses at the AAT and, with hindsight, it is clear that the money was not payable. As a result, these stay order debts cannot be recovered. This bill amends the Act to add to these debts to the categories of recoverable overpayments.

The Government decided in the 1993 Budget context to abolish, from 1 July 1994, the administrative charge currently applicable under the Social Security Act in relation to certain debts. The administrative charge will be replaced with a penalty interest charge that can be applied to any debt owed under the Act if, and only if, the person who owes the debt, is not a current client of the Department and refuses to enter into an agreement to repay the debt or if, having entered into such an agreement, the person defaults on the agreement.
The bill also makes a number of minor and technical amendments as part of the ongoing exercise to ensure the integrity and accuracy of the Social Security Act.

Finally, the bill corrects an unintended consequence of an earlier amendment to the National Health Act 1953 so as to prevent a person who is a dependent of a mobility allowee from attracting concessional pharmaceutical benefits unless the person can attract those benefits otherwise than because they are a dependent of the mobility allowee.
I commend this bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (SEARCH WARRANTS AND POWERS OF ARREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 February, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill 1993 has been a long time in the making. It started some 18 years ago with an Australian Law Reform Commission report. It got a boost along quite a few years after that with the Gibbs committee in 1987. And here we are in 1994 debating a bill that was introduced last year.

PARA.TAB: As the title indicates, the bill deals with search warrants and powers of arrest. Basically what that means is that it covers the investigatory matters in relation to Commonwealth offences. While you and I, Madam Acting Deputy President, might think this bill is a bit dry and something that only the lawyers would be interested in, a headline in today's Advertiser indicates just how interested individual citizens should be in the provisions of the bill. In fact, the civil liberties groups, the law societies and the law institutes have taken a significant interest in this bill from a perspective of the rights of individual citizens.

There is no dispute about the need for such a bill. There may be some, as yet, unresolved disagreement about the terms of the bill. The headline in today's Advertiser is `Police Probe Footy Park Arrests'. The first paragraph of the article reads:
Police are investigating allegations that two teenage girls endured a 6 1/2-hour ordeal in which they were jailed over an under-age drinking incident at Football Park.

SPEECH.PARA: If these allegations prove to be correct, it is a quite serious matter if teenage girls are deprived of their liberty for 6 1/2 hours. What is alleged to have happened in this incident is that the girls were spoken to by undercover policemen about drinking and asked for identification. When it turned out they were not of age, they were instructed to leave Football Park—probably a sensible police decision not to pursue them at the time and seek some sort of prosecution later. The girls say that they left Football Park and tried to contact the parents of one of the girls. In any event that was unsuccessful, partly because one girl's parents do not have a phone and the other girl's parents were already on their way to Football Park. The girls tried to ring a friend and were unable to get through.

PARA.TAB: The consequence of that was that, not being sure what to do having been instructed to leave, the girls then decided to go back into Football Park because, they say, they knew where the parents of one girl would be. Before they got to the parents, the police who had told them to leave saw them come back, apparently took them to some sort of place for detention, placed them in a paddy wagon and allegedly they were left there for an hour before someone else joined them. And so the saga continued. It was no doubt a very frightening experience for those young girls who would have no idea of their rights and obligations in that respect.

One can see both sides of the story. The police might have thought they were being lenient in saying, `Look, just leave' and then, seeing the girls coming back, might have thought they were being hoodwinked by two young girls who were just saying that their parents were somewhere in the crowd. In any event, a simple thing such as underage drinking—not that I approve of it by saying that it is simple—can deprive people of their liberty for quite an extensive period and have significant consequences of apprehension in the family and possibly after that as a consequence of these activities.

I add in this respect that the South Australian police have not necessarily done anything wrong. These are allegations raised in the newspaper and I believe that there are always two sides to a story. But it highlights what can happen to people. It is important that we realise when we are dealing with legislation in this place that we are not just dealing with bits of paper and laws that someone somewhere else will reflect on in days or years to come but with things that will, on a day-to-day basis, impact on the lives of Australians. I thought that was worth raising in that context.

In the other place my colleague Daryl Williams QC, MP raised one practical impact of this legislation as it relates to police officers rather than to citizens from day to day. This act gives the power to state police officers with respect to Commonwealth offences, and the question necessarily arises as to how the police are to decide from one moment to the next which sort of offence they are investigating. Mr Williams used the example of an offence of conspiracy under federal or state law. If the powers in relation to search warrants and powers of arrest are different in this bill for a federal offence than they are in the state bills, that raises a confusion for police officers. Which offence are they alleging to investigate at any one time?

The civil libertarians and those who do not want to give the police any more power at all would probably say, `I know what will happen. They will cunningly claim that they were investigating what they thought to be an offence under whichever law gives them the greater power'. That is not the point that Mr Williams was raising, although it may well be made. The point he made relates to the difficulty that is created for police officers in this respect. This bill will have a far-reaching day-to-day impact on a wide range of people: Commonwealth and state police officers and, of course, individuals who might be affected by an investigation or an action having taken place.

The bill has a number of divisions. There is obviously a preliminary one dealing with search warrants, and that covers the requirements of issuing of search warrants, including telephone warrants and the powers that can be conferred by them, matters relating to the seizure of property and the use of electronic and other equipment during the execution of a search warrant. Division 3 deals with stopping and searching of conveyances. Division 4 deals with arrest and some related matters. Division 5 is a somewhat general division.

One might have thought that, because this bill was introduced last year, in early January there would have been a significant amount of comment available on it. That is not, as we have discovered, the case at all. Mr Williams made the point that probably everyone was on holiday at that time, and I think that is true. I think it is true today that Australia generally shuts down over late December early January, but it is a very conscientious volunteer worker for civil liberties, for a law society or whatever who takes the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill home for some light early January reading rather than watching the cricket or whatever. We need to understand that the people who will make contributions to this sort of legislation, other than those who already have done so, are volunteers.

We came to the situation where the bill was coming on in the House of Representatives and there was not a very wide range of comment. There clearly needed to be some further investigation—not as to the principle of having such a bill codifying these powers, but with respect to the individual clauses. Mr Williams sought in the other place to send this bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—a proposal which I note was greeted with some agreement by Mr Melham, who happens to be the chairman of that committee.

I make no remarks as to Mr Melham's ego, but I was amused to read in the House of Representatives Hansard an explanation that he had been overseas when this bill was introduced and that he did not get the opportunity to see it before it went into the House. This raised two things in my mind. Firstly, I thought how nice it would be to be in government when backbenchers could see bills before they were brought into the house and get a longer period to make a contribution. Obviously, Mr Melham was indicating that he would have had the opportunity to have some input to the bill. Secondly, I thought he was implying that had he seen the bill before, all would have been well. Mr Melham might have waved a magic wand and fixed the concerns raised by Mr Williams and others.

He was good enough to his committee to indicate that it was the premier committee of the parliament—not of the House of Representatives, but of the parliament. It was the premier committee. I thought this confidence was inspiring and, as I read on, I felt quite sure that the confidence would have been shared by other honourable members of the House of Representatives. But it was not to be. Apparently, the government does not share Mr Melham's confidence in that committee, of which Daryl Williams QC, Ian Sinclair and, I understand, a former Attorney-General or two are members. For some inexplicable reason—and I am interested, when this debate concludes and the minister responds, to see if we can get some idea what that reason was—the government decided not to send this off to a Senate committee to do some investigation. Of course, it comes up to this place and the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs takes on the task, which is not surprising to me.

As to the substance of the bill, there are a number of things that have caused concern. There are always competing arguments, as I said with respect to the matter raised in the Adelaide Advertiser this morning. What we have seen so far is the allegations made by the girls or by their parents. It would be interesting to hear what the police have to say. There are concerns raised by, for example, the Law Society of New South Wales. I also note the Public Defenders Office, an office from which, I understand, Mr Melham came. I thought he would be particularly interested to hear what the Public Defenders Office in New South Wales had to say with respect to some of these clauses.

The government is proceeding with the second reading of this bill in this fortnight of sittings. As I understand it, an agreement has been arrived at that the committee stage of the bill will be held Wednesday next—not Wednesday of this week, but Wednesday next. That, I understand, is to give further time to people who want to get in more views from the people who may have an interest. The Senate standing committee has already done that from a wide range of people, but there are still more who might wish to put their views.

For example, the Senate standing committee spoke to Mr Andrew Menzies, who was part of the review of Commonwealth criminal law—otherwise referred to as the Gibbs committee; it had something to say about this in 1987. The committee also spoke to Mr Martin Sides QC from the Public Defenders Office in New South Wales, Ms Beverley Schurr from the Law Society of New South Wales, Terry O'Gorman from the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties, and Dr Jill Hunter from the University of New South Wales, who is an academic in this area. It is fair to say that none of these people wholeheartedly endorsed the bill. In fact, there was not one of them, apart from the government representatives, who did not raise some concern. I stress that this is not a debate about politics of the Labor Party or the Liberal Party or whatever: it is a desire to try to get this codification right.

It might be useful in the remaining time I have to raise some of the concerns that have been raised by the New South Wales Law Society and, for example, the Public Defenders Office. The committee stage—which it is agreed will be postponed until Wednesday week—is where the for and against arguments in each of these matters can be more clearly argued. The Law Society of New South Wales is not, for example, at all happy with police having powers to enter premises without a warrant to arrest. It is simply dissatisfied with that and it queries a number of things. For example, it asks that if someone is not arrested, what are the police powers? The bill is silent as to powers, such as to detain the persons in the premises and to search and seize persons and the contents of the premises. The Law Society of New South Wales goes on to point out how persons may then turn to rely on the common law.

Probably the most contentious clause is the creation of an offence for the failure to supply name and address to police. The argument put by the New South Wales Law Society basically is that it may be true—and I believe it is true—that by far the greater majority of citizens want, whenever it is possible, to be of assistance to the police. If they have seen something and they think they can contribute, they will. But we have always maintained that it is a citizen's right not to do that.

There are plenty of reasons why people do not participate in matters associated with an investigation in an incident that they have seen—not the least of which is the old fashioned and sometimes regrettable desire not to be involved. There is the fear of the consequences of speaking out. Sometimes there is a fear of reprisal or simply a fear of the time that will be taken in having to give a statement. There is probably the fear of being called into court and cross-examined on what they saw when they were simply innocent bystanders. They were walking along unlucky enough to be the schmucks who saw whatever it was that happened. They would say to themselves, `We are getting out of here. We do not want to know about this. We do not want our time taken up. We cannot take time off our jobs. We would like to help, but forget it'. Some of those people ring up and give anonymous contributions to the police. Others do not; they just put it aside and forget it.

This clause means that if people are there at the time, the police can ask for their names and addresses. It is not only those people who might feel apprehensive about that. I do not see a huge difference, in some respects, in having to have an identification card. I see there is a substantial difference, but I also see the similarities that someone is entitled to just come up and ask people their names and addresses.

Perhaps the easiest way to clarify this for people of older years—it might not be something that affects people of younger years—is simply to ask them whether they have ever been at a place, at a particular time, they would rather everyone else not know they were there for whatever reason. I do not need to waste the Senate's time listing the pages and pages of reasons that people might have to be in that position. What happens to these people lawfully going about their business—doing nothing that we have any business interfering in—and who are just unlucky enough to be there when a robber runs out of a bank, a car smashes into another car or whatever. Up until now, in most states, and as I understand it, in relation to federal offences, these people could silently slink away into the night or the day, whatever it may be. But that will be no more if this bill is passed.

The reasons offered are legitimate reasons. Some of those people might feel at the time that they do not want to be involved, et cetera. The police might have an opportunity to persuade them otherwise if they had their names and addresses. That begs the question of what form the persuasion would take. It does, however, raise the very valid point that it gives the opportunity for the police to get back in contact with people and to give them a reminder and an opportunity to reconsider their positions as to whether they want to participate and be of assistance. That comes back to the basic position put by the civil liberties people—that is, that it is the citizens' choice whether they cooperate with the police or not. It is perfectly valid.

All the reasons offered that would make it easier for the police if all people had to give their names and addresses are quite true. But the point is bypassed that, up until now—except for a number of things such as traffic offences—citizens have had that choice. That choice now, we would have to consciously admit to ourselves, would be being taken away from them. The question is whether we want to give the police the power to do that. The second argument with respect to this clause of probably equal, if not greater, standing raised by the civil liberties people and, indeed, by the Public Defenders Office in New South Wales is the opportunity it creates for a misuse of power against minorities and the difficulties that it, therefore, may well create for those minorities.

People unaware of their rights and obligations and who are, for whatever reason, apprehensive about giving their name and address and who are wanting to slink off into the night, all of a sudden find themselves arrested. It is the age old problem of people being arrested for some minor, piffling offence as a means of securing their custody, either to question them further about something or as a form of harassment or, in many cases, simply as a result of an ill-informed understanding of these people's place in the community and their knowledge of their rights and obligations. That is probably the most serious clause that we need to look at. I do not say at this stage that we will oppose that clause but we are very concerned about its inclusion, as are a number of other people, and it is a matter we will deal with in the committee stage of the debate on this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill 1993. This bill amends the Crimes Act of 1914 to insert a new part which will deal with search warrants and powers of arrest as they apply to the investigation of Commonwealth offences. The bill deals with five substantive areas: the issue of warrants for search and arrest; the procedures for obtaining search warrants for premises and persons; the provision of names and addresses to police officers; the procedures for arrest undertaken with or without warrants; and the collection and use of identification material.

PARA.TAB: As the law currently stands, Commonwealth police must use state powers when dealing with these matters. This leads to great inconsistencies because each state applies different laws to these powers and procedures. The bill's provision will supplant all these state powers in relation to search warrants and powers of arrest with the exception of those relating to forensic samples. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, made reference to this gap in the law. We have received assurances that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is currently working on uniform forensic sampling provisions for all jurisdictions in Australia. We assume that once this position has been reached a further amendment to the Crimes Act will be proposed.

This bill had its genesis in recommendations made by the Gibbs committee in November 1990. That committee undertook quite extensive community consultation on the issues of search warrants and arrest. The bill is aimed at balancing the competing public interest of effective law enforcement and civil liberties. While recognising that this is a very difficult task, the Australian Democrats believe that the balance has not been found.

The bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which heard further evidence from interested community groups, such as the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties and the New South Wales Law Society, as Senator Vanstone mentioned. The submissions from those groups raised many important issues from a civil liberties perspective, which the Australian Democrats believe must be addressed before the bill is finally passed into law.

The Democrats' proposed amendments fall into four categories: the issue of warrants; the execution of warrants; the name and address provisions; and the identification material provisions. On the matter of the issuing of warrants, we believe that it would be advisable to limit the right to issue telephone warrants to magistrates only. The Australian Democrats believe that only magistrates should be authorised to issue these sorts of warrants—namely, those obtained in situations of urgency. The decision to infringe a person's privacy and liberty is a serious one. In the case of warrants issued by telephone or other electronic means, the safeguards for abuse of the search powers are greatly reduced. Such warrants should only be granted by those fully trained in the consideration of evidence and the determination of questions of law as they apply to such situations.

On the matter of report-back provisions, the bill provides for very little supervision of the powers it bestows upon the police force. The New South Wales Search Warrants Act 1985 requires police officers to report back in writing to the magistrate or justice of the peace who issued the warrant with the following details: whether the warrant was executed; the result of the search; a description of any seized goods; an explanation in the case of a warrant not being executed; and whether the warrant and occupier's notice were provided to the occupier. The aim of such a report-back procedure is to create a paper trail which an aggrieved occupier is able to trace in order to ascertain whether there has been any abuse of the search powers. It also provides a mechanism for detecting forum shoppers—police officers who approach various issuing officers to obtain a warrant. The Democrats would like to see such reporting mechanisms in this bill, preferably computerised in a central search register.

On the matter of disclosure of additional information in the warrant application, the bill provides for various types of information which the executing officer must give to the issuing officer when applying for the search warrant. For example, it may be necessary to use firearms, which is a somewhat topical issue. Given that the bill allows for premises to be entered in certain circumstances without any announcement to the occupiers, we believe that if a police officer has a suspicion that this might be necessary at the time when he or she applies for the warrant, it should be disclosed to the issuing officers. Similarly, it is also essential for the police officer to inform the issuing officer whether a warrant for the same person or premises has been applied for on any previous occasion. This will help to mitigate the use of forum shopping, which I mentioned earlier.

On the matter of disclosure of additional information on the face of the warrant, given that the potential use of firearms must be disclosed in the application for a warrant, we believe that that fact should also appear on the face of the warrant. Similarly, if the need for entry without announcement is anticipated, that also should appear on the face of the warrant.

Civil liberties organisations have expressed concern about the fact that fingerprinting on premises is automatically authorised when a search warrant is issued. In order to curtail the indiscriminate use of this power, the Australian Democrats propose that this is another power which should be stated clearly and overtly on the face of the warrant.

I turn to the matter of the execution of warrants, in particular to the tape recording of the search. The Australian Democrats support the call of civil liberties groups for the tape recording of all search procedures. That would provide an important safeguard against the abuse of the suspect's rights. We will therefore move an amendment to that effect during the committee stage of this debate.

I turn to the matter of searches to be conducted in the presence of the occupier. We believe that searches of premises should be carried out in the presence of the occupier at all times in order to minimise the opportunities for police to plant evidence. To make this practicable, rooms should be searched one at a time with all persons present. The bill presently gives an occupier the right to be present for the examination of `things containing electronically stored information which have been seized and removed from the premises'. We do not believe that this right should be limited to a specific class of goods and we will move an amendment to extend this right to all goods removed from premises.

Further, the police should give the occupier a notice which clearly states the powers that the warrant affords the police, as well as the rights that the various amendments which we will be moving would ensure that the occupier has, namely: the right to be present during a search; the right to have a receipt for goods seized; the right not to be strip-searched; the right to be present at any examination of goods taken from the premises; and the name of the local court where the warrant and report-back information have been lodged.

I turn to the name and address provisions. The bill makes it an offence for a person to refuse to give his or her name and address or a false name and address if a police officer believes on reasonable grounds that the person may be able to assist an inquiry in relation to any—and I emphasise any—offence which has been committed. We believe that this provision is cast far too broadly and should only apply in relation to inquiries about indictable offences.

In the area of identification material, the Commonwealth bill does not lay down procedures for any intimate forensic sampling. In an effort to bridge this gap, the bill expressly preserves all state and territory laws relating to the taking of all forensic samples, including the non-intimate identification material which the Commonwealth bill lays down in provisions. As a result, it vests a discretion in AFP members as to whether they can use state fingerprinting laws or Commonwealth laws. The Australian Democrats will remove this discretion in relation to non-intimate identification materials such as fingerprints. One of the reasons we believe extra care should be taken in this area is the draconian Victorian legislation which has recently been introduced. Turning to the area of identification material, the Commonwealth bill does not make express provision for the informed consent of the person who may be asked to submit to the procedures. We believe that where a person refuses to provide that consent after he or she is fully informed of his or her rights, then that identification material should not be available unless a court order is obtained by the police.

The current provisions for destruction of old identification material are not strict enough, in our view. This is one area where the Victorian legislation actually provides better safeguards, and thus we propose to bring the Commonwealth provisions into line with the Victorian legislation. The bill allows a court or jury to draw any inferences it thinks proper from a suspect's refusal to participate in an identification parade. This is not currently a provision in the common law, and marks a serious intrusion on the normal presumption of innocence. It, effectively, forces people to participate in identification parades, even though there is the alternative available to police of a photographic identification parade, which they may turn to at any stage. We will, therefore, move an amendment to withdraw this provision from the bill.

These amendments, and several others, aim to make the police more accountable in their use of the powers which the bill confers. Furthermore, they will provide safeguards to the individual who may have his or her privacy seriously intruded upon by any unauthorised use of these powers. We shall also propose that any police person who exceeds the act's powers shall be subject to disciplinary procedures. In this area I refer to a position we have consistently advocated, which is the need for independent tribunals to deal with complaints against police. The current provision which obtains in most states is that we have a police disciplinary unit to which people must complain when they feel they have reason to have concern about any actions of police. Clearly, the principle of complaining to Caesar about Caesar is not acceptable in a proper judicial system, and it is an issue we will continue to pursue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, there are some very good things in this Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Bill. It seeks to clarify the position in relation to the Australian Federal Police. I take on board the comments of Senator Spindler in relation to the fact that various pieces of legislation apply around the country from state to state because the Australian Federal Police act under the various state provisions applicable thereto. In that sense, the bill would no doubt serve to enhance the operations of the Australian Federal Police force and it certainly lays down with some clarity procedures to be adopted. To that extent, this is a desirable piece of legislation. The setting out of how warrants are to be obtained, the search of premises—all of those aspects have been covered and in a way in which perhaps other pieces of legislation in this country have not endeavoured to do so.

PARA.TAB: The bill does fall short in one or two aspects. I take on board the comments made by Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler. In particular, the provision which causes me some concern is proposed new section 3ZK(3)(b), which deals with the refusal of a suspect to take part in an identification parade. As has been stated, should that happen, then the court or jury may draw such inferences from that refusal as appear proper.

It is a basic tenet of our law that a person is innocent until proven guilty and that when questioned by the police a citizen of this country does not have to say anything. Above all, there is a rule against self-incrimination. If a person chooses not to say anything to the police, says, `I have no comment', goes to trial and declines to give evidence, then it still cannot be put to the jury that that is something from which that jury can infer guilt. That is an absolutely classic tenet of our criminal judicial system in this country. But what this proposed new section would purport to do would be to allow the jury to draw an inference. It says:
. . . such inferences from that refusal as appear proper . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, what, indeed, is `proper' to infer from that? One might never know the condition in which the suspect was brought to the police station, the condition in which the suspect was arrested, as opposed to when the offence was committed. The person, when offered to participate in an identification parade, might be in an unkempt condition, and for all manner of reasons might not want to participate in an identification parade. To that extent, it is absolutely wrong to place that person under an onus to participate in an identification parade. That cuts across the basic tenet of our judicial system.

PARA.TAB: This bill provides that if a person does refuse to do that, there might be identification carried out by way of photograph. For my part, an identification parade carried out properly is an adequate form of identification to be supervised and conducted by the police, because all too many cases have involved the way in which photographs have been put to witnesses. I note that this bill attempts to set out how those photographs are to be put to any witness or complainant. That is highly desirable, but I do not think one has to attach the sanction that if someone refuses an identification parade, then the jury can draw whatever inference it considers proper. That is a grave problem with this bill.

I take on board the comments made previously in relation to this provision, bearing in mind, of course, that we can say to a citizen, `Look, if you don't participate in this identification parade you will have inferences drawn either for or against you, but, at the same time, you don't have to say anything when questioned by the police'. There is an absolute inconsistency there.

In relation to other provisions in the bill, one which I know caused some concern to witnesses who appeared before the committee was clause 3F(1)(b), being the provision which said that a warrant could authorise the searching for and recording of fingerprints found at the premises. I am aware that the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) wrote a letter saying that it was not intended to include the taking of fingerprints from people at the premises. I want to make it very clear at the committee stage that that is exactly what that subclause means.

PARA.TAB: I wish to say thank you to a number of people in Europe. The world championships this year were held in the small town of Altenberg, or more precisely the Bergstadt of Altenberg in the Ostliches Erzgebirge in what used to be East Germany. Altenberg is a small town of about 3,000 people close to the German-Czech border.

It is a sign of the times that just two years ago the road from Dresden to Altenberg, a major road, was a cobbled street. It is now a sealed bitumen road. But that isolation has in no way diminished the hospitality of the good people of Altenberg. I should make it very clear at the start that Altenberg is not, and I do not think the people of Altenberg would wish it to be known as, a rich town. Historically it has been a mining town, as its name would suggest, and the people who live there are very proud descendants and inheritors of a mining tradition which stretches back hundreds of years.

The track at Altenberg is one of the most technically demanding tracks in the world, and that is what made for a good race. But what made for a really good race was the incredible effort that was put in by everybody associated with the organising committee. I suppose in singling out the Organisationsleiter, Herr Eberhard Roesch; the Gesamtleiter, Herr Wolfgang Landt; and the Bahnleiter, Herr Ulrich Hahn, I do a disservice to the many other men and women who freely gave of their time to make sure that the track and the race were everything that we could possibly hope for. Many people—for example, the track announcer Ron Ringguth—gave their time and asked for absolutely nothing in return.

What impressed me was the opening ceremony to the world championship. I have been at a number of world cups and world championships over about five years and this one was the most touching and moving of all. Every athlete, coach and official participated in an opening ceremony march that started near the Altenberg railway station and proceeded to the town square.

We were escorted through the street of this beautiful town by men in traditional costume from the Erzgebirge region and by school children carrying flaming torches as we marched through the night. I will never forget my surprise and amazement as we went down the main street and swung into the town square where there were well over 1,000, maybe 2,000, of the town's 3,000 inhabitants crammed into the town square to greet us, and my immense pride at being the first of the athletes, coming from Australia, to enter the town square with the honour of having my name read out as a representative of my nation.

That welcome was just the start of an evening of festivities that included a dinner at which every one of the athletes and officials was a welcome guest, and where the food was everything that one could possibly imagine. As an athlete who had spent five or six weeks in Europe eating bread rolls and sausages, the sight of meat, fish and lobster in abundance was just wonderful. We were presented with participants' medallions and team captains' medals. We were entertained by a local dance troupe, an acrobatic company and a world champion in tumbling and acrobatics who did feats on a bicycle, mounted on a stage less than half the space of this Senate chamber, that left the mind boggling.

In particular I remember the individual in question, a very brave man, sitting on the handlebars of the bicycle facing backwards and pedalling the bicycle on its back wheel whilst making it pirouette on the spot. Everybody was very impressed and very touched by this moving tribute. I remember saying later to one of the organisers that it was the most impressive reception that we had ever seen and that we were really touched. He said, `You are athletes as these people are athletes, and that is a beautiful thing'.

I want to say two thankyous, first of all to the Prime Minister of the free state of Saxony, Professor Kurt Biedenkopf, who attended the race and the ceremonies, and especially to the very gallant Mayor of Altenberg, Burgermeister Herr Thomas Kirsten. He is the only mayor to have opened a world championships in one-man bobsled by doing an opening run from halfway down the track. I think he deserves our congratulations. He certainly won the admiration and respect of all the athletes for his courage in doing that, and I think the manner in which he was received by the athletes, spectators and officials at the closing ceremonies was a tribute to the high respect in which he is held.

Finally, I congratulate the world champion this year, my friend Gregor Staehli from Switzerland; the runner-up, Andy Schmid from Austria, who retires this year after 12 years of world cup and world championship competition; and the third placegetter, Franz Plangger, also from Austria. Congratulations, too, to my very good friend of many years, Christian Auer, who won the world cup overall this year. Thanks to all of my friends on the circuit—the Canadians, the Americans, the British and others who assisted me and made my task of representing my country a little bit easier.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer tonight to a matter that has come to my notice relating to a constituent in my electorate. It deals with the problem—I think problem is the right word—that he has had with Comcare. About five years ago he contacted Comcare to say that he thought something was wrong with the amount that he received. Not a lot happened after that, but it turned out that he was right. In December 1993 he received a letter from Comcare. I will read it because its starkness in the circumstances I think is part of the difficulty:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to you regarding your compensation benefit which is paid by the Comcare direct payments system. Due to recent problems with the accuracy of payments on the system, we are currently undertaking a full review of compensation entitlements and payments made. As a part of this review, any outstanding wage increases and superannuation adjustments are being applied where applicable.I have completed a review of your entitlement and have made all necessary adjustments to ensure that you are now receiving benefits at the correct rate. Your file will now undergo a reconciliation of payments made and you will be advised of the outcome of this as soon as possible.

That is all accurate and to the point. It does not mention, of course, that my constituent had contacted the department five years previously. No mention was made of any regret that there had been difficulty with the payments or anything of that nature. That letter was dated 2 December 1993. I have another letter dated 7 January 1994, which states:

PARA.TAB: I am writing to you regarding your fortnightly compensation payments. In particular, I refer to a complete reconciliation of entitlements and payment that has occurred on your claim. The outcome of this reconciliation shows that you have been underpaid $14,803.75 gross. The attached shows the calculations performed in reaching the abovementioned figure.
The amount of $14,803.75 will be paid to you on 27 January 1994. If you have any further queries, please contact the direct payments team on the above telephone number.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours sincerely

That is accurate. It turns out that $14,803.75 was the amount that my constituent had been underpaid over the five-year period. As I mentioned earlier, he had contacted Comcare to indicate that he thought there was something wrong with the payments. I think he is pleased to receive the money. There was not a word of apology or regret that this had happened. I really feel disappointed that some sort of button on the computer cannot be pressed to put in a small sentence to indicate that some mistake had been made.

PARA.TAB: When I heard about this, I found it extraordinary that my constituent was told that he would not get any interest on the money that he had not received over that period. My constituent really did not make a great deal of fuss. I think I would have made more fuss had I been in his position. So I wrote to the state manager and referred to the correspondence which I had seen. I asked whether or not, given that the Australian Taxation Office demands very high interest from anybody who is a bit late in paying, there was any way in which an ex gratia payment could be made to him. Of course, I was not for a minute suggesting that Comcare was liable to pay interest but, from what I know of this matter, it seemed to me that it would be the right thing to do to offer to pay interest to him.
I have had a reply from Comcare which is very precise and to the point. It notes the comments, and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Comcare is governed by the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act. It has no provision to pay interest. In fact, the only place in which it is required to pay interest is where a lump sum has been delayed by more than 30 days.
The letter goes on to say:
Given that, it is obviously the intention that no interest should be paid in any other circumstance.

I was disappointed, though, that Comcare, after receiving my letter, had not made a submission to the minister suggesting that perhaps in these circumstances an ex gratia payment for the interest might have been offered to my constituent. But that was not to be. So I raise the matter here tonight. There must be others in the same position. I find it hard to believe that, after this extensive inquiry, this particular constituent was the only one who received moneys that had been withheld from him, through no fault of his, of course. I am not suggesting it was anybody's fault, but it was in fact money withheld from him. Living on money from Comcare is not that easy, according to most of the constituents that I hear about who have dealings with it. It is fairly lean. The amount owed to my constituent over five years was fairly considerable.

PARA.TAB: I remind honourable senators that, if people are late in paying the tax office, the rate of interest they will be charged is 16 per cent. That rate is pretty high these days, considering that interest rates have come down as they have. If one happens to be non-custodial parents required to make payments to the Child Support Agency, and if per chance one should happen to be a little late with those payments, one will be charged 16 per cent. Again, that is a very high rate of interest considering the level of interest rates these days.

I think it is appropriate that, in circumstances such as those I have described to the Senate this evening, the minister should consider making an ex gratia payment to a person who has suffered in the way that I have mentioned. I am not suggesting that interest should be paid at a rate of 16 per cent but, if it is not 16 per cent, I think we are entitled to ask why the tax office and the Child Support Agency do charge for late payments at that rate.

I hope the minister will perhaps refer this to the relevant minister. I have not mentioned my constituent's name; it is not relevant. I hope to hear from the minister and be invited to submit this case. I hope that the matter will be looked into with a view to considering making an ex gratia payment, bearing in mind that an amount of nearly $15,000 was withheld over a period of five years from someone who was entitled to it.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service: Dog Kennel

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, Business Services, had a dog kennel built at a cost of $46 972 by Australian Construction Services, Brisbane.
(2) How many dogs does this dog kennel house.
(3) What other items are stored in the dog kennel.
(4) Are there any unusual or special features to this dog kennel; if so, what are they.
(5) How long did it take to construct the dog kennel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian Construction Services did build a dog kennel compound for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service's Quarantine Detector Dog Program at its Training Centre at 160 Curtin Avenue, Eagle Farm. The total cost of the project was $59,392.00, which included provision and installation of a relocatable dog compound comprising 11 dog runs with kennels, dog bath with ramp, stainless steel tub with insinkerator, two outdoor exercise yards, connection of all drainage to sewer, electrical modifications, refit of office, classroom and training shed and Council application and inspection fees.

(2) The kennel compound can house up to eleven dogs separately, with one of the runs being reserved as an isolation facility. This capacity is required to facilitate housing dogs during training sessions (three to four months) and hold selected dogs when they become available.
(3) Only dogs are housed in the kennels, but training aids, dog food and related supplies are kept on the premises.

(4) The only special feature of the kennel compound is that it is relocatable. It was constructed on an existing carport/maintenance area and, to keep costs to a minimum both at time of construction and in the future, was designed so that it could be readily dismantled, transported and reassembled if necessary.
(5) Construction of the kennels, coupled with the other work as detailed in (1), took approximately four weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 1 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was a proposal from the Tasmanian Forestry Commission to log parts of south-west Tasmania considered at around the same time as the launch of the Federal Government's celebrated National Forest Policy Statement.

(2) Was written advice received from the Australian Heritage Commission, on or about 21 December 1992, stating that the proposed logging would further reduce wilderness in one of the world's great temperate wilderness areas.
(3) Was the go-ahead for the proposed logging of these areas given on 31 December 1992.
(4) Were bulldozers and logging equipment quickly moved into the south-west on at least four new fronts.
(5) Did these areas of logging activity include the Weld, Styx, Picton and Huon valleys.
(6) Is the Minister currently in the process of deciding whether or not to allow logging to go ahead in the Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness areas.
(7) Are these areas part of the National Estate.
(8) Will a further decision be made as to whether to allow an extension of the Riveaux Road toward Blake opening in south-west Tasmania.
(9) Will advice received from the Australian Heritage Commission again be ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Proposals for logging of forests listed on the national estate are submitted each year by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission for approval by the Minister for Resources in conjunction with his consideration of annual export licences. The consideration of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission proposals in 1992, at the same time as the launch of the National Forests Policy Statement, was coincidental.

(2) Yes. The then Minister for Resources, the Hon Alan Griffiths MP, received comments from the Australian Heritage Commission on 23 December 1992 on proposed forest operations in national estate areas in Tasmania in 1993, including advice on the impact of operations on wilderness values in Western Tasmania.

(3) Mr Griffiths issued licences for the export of woodchips from Tasmania to three companies on 31 December 1992. In deciding to issue export licences the Minister considered the advice provided by the Australian Heritage Commission. He concluded that there were no prudent and feasible alternatives to approving operations in the national estate areas and that adverse effects of logging in these areas would be minimised by adherence to harvesting codes of practice.

(4) Several of the forest operations approved for 1993 were for new operations. These were all part of the normal planning for long term sustainable production of sawlog and veneer log from Multiple Use State forests under Tasmania's Forests and Forest Industry Strategy and the Forestry Commission's Three Year Wood Production Plans. Due to the high rainfall in these forests it is normal for roading and logging to be concentrated in the drier summer months.
(5) Yes.

(6) In December 1993, the Hon Michael Lee MP, the then Minister for Resources issued licences for the export of woodchips from Tasmania in 1994 which included material sourced from national estate areas in the Great Western Tiers and the Tarkine.
(7) Parts of the Great Western Tiers and the Tarkine are entered on the Register of the National Estate.
(8) The extension of Riveaux Road was included in the operations in national estate areas during 1994 approved by Mr Lee.

(9) No. Commonwealth Ministers take their obligations under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 very seriously. The advice of the Australian Heritage Commission has not been ignored. Where there are no prudent and feasible alternatives to proposed harvesting operations in national estate areas, the Minister includes conditions in the licences in order to minimise adverse effects of operations on the national estate. In issuing the 1994 licences the then Minister for Resources, the Hon Michael Lee MP, also wrote to the licensees informing them that he had forwarded the Australian Heritage Commission comments to the Tasmanian Minister and indicated that the companies should liaise with the Tasmanian Forestry Commission to ensure that adverse impacts on the national estate are minimised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy upon notice on 9 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What changes in the amount of production would result from a 100 per cent conversion to organic agricultural methods throughout Australia with respect to the major commodities produced.
(2) What was the total Commonwealth Government funding provided for research and development of organic agricultural methods in each of the previous 5 years.

(3) Is it a fact that countries such as Denmark and Sweden have developed active pesticide policies under which they have committed themselves to reducing pesticide use by up to 50 per cent during the l990s.
(4) What progress has been made towards developing a pesticide policy for Australia and when can such a policy be expected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is little factual information on the impact on agricultural production that would result from a 100 per cent conversion to organic production methods in Australia, although I am informed that a number of studies are currently being conducted by various State Departments of Agriculture that relate to production levels associated with organic production methods.

Some estimate of the impact of a 100 per cent conversion to organic production methods may be obtained by examining the importance of agricultural chemicals to Australian agriculture. This was addressed by the Report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals. The Senate Select Committee, although not arriving at a definitive figure, reported that "farm chemicals have a significant beneficial economic impact on Australia".

(2) Data for Commonwealth funding of agricultural research and development is not collated on the basis of organic versus other production methods. Hence the information required to answer the honourable senator's question is not readily available and I regret that I am unable to provide an accurate response to this part of his question. I am informed however, that the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation is assembling available information on the issue and I undertake to provide the Honourable Senator with that information as soon as it is available to me.

(3 & 4) In relation to pesticide policy in Australia, the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development contains a number of objectives that relate to agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Objective 1.5 of the Strategy calls on Governments to assess the merits of setting indicative targets for the use of selected agricultural and veterinary chemicals. This issue was considered by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council who referred the matter to the first meeting of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Policy Committee, held in November 1993.

The Agricultural and Chemicals Policy Committee agreed with the need to monitor international policy developments regarding pest and disease management such as those of the Nordic countries. While it is correct that countries such as Sweden have targeted a 50 per cent reduction in agricultural pesticide use in the 1990's, it must be noted that it is not always in Australia's best interests to adopt similar policies. The key issue for consideration in the assessment of national targets in Australia, is one of improved pest and disease management, and as pesticide reduction is only one aspect of improved management, it is inappropriate to consider it outside of this context. The Agricultural and Veterinary Policy Committee also considered that the National Registration Authority's proposed Existing Chemicals Review Program which is due to commence in the first half of 1994, was the most appropriate forum for assessing the need to reduce the use of selected agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 9 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total value of resources devoted to the delivery by the ABC of domestic free-to-air television services in the 1992-93 financial year.
(2) What are the projected figures for the same in the 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.
(3) Will any of the resources devoted to the free-to-air services, as above, be redirected to any of the ABC's commercial enterprises; if so, to what extent and to which enterprise.
(4) Will the independence, quality or availability of the ABC's free-to-air service be affected in any way by the ABC's involvement in Pay Television; if so, in what way.

(5) (a) What has the ABC projected as its yearly operating cost for Licence C; (b) how does the ABC intend to meet this cost; and (c) what planning measures has the ABC taken to achieve this objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice received from the ABC:

PARA.TAB: (1) The value of resources is $286.526 million.
(2) For 1993-94 the projected estimate is $292.69 million. The 1994-95 figure is subject to a new financial funding agreement currently being negotiated with Government.

(3) In the case of Australia Television International (ATV), no ABC free-to-air service resources are redirected to ATV operations; however, access is made available to the service for such resources as underutilised satellite capacity and raw program material including News and normal programs. Such access has no effect on the free-to-air application.

No ABC free-to-air resources will be redirected to the ABC's participation in Pay TV. The terms of the Government decision on ABC involvement in Pay TV included that activities be undertaken on a commercial basis with no further calls on Budget funding, and that there be no detriment to the ABC's free-to-air services. Detailed arrangements are currently being developed to implement the Government's decision, including provision for a transparent charging and accounting regime to further safeguard the ABC free-to-air services. Common use of certain facilities at no detriment to their free-to-air application will be technologically possible and appropriate. This includes the use of Trans Pacific satellite capacity, interconnection with the integrated BASYS news data network; integration with the voice data network; use of the domestic satellite interchange facilities; access to raw originated ABC vision material and ABC domestic and international correspondents; access to ABC news and program libraries and general information resources. Such access will operate in accordance with the charging and accounting regime being developed and will not in any way diminish the effectiveness or attribution of fixed facilities and resources in their day to day free-to-air application.

(4) The independence, quality and availability of the ABC's free-to-air television service will continue unabated with the advent of Pay TV. The ABC envisages that Pay TV will supplement its free-to-air services by permitting programming on a more specialised and extended basis in such areas as news, children's, documentary and cultural programming, including drama and comedy.

(5) (a) The estimated annual operating cost of Licence C is commercially confidential. However, the ABC has advised it has calculated the full operational cost for the delivery of two channels comprising news and information programming for one channel and children's, documentary and cultural material for the other as separate, stand alone operations reflecting the arm's length costing and charging arrangements as independently determined.

(b) The ABC indicated it intends to meet the operational cost by way of capitalisation of the service comprising a mixture of cash contribution via the $12.5 million start-up-grant allocated in the current financial year by the Commonwealth, allocation of back catalogue from ABC resources and financial partnership with investors meeting the capitalisation costs of the service.

The ABC has estimated the external capitalisation requirements of the service at approximately $50 million by way of combination of equity and debt predicated on conservative penetration rate assumptions.

(c) The ABC's planning activities for the delivery of subscription broadcast services commenced in 1991. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 20 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has there been any off-shore exploration for hydro-carbons off the western coast of Cape York Peninsula; if so, what are the results of this exploration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The area offshore from the west coast of Cape York lies within the Gulf of Carpentaria. There is presently one offshore petroleum exploration permit held in this area—permit Q/22P, held by Comalco Aluminium Ltd (Comalco). Since the permit was awarded in 1990, Comalco has completed 2657 kilometres of seismic data acquisition and the permit area is continuing to be actively explored.

Only limited exploration drilling has been undertaken in the Gulf of Carpentaria and to date no significant hydrocarbon shows have been encountered. In 1961, minor hydrocarbon shows were encountered in shallow sediments in two wells drilled on Mornington Island in the southern part of the Gulf.

In 1984 the Duyken No. 1 well was drilled in a water depth of 59 metres, to the west of permit Q/22P and on the Northern Territory side of the Gulf. The section drilled was not entirely as predicted, indicating that further exploration was required for a better understanding of the geology underlying the Gulf. The well failed to find hydrocarbons.

In 1989, Phoenix Resources Company of Australia undertook a geophysical survey of the area north of permit Q/22P. The seismic data obtained showed that an undrilled sedimentary basin, the Bamaga Basin, underlies the Jurassic-Cretaceous Carpentaria Basin.

Most of the Gulf of Carpentaria was held under exploration permit in the early 1980's. During this period, the Gulf was explored with geophysical surveys, mainly at a reconnaissance level. This exploration provided fair seismic resolution of the younger sediments (the Carpentaria Basin sequence). Geophysical surveys were also carried out prior to 1980, but the data are of poor quality and of little use for hydrocarbon exploration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 21 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given that under subsection 117(1) of the Telecommunications Act 1991 the Minister for Transport and Communications must determine the Telecommunications National Code, could the Minister explain why he has not yet signed the determination for a National Code when in fact the Telecommunications Act 1991 has been in place for about 2 years.
(2) Why has there been an AUSTEL redraft of the Draft Telecommunications National Code for over 12 months which has not yet been acted on.
(3) At approximately what date is it expected that the determination for a Telecommunications National Code will be signed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) In December 1991 the then Minister for Transport and Communications published a draft Telecommunications National Code following extensive consultations amongst relevant Commonwealth Departments, the carriers, potential second carriers, State, Territory and Local Authorities and AUSTEL.

Carriers have been required to observe this draft code from that time. The draft code has been working effectively by facilitating the rapid roll-out of network infrastructure, while ensuring the carriers are environmentally responsible. There has been minimal public criticism of the way the carriers have complied with the draft Code.

Concurrently with publishing the draft Code, the then Minister for Transport and Communications requested AUSTEL to hold a public inquiry to facilitate discussion on the draft Code and to provide feedback to the Government on the comments received.

AUSTEL reported to the then Minister for Transport and Communications on the draft Telecommunications National Code in September 1992. AUSTEL noted that a large number of those who commented found the wording of the draft Code legalistic and difficult to understand. Bearing in mind the need for the Code to be understandable to the community at large, AUSTEL suggested that the Code be redrafted in plain English, in a manner that recognises the need for precision. The Government accepted the suggestion in AUSTEL's report but this has required extensive reworking of the Code, including further lengthy consultations with the carriers and the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency (CEPA).

A further factor contributing to the delay in finalising the Telecommunications National Code was the decision of the Parliament in May 1993 to amend the Telecommunications Act 1991 to provide for a code of conduct to regulate the carriers' use of land access powers, provided to them under Part 7 of the Act. The code of conduct was seen as a desirable safeguard at the time the general carriers' land access powers were extended to mobile carriers.

There are conceptual and procedural similarities between the Land Access Code and the Telecommunications National Code: both provide for safeguard mechanisms to operate in place of other established legislative frameworks; and both are characterised by requirements for consultation, regulation and consultation. Consequently there was a need to ensure both Codes interrelated and were mutually compatible.

(3) Extensive consultations on the Land Access Code were required with the carriers, AUSTEL, and the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman. These consultations have now been completed. Both codes of conduct are therefore now in the final stages of redrafting. It is expected that the revised National Code and the Land Access Code will be available for tabling in the Autumn 1994 sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to question on notice No. 824 (Senate Hansard, 1 February 1994, page 150), is it appropriate, in any circumstances, for the chairperson of a commission established under federal legislation to write to a minor party asking the leader to vote against a motion before the Parliament seeking to establish an inquiry into that particular commission when its accountability for expenditure of public money is the subject of the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: As indicated in the response to Question No. 824, one of the considerations in determining the appropriateness of the actions outlined in the Question is the content of the motion in question and its relationship (if any) to the powers and functions of the commission in question.

It is conceivable, for example, that where a commission has powers and functions to represent particular interests, or to develop and implement policies and programs in cooperation with those interests, it would be appropriate for the commission chair to make contact with political parties.
